titleStmt.title: The schoolemaster, or teacher of table philosophie A most pleasant and merie companion, wel worthy to be welcomed (for a dayly gheast) not onely to all mens boorde, to guyde them with moderate [and] holsome dyet: but also into euery mans companie at all tymes, to recreate their mindes, with honest mirth and delectable deuises: to sundrie pleasant purposes of pleasure and pastyme. Gathered out of diuers, the best approued auctours: and deuided into foure pithy and pleasant treatises, as it may appeare by the contentes.
titleStmt.author: Twyne, Thomas, 1543-1613.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: The Schoolema≈øter, or Teacher of Table Philo≈øophie. A mo≈øt plea≈øant and merie companion, wel worthy to be welcomed (for a dayly Ghea≈øt) not onely to all mens boorde, to guyde them with moderate & hol≈øome dyet: but al≈øo into euery mans companie at all tymes, to recreate their mindes, with hone≈øt mirth and delectable deui≈øes: to ≈øundrie plea≈øant purpo≈øes of plea≈øure and pa≈øtyme. Gathered out of diuers, the be≈øt approued Auctours: and deuided into foure pithy and plea≈øant Treati≈øes, as it may appeare by the contentes.
‚ùß Imprinted at London, by Richarde Jones: dwelling oueragayn≈øt S. Sepulchers Church without Newgate. 1576.

div.head: ‚ùß The Printers preamble to al e≈øtates, for the friendly entertaynment of this Teacher of Table Philo≈øophie.

lg.l: YOu worthy wights, that hautie halles do hold,
Who≈øe tables ≈øundrie ≈øtates do dayly haunt:
Giue leaue (my Lords) this Teacher may be bold
To prea≈øe in place, and ≈øhew him ≈øelfe a flaunt,
Among≈øt your merie ghea≈øts of ≈øere & ≈øundry ≈øort,
To play his merie partes, in playn & plea≈øant ≈øport.
What though his phra≈øe, & ≈øtile be rudely framd,
His fruits are furthering to your healthes auayle:
To deale in dayly dyet, although he may be blamd,
To tell his minde therin he doeth not fayle,
To ≈øhew the diuers kinds, of euery meat and drinke
Bread, broath, fle≈øh, fi≈øh, or what you els can thinke.
Yea, more then this, he meaneth for to ≈øhow
Among the ≈øtates your table round about
Demeanour meet from hie vnto the low,
For ech degree to teach he doeth not doubt:
The Prince, the page, the Gentle and the ≈ølaue,
To ≈øerue his proper turne example heere may haue.
Diuines perhaps, wyll hearken to his tale.
The warlyke knight, the Squire, the ≈øouldier h ‚Ä¢ ld,
The marchant eke that makes the merie ≈øale.
The lawier to that pleads the ca≈øe for gold.
The Ladie bright will heare when he doeth ≈øpeak,
The widow, wyfe, chyld, mayd, lame, blind, & weak,
His problemes fine, wil ≈øomwhat plea≈øe you all,
And queint demaundes, ≈øo pithie in ech poinct
His ie≈øtes I knowe will plea≈øe both great ≈ømall
And hit your veyne, and nick you on the ioinct
What ≈øo you be, or where you do ≈øoiourne
This plea≈øant pithy booke wyll ≈øurely ≈øerue your turne,
Then bid him welcome, Gentles all, and ≈øay:
Come merie Ghea≈øt, come neare and ≈øit thee down,
Vndoe thy packe, ≈øhow foorth we do thee pray
Such newes as may vs mery make in field & town:
Thus him to you I leaue, to ≈øee what he can ≈øhow,
For doubtle≈ø≈øe, I to ioy your mindes, this trauaile dyd be≈øtow.

div.head: To the right wor≈øhipfull M. Alexander Nowell, Deane of the Cathedrall Churche of S. Paules in London, Grace and peace from God, &c.
div.p:
RIght wor≈øhipful, hauing by chance happened on this Pamflet, comming vnto my hands both without name and orderly beginning: I did not onely peru≈øe it my ≈øelf (according to my ≈øimple ≈økil) but shewed it al≈øo vnto ≈øome of my freends: of who≈øe learning & Iudgement very many haue good opinion, and beeing therto ≈øufficiently willing of my ≈øelf, I was by them and others exhorted to publish the ≈øame in print, for that it ≈øeemed to containe nothing els but hole≈øome diet, ≈øauced with honest mirth and plea≈øant pa≈øtimes: and interlaced with pithy and effectual examples, tending vnto the aduauÃÑcement of vertue and ≈øuppre≈øsion of vice, a fit meane to delight and recreate the weake, & ≈øpecially the ouer weryed ≈øpirits of Studients. Now calling vnto my remembrance (which I cannot forget) the manifolde benefits & curte≈øies at all times by your worship be≈øtowed on me & mine, a≈øwel in calliÃÑg me (mo≈øte vnworthy) not a few times vnto your table, as otherwi≈øe, the lea≈øt part wherof I am not able of my ≈øelf to recoÃÑpence: my good wil not wanting, but mine abilitie fayling. I haue now pre≈øumed to offer this poore pre≈øent vnto you, comming from an vnfained hart, partely the
trauaile of another man, but the te≈øtimony of my harty affection, hoping that your worship wil accept it in the better part, the rather becau≈øe I haue perceiued you among other graue and waightie matters (a≈øwel of Religion as otherwi≈øe) to ≈øolace your ≈øelf and others at your Table, with ≈øeemly mirth in opportunities vttered, according to the knowledge and capacitie of tho≈øe your poore neighbours and others with whom your bourd is alwaies furnished, either coÃÑcerning the qualities of meats, or their v≈øages in forrain coÃÑtries, to the great delectation of the hearers: To the which purpo≈øe, there is much matter ≈øet down in this pre≈øent work, as al≈øo to other effect, wherein if there shalbe any thing founde, not conuenient for your learned view and ≈øeuere Iudgement: I hartely craue your worships pardon: prote≈øting, that the ≈øame is not written for ≈øo graue eares, but de≈øirous to plea≈øe all ≈øortes in hone≈øt delight: I thought it good not to leaue out any thing, but to admonish, that who ≈øo shall not ≈øo well like of ≈øome trifling tales of this book, in the fourth part, he may ≈øufficieÃÑtly recreate him≈øelf in the other .iii. parts.

Thus much hauing been ouer bolde to vtter my minde vnto your worship, pre≈øuming vpon your accu≈øtomed humanitie, there remaineth no more, but that I commend you vnto the tuition of the almightie: who alwaies keepe you and yours, and ≈øend you now a mery new yeer and many, to his good plea≈øure and glory. Amen.

div.head: This fir≈øt booke of Table Philo≈øophie ≈øheweth the nature and qualitie of all manner meates, drinkes and ≈øawces, that are v≈øed at meales.
div.p: ACcording to the ≈øaying of Macrobius. Macrobi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lib. 1. de Saturnalia. It were a very vn≈øeemely thing that Philo≈øophie which intreateth curiou≈øly in bookes, of dueties, & behauiour at fea≈øtes, ≈øhould be afearde to ≈øhew her ≈øelf al≈øo at fea≈øtes: as who ≈øhould ≈øay, ≈øhee would not auouch that in deedes, which ≈øhee profe≈ø≈øeth in words: Or that ≈øhee could keepe no meane or mea≈øure, who only pre≈øcribeth the meane and mea≈øure her ≈øelf vnto al humane affaires. Neither do I now welcome her to my table to thintent ≈øhee ≈øhould moderate her≈øelf, who≈øe order of in≈øtruction is to teach all other, how to moderate and gouerne them≈øelues. And ≈øhortly after in the ≈øame place he ≈øayth, VVherfore, ≈øuch a kinde of Philo≈øophie, there is no goodman, no place, nor companie, that wyll exclude it, which ≈øo behaueth it ≈øelf in euerie re≈øpect, that it ≈øeemeth to be nece≈ø≈øarie in euerie place, as though it were vnlawfull it ≈øhould be ab≈øent. Then fora≈ømuch as moderate Philo≈øophie ought to be pre≈øent at the table and fea≈øtes of the wi≈øe, and learned: euerie goodman mu≈øt v≈øe the ≈øame, both for to profite & delight others. For as the ≈øame Macrobius writeth, our talke ought to be merie at the table, more poudred with plea≈øure the ≈øauced with ≈øeueritie. And our communication at the boorde, as it ought to be faier with hone≈øtie: ≈øo mu≈øt it be plea≈øant with delight. VVherfore, it is generally expedient, that all table talke be either concerning the nature & qualitie of the meates and drinkes wherof we feede, or of table que≈øtions wherwith we may be made merie and ≈øturred vp to mirth at the boorde, or els touching them their condition, and manners with whom we meete at the table, or la≈øtly of ≈øuch meriments and hone≈øt deui≈øes wherwith we may be refre≈øhed and delighted at our meate. And for this cau≈øe I haue determined to intitle this worke, The Schoolema≈øter or teacher of Table Philo≈øophie, and haue diuided the ≈øame into foure ≈øeuerall partes. The Arguments wherof, I haue thought good to ≈øet downe together before the whole worke, and afterwardes euerie Argument ≈øeuerally before eche booke whereto it belongeth.

div.head: ‚ùß The Argument of the fir≈øt booke, which is of naturall Philo≈øophie.
div.p: The fir≈øt booke treateth of the nature and qualitie of all manner of meates, drinkes, and ≈øauces, that are v≈øed at meales.

div.head: The Argument of the ≈øecond booke, which is morall Philo≈øophie.
div.p: The ≈øecond booke ≈øpeaketh of the manners, bebauiour, and v≈øage of all ≈øuch, with whom we may happen to be conuer≈øaunt withall, a≈øwell at the table, as all other times among companie.

div.head: The Argument of the thirde booke, and is of naturall Philo≈øophie.
div.p: The third booke conteyneth certayne delectable and plea≈øaunt que≈øtions and pretie Problemes to be propounded for myrth among companie at all times, but mo≈øt conueniently at the table.

div.head: The Argument of the fourth booke, and is of morall di≈øcour≈øes.
div.p: The fourth booke, compri≈øeth honest Ie≈øtes, delectable deui≈øes and plea≈øaunt purpo≈øes to be v≈øed among companie, for delight and recr ‚Ä¢ ation at all times, but especially at meale times at the table.

body.head: ¬∂ The Teacher of Table Phylo≈øophy, a≈øwell Naturall as Morall.

div.head: The first Booke of Meates, Drinks, and Sauces.
Chap. 1. ¬∂Of conuenient time to eate meate, and how often a Man may eate according to his Complection.
div.p:
NOw fir≈øt of all, let vs ≈øee concerninge the time and houre to eate, which were the mo≈øt conuenieÃÑt: wherof Rha≈øis maketh mencion, ≈øaying,Rha≈øis. that it is be≈øt time to eate, when the weight of the meate which we eate la≈øt before is funck downwarde, and the bottome of the ≈øtomacke is become light, and there remaine no ≈øwelling nor fulnes, and a man haue moderatly exerci≈øed him≈øelf before, & h√©e haue a good appetite: then is it ye be≈øt time to feade. Moreouer, as the ≈øame aucthour ≈øaieth, a man mu≈øt take h√©ede that h√©e defer not to feade when his appetite ≈øerueth him, vnle≈ø≈øe it b√©e ≈øome counterfeit appetite, ≈øuch as chaunceth ≈øumtimes to Drunkards, and tho≈øe that loath their meate. But ≈øo ≈øoone as one that is not drunke, beginneth to haue an appetite, and the nouri≈øhment which h√©e receiued before were not mutch nor gro≈ø≈øe: then ought he to eate pre≈øently without all delay. But if h√©e deferre eating ≈øo longe vntill his appetite b√©e pa≈øt which h√©e had before: then were it be≈øt for him to eate ≈øome of the Syrupe of Violets, or the Syrupe called Aceto≈øus, or drinke warme water, and ≈øo to ab≈øtaine from eating vntil he haue vomited, or gone to ≈øtoole, or that his appetite begin to come againe. Likewi≈øe, the ≈øame aucthor in ye ≈øame place ≈øaieth farther. This is very diligently to be ob≈øerued, that euery man eate ≈øuch meates as he hath binne accu≈øtomed vnto, and v≈øe to f√©ede as oft as hee hath binne woont, vnle≈ø≈øe this cu≈øtome of his hath bin √©euell, and therfore ought to bee e≈øchued
howbeit not ≈øuddenly, but by meanes, and by litle and litle. And a man mu≈øt ≈øo di≈øpo≈øe his feeding times, that hee eate twi≈øe beetw√©ene one day and a night, or at the mo≈øt twi≈øe in one day, or, which is more temperate thri≈øe in two dayes. As for tho≈øe which haue leane and drie bodyes, it is hurtfull vnto them to eate but once in a day. And it is √©euell for ≈øutch as haue gro≈ø≈øe and fat bodies to eate twi≈øe in aday. Al≈øo tho≈øe that do exerci≈øe them≈øelues, and labour mutch, haue neede of meate of more gro≈ø≈øe ≈øub≈øtaunce then tho≈øe which v≈øe contrary order, who require contrary meates.

Auerrois. in Cant. Auicen.The Commentarie writer Auerrois, vpon the Canticles of Auicen, ≈øaith thus: It is a more temperate and orderly cu≈øtome for a man to f√©ede twi≈øe in two daies. For ≈øome doo thinke that the perfection of the third dige≈øtion is accompli≈øhed in eight√©ene houres, in proportion whereof when we eate thr√©e refections the dige≈øtion thereof is fini≈øhed in all partes of the body in that time, or much there aboute. And whereas I woulde haue eight√©ene houres b√©etw√©ene two meales: it is therby euident that the mo≈øt conuenient time to eate, is when a man f√©eleth him≈øelfe lightned, and hath fully dige≈øted the meat which h√©e eate before.

div.head: Chap. 2. Of Appetite, and cu≈øtome to eate.
div.p:
Auicen. in Cant.COncerning Appetite and cu≈øtome to eate, Auicen writeth in the ≈øecond part of his Canticles. Wherefore let a man f√©ede according to the v≈øe and cu≈øtome of his owne nature, not omitting to eate tho≈øe meats that are delectable. Vpon which place Auerrois writeth thus,Auerrois. in his Commentarie: Cu≈øtome is likened vnto Nature, which is to ≈øay, Cu≈øtome mu≈øt n√©edes be ob≈øerued although it were √©euell, and not to b√©e commended. And wheras h√©e ≈øaith: Appetite is not to b√©e omitted, which is a precept of this Art: it is to be vnder≈øtood in all meates whether they be de≈øired for that they bee of their owne Nature commendable, or otherwi≈øe. And therfore it is ≈øaid, that of two ≈øortes of meates that which is le≈ø≈øe
good and plea≈øeth more the Appetite: is better for vs, then that which is better and le≈ø≈øe plea≈øeth our fan≈øie.Rha≈øis. Rha≈øis al≈øo vpon the fourth of Alman≈øor ≈øaith: it chaunceth manie times,Alm. 4 that ≈øome meates that are √©euell, are founde to agr√©e with ≈øome natures which cannot ab≈øtaine froÃÑ them as other ≈øome can. And perhaps ≈øome meates that are good, are perceiued not to agree with ≈øome mens ≈øtomackes, from which it were good for them to ab≈øtaine wholy. And if there b√©e ≈øome meats agr√©eing with ≈øome Natures which are de≈øirous of them, although they bee not good nor hol≈øome: yet are they to bee y√©elded vnto the Appetite, vnle≈ø≈øe they bee exc√©edinge eeuell‚ñ™ and a man mu≈øt beware that hee v≈øe not alwaies naughtie nutriment.

div.head: Chap. 3. Of the order of Meales, and eating Meate.
div.p:
THE cau≈øe why our Dige≈øtion is many times corrupt is this: becau≈øe at one meale w√©e f√©ede on ≈øundrie ≈øortes of Meates, eatinge the gro≈ø≈øe b√©efore the fine, and fillinge our ≈øelues with ≈øundry kinde of cates made with broathes thickned with grated bread, and to to long protracting the tyme from the b√©eginning of the Meale to the ende. But for the better ordering of our diet, w√©e mu≈øt note: that it is be≈øt in Winter to v≈øe meates actually hot, and in Summer actually colde. Howbeit we mu≈øt beware of Meates ouer hot as they come out of the pot, or from the fire, and take h√©ede of them that are verye colde, as ≈øutch as are cooled vpon the Snowe. Auicen in his Canticles ≈øaieth thus: that moy≈øt and ≈ølipperie meates are to bee eaten beefore ≈øutch as binde,Auicen. and that which is ≈øw√©ete mu≈øt b√©e mingled with that which is ≈øower, and the dry corrected with the moy≈øt, and the colde with the hot. And wheras we ≈øay that the moi≈øte and liquid mu≈øt be taken before the binding: that is a precept in the regiment and order of meate, for that it is required to the pre≈øeruation
of health, that the meate be mea≈øured in qualytie, quantytie, time, & order. Adding al≈øo vnto the≈øe conditions, yt the Meate be good, and well dre≈ø≈øed. Which rule is gathered of the contrarie, to wit, that one contrarie be brought to a iu≈øt temperature by his contrarie, as are the qualeties ≈øw√©et by ≈øower, drie by moi≈øt, cold by warmthe, and ≈øutch like, aboue recited.

div.head: Chap. 4. Of a conuenient place to feede in.
div.p: Auicen.ACcording to the aduerti≈øement of Auicen in his Canticles, we ought to haue a ≈øpeciall regard to the place wherin we f√©ede, that it be quiet and colde, and through blowne with the winde, and that it be ≈øo at the time and houre when wee intend to feede therin. And therfore in this poynt it behooueth a man to be dylygent.Auerrois. Auerrois the Commentarie writer ≈øaieth, that we mu≈øt looke to this mo≈øt e≈øpecially in Summer, becau≈øe then erternall heat w√©ekeneth naturall heat, lyke as the ≈øhining of the Sunne putteth out the fire if it come to it, and yet when the fire is once come into the ≈øhadowe it reuiueth againe.Rha≈øis. And Rha≈øis in the place aboue recited, willeth vs to eate our meate at coole times, and if ca≈øe we cannot get a colde place, yet to watch a colde time to f√©ede in, and ≈øo after that we be refre≈øhed we may ≈øl√©epe, and take our re≈øt.

div.head: Chap. 5. Of Meates and Drinkes, wheron wee feede at the Table.
div.p:
HEreafter w√©e haue to intreate of ≈øuch meats and drinkes as are for the mo≈øt part v≈øed at the Table. And fir≈øt of Bread,Rha≈øis. Rha≈øis writeth vpon the third Booke of Alman≈øor, ≈øayinge: Breade that is made of Wheat is in many re≈øpectes mo≈øt conuenient f ‚Ä¢ r men, e≈øpecially if it be wel ≈øea≈øoned, wel leauened, well ‚Ä¢ aked, fine ground, & purely clen≈øed, although it be then ≈øumwhat hard of concoction.Auicen. And Auicen ≈øheweth the cau≈øe why it is ≈øo: ≈øaying that the better it is boulted the ea≈øier it is of di≈øge≈øtion, and ≈øo m ‚Ä¢ tch the harder how mutch
the more it is ful of Bran. And the cau≈øe is: for that the bran hindreth the pa≈ø≈øedge, and the ≈ølipperine≈ø≈øe of the voydinge of it. And that is the be≈øt bread whiche is baked in an Ouen, temperatly ≈øea≈øoned and leauened, and made light, that when it is cut it be hollow like a ≈øpunge. Moreouer Rha≈øis in the place before alleadged, affirmeth ye vnleauened bread is hard to di≈øge≈øt, and di≈øcendeth ≈ølowly out of the ≈øtomack, cau≈øinge griping in the bellie, ob≈øtruction in the liuer, and procureth grief in th ‚Ä¢ kidneis. H√©e ≈øaith al≈øo that Barlie bread is colder then Wheaten, of ≈ømall nutriment ingendring windyne≈ø≈øe, the collick, and other colde di≈øea≈øes, & maketh a man co≈øtiffe. The bread of other kinds of graine is of qualitie according to the nature of the graine of which it is made. Auicen ≈øaith, let no Man eate Bread while it is hot, but when it is one night olde.

div.head: Chap. 6. Of Wine, and the qualyties thereof.
div.p:
WYne, as I≈øaac ≈øayeth in the thirde booke of dietes,I≈øaac. cau≈øeth good nutriment, bringeth health to the body, and pre≈øerueth the ≈øame. And there is no drink nor meate to be founde ≈øo comfortable vnto naturall heate, by rea≈øon of a certen famyliaritie with it, for naturally it ≈øtrengthneth di≈øge≈øtion. The heate therof is lyke vnto naturall heate, and therfore it is ≈øoone conuerted into naturall and mo≈øt pure bloud. It claryfieth thick bloud, ≈øerching the pa≈ø≈øadges of the whole body, but ≈øpecially of the veines, and clen≈øeth them, it openeth the Liuer, it taketh away darke ≈ømokine≈ø≈øe whiche ingendereth heauine≈ø≈øe, repelling the ≈øame from the hart, it comforteth al parts of the body, it cau≈øeth the minde to forget ≈øorow and griefe, it bringeth mirth, it maketh hardie, it ≈øharpneth the wit. Wherfore it is conuenient for all ages, all ≈øea≈øons, all cuntreis, being receaued according to ye cu≈øtome of him that drinketh the Wine, as ≈øo much his nature is able to beare. Thus is it manife≈øt, that Wine is good for all men if they
take it moderatly. And therefore in ould times, Wine was likened vnto the great triacle, and to the Nature therof. For it heateth colde bodies, and cooleth hot, it moi≈øtneth the drie, and drieth the moi≈øt. And many times it quencheth the thir≈øt more then water.Rha≈øis. Rha≈øis in the fore alleaged place of his third booke, ≈øaith thus: Wine generally heateth the ≈øtomack, and liuer, making pa≈ø≈øedge for the nutriment, it al≈øo increa≈øeth blood, and flea≈øh, and augmenteth naturall heate, helping nature to accompli≈øh her peculiar functions. By Wine dige≈øtion beecommeth ≈øtronger, ≈øuperfluities are expul≈øed, and the pa≈ø≈øedge made ea≈øie for their riddance. By wine health is permaneÃÑt, and ≈øtrength abideth, & oldage kept away. Wine al≈øo maketh the ≈øoule merie, but if it b√©e immoderatly taken it hurteth the Liuer, braine, and Sinewes, it breadeth the Trembling, the Pal≈øie, and Apoplexie, and bringeth ≈øuddein death.

div.head: Chap. 7. Of Meade, and the properties therof.
div.p: Rha≈øis.THe drinke which is made of Honie coÃÑmonly called Meade, by the auctorytie of Rha≈øis is verie hot, ingendring redde Choler. It agreeth not with hot complexions, but it is verie conuenient for colde temperatures.Auicen. Auerrois al≈øo vpon the Canticles of Auicen, ≈øaith, that Mead is better then wine, for ≈øutch as haue naturall f√©eble ≈øinewes.

div.head: Chap. 8. Of ≈øtrong or double Ale.
div.p: Rha≈øis, DOuble Ale ≈øaith Rha≈øis, in the place aboue recited, & chiefly which is made of Barly, hurteth the ≈øinewes, maketh the head to ake, filleth the bodie with winde, but it prouoketh vrine, and repre≈ø≈øeth the heate which cummeth of drunkenne≈ø≈øe. But that Ale which is made of wheate, hauinge in it Mintes and Smaledge, well burned‚ñ™ is ≈øuppo≈øed to b√©e better for all men, but e≈øpecially it is forbidden them that are hot in the Sun and conuer≈øant abroade, and of hot di≈øpo≈øition, and in an hot time of the y√©ere.

div.head: Chap. 9. Of flea≈øh in generall.
div.p: IT is confirmed by the auctority of Rha≈øis in the place before alleaged,Rha≈øis. that of all nutriments Flea≈øh nouri≈øheth mo≈øt ≈øoone≈øt, fatteth, and ≈øtrengthneth. And tho≈øe that v≈øe it mutch: haue full bodies, and haue n√©ede to b√©e let blood often, and ≈øpecially if they drinke wine with it. Generally, all flea≈øh heateth, and is counted vnm√©ete for tho≈øe that haue an Ague, and are troubled with replecion. Flea≈øh that is red without fat: nouri≈øheth more then that which hath fat, for it ingendreth le≈ø≈øe ≈øuperfluitie, and ≈øtrengthneth the ≈øtomack more. Cour≈øe flea≈øh which is of gro≈ø≈øe ≈øub≈øtance is fit for ≈øutch as laboure, and fine flea≈øh for tho≈øe that v≈øe ≈ømall exerci≈øe.

div.head: Chap. 10. Of the flea≈øh of wilde bea≈øtes.
div.p: EVerie bea≈øt generally, according to the diui≈øion of I≈øaac in his third booke of Dietes, is either wilde, or tame.I≈øaac. The Fleash of wilde bea≈øts is drie, and hard of dige≈øtion, and y√©eldeth di≈øcommendable iuce by rea≈øon of their ouermutch motion and exerci≈øe which they v≈øe, and the heat and drieth of ye aire wherin they abide, hapning through the vehement heat of the Sun, and lacke of couert from the parching Sun beames. So that wilde flea≈øh is of no good Nutriment, neither in qualitie nor quantitie, ≈øauinge onely the flea≈øh of wilde Goates. For their naturall coldne≈ø≈øe is mutch repre≈ø≈øed by the ouermutch heate and drieth, wherto they do accu≈øtome them≈øelues. Wherfore, ≈øeinge al≈øo that the ta≈øt and vn≈øauerie ≈ømell of their flea≈øh is corrected by their exerci≈øe: it is ≈øome helpe vnto dige≈øtion, that their flea≈øh may be very wel and ea≈øely concocted. Al other tame bea≈øts in compari≈øon to ye wilde: are better to b√©e liked of, & do more nouri≈øh, by rea≈øon of their quietnes, & the temperate aire, yet are thei ≈øumdeale gro≈ø≈øe & hard of dige≈øtion. And among the≈øe in my iudgment, the Male bea≈øt is hotter & in different moi≈øt aboue ye female, and is therfore more commended and ye ≈øooner dige≈øted. The flea≈øh of the female, is more colde with immoderate moy≈øture, and therfore ≈ølower of dige≈øtion. And ye flea≈øh of tho≈øe bea≈øts that are gelded is of a middle nature betw√©ene both.

div.head: Chap. 11. Of Kiddes fleash.
div.p: Rha≈øis.AGaine, in the place of Rha≈øis by m√©e erewhile alleaged, it is writen of Kiddes fleash, that it is temperate, hauinge no √©euel quality mixt with it, which albeit it ingender temperat blood: yet is it not conuenient for labourers. As for ≈øutch as take no great paine, but liue a gentlemans lyfe: they cannot chu≈øe a better kinde of meate then this. For it is not altogether ≈øo ea≈øie of concoction that it de≈øtroieth the di≈øge≈øtion, neither yet y√©eldeth it ≈øo gro≈ø≈øe or ≈øutch plenty of nutriment that the body be therby filled with replection, and corrupte bloud ingendred. But the bloud that is made thereof, is betw√©ene both, as neither thick nor thin: hot nor colde. In the ≈øame place al≈øo I≈øaac ≈øaieth, that the ≈øucking Kiddes are the be≈øt, of al other mo≈øt excellent both for ta≈øt, nouri≈øhment, and di≈øge≈øtion, ingendring good bloud, for the milke which they ≈øuck of their DaÃÑmes giueth vnto them naturall moi≈øture.

div.head: Chap. 12. Of Lambe.
div.p: I≈øaac.LAmbes fleash al≈øo, as ≈øaith ye ≈øame mine aucthor I≈øaac in the place often before alleaged, is good while they ≈øuck, by rea≈øon of the ≈øtoare of moi≈øture & ≈ølimines: yet the ≈øuperfluity of fleame which it ingendereth wherby it ≈ølippeth foorth of the ≈øtomack before it be fully concocted: maketh it ≈øumwhat fautie.Auerrois. Howbeit Auerrois in the fifte of his Collections ≈øetteth downe, how that mo≈øt conuenient it is that Lambes Flea≈øh be placed in goodne≈ø≈øe next vnto Kiddes Flea≈øh, whiche although it haue mutch ≈øuperfluity: yet is it of a moderate, and commendable temperature.

div.head: Chap. 13. Of Rammes fleash.
div.p:
Rha≈øis.TOuching the Fleash of Rammes, Rha≈øis in the place before alleaged is of opinion, that it is gro≈øer then Kiddes Fle≈øh, and increa≈øeth more the ≈øtrength of Man, y√©elding mutch more ≈øuperfluitie then Kiddes Flea≈øh doth. Young Rammes
of one y√©ere olde are better then Lambs or Ewes, for if their flea≈øhe b√©e well dige≈øted it ingendreth plentie of blood, and that good, ≈øpecially if it b√©e Weathers flea≈øh, for the heate and moi≈øture of it is temperate which cau≈øeth the flea≈øh to haue a very good ta≈øt. But Galen the prince of Phi≈øitions,Galen as Auerrois reporteth of him in the fift of his collections, mi≈ølyketh the flea≈øh of weathers, and commendeth Veale exc√©edingly.

div.head: Cap. 14. Of Veale.
div.p: NExt in≈øueth to intreate of Veale, which according to the iudgment of Auerrois is good and hol≈øome,Auerrois as not hauing that ≈ølimine≈ø≈øe and coldene≈ø≈øe which is in B√©efe, and is more ≈øw√©ete both to the mouth and no≈øe, then any other flea≈øh. And in this re≈øpect it is better then Kid. But againe, kid is better then Veale bicau≈øe it ingendreth better humours. And mine aucthour I≈øaac in the place often aboue rehear≈øed, ≈øaith: B√©efe ingendreth gro≈ø≈øe blood, troubled, and Melancholike, y√©eldeth mutch nutriment hard of dige≈øtion, and painfully ouercome by the ≈øtomack, and difficulti di≈ø≈øolued into the partes of the bodie, and it bindeth the belly. And if a man that is of a Melancholik complexion, v≈øe to eate b√©efe: h√©e ≈øhalbe gr√©eued with the Spl√©ene, fall into a quartaine Feuer, and come into a Drop≈øie. Al≈øo h√©e ≈øhall ware itchie, haue the Morfewe, Lepro≈øie, Canker, ringewoormes, according to the complexion of him which agreeth fit with this meate.

div.head: Chap. 15. Of Swines fleash.
div.p:
AFter the iudgment of Auicen, Auicen. Swine≈øflea≈øh is more naturall vnto men then the flea≈øh of any other liuing thing on the ground, which experience it ≈øelf declareth according to Auerrois, in the fift of his Collections.I≈øaac. And I≈øaac al≈øo in the woork aboue named, writeth that Swine≈øflea≈øh is colder and moi≈øter then the flea≈øh of any other bea≈øt, e≈øpecially if it b√©e of a tame Swine. For wilde ≈øwine≈øflea≈øh in compari≈øon of tame Swine≈øflea≈øh, is hot and drie, and nouri≈øheth le≈ø≈øe. Yet is it be≈øt to f√°ede on tame ≈øwine≈øflea≈øh but ≈øeldome, and only vpon the extreame partes therof, as are the f√©ete, chappes,
and Swine≈øflea≈øh in d√©ede nouri≈øheth mutch ingendreth good iuce, and looo≈øeth the bellie by rea≈øon of the ≈øtoare of moi≈øture and ≈ølimine≈ø≈øe which is in it: howbeit, it prouoketh not vrine, and agr√©eth very well with them that v≈øe a ≈ølender diet. But the yong ≈øucking pigge is be≈øt of all, and nouri≈øheth mo≈øt, and maketh pa≈ø≈øing good blood.

div.head: Chap. 16. Of Deeres fleash, Hares fleash, and Beares fleash.
div.p: ANd ≈øtill to folow the iudgement of my fir≈øt auctour in the place aboue recited, Deares flesh is Melancholik & hard of dige≈øtion, but the yonge ≈øucking Fawnes are the be≈øt in that kinde, and the midle aged are next in goodnes vnto the≈øe, and the ould ones wor≈øt of all. The gelded buck, and the barrein Doe, are be≈øt of the two la≈øt ≈øortes, for that they b√©e of a temperate heat, & drieth. Auicen.Howbeit Auicen ≈øaith, that they make gro≈ø≈øe ≈øub≈øtance which de≈øcendeth down to fa≈øt, and breadeth the quartaine ague. And the top of the Deares taile is poy≈øon. The Hare, as ≈øaith Rha≈øis, mo≈øt certenly ingendreth Melancholick blood, aboue all other flea≈øh. But I≈øaac ≈øaith, that although it ingender drie, and gro≈ø≈øe blood: yet is it betttr then the flea≈øh of the yong Kid or Goate. And Beares fleash, as h√©e writeth, is very clammie, repugnant to dige≈øtion, and y√©elde eeuell nutriment, and is more to be v≈øed for Medicine, then for Meate.

div.head: Chap. 17. Of the partes of Bea≈øtes.
div.p: Rha≈øis.THe Head, ≈øaith Rha≈øis, of euery thing is of gro≈ø≈øe ≈øub≈øtance, nouri≈øhing much, & heateth, & ought not to be eaten but at cold ≈øea≈øons: For thereby many times is the Collick ingendred, it much comforteth bloud, & increa≈øeth the ≈ø√©ede of Man.

The Braine being colde, ouerturneth the ≈øtomack, and hurteth it, and therfore who≈øo eateth Braines: let him eate theÃÑ before al other meate. Moreouer it is good for hot Complexions, and √©euell for ≈øutch as are troubled with colde di≈øea≈øes.

Marrow cummeth very nigh vnto temperature, but it is ≈øumwhat of the hotte≈øt, it increa≈øeth naturall ≈ø√©ede, and mollifieth
the ≈øtomack. The Vdder of a bea≈øt is cold & gro≈ø≈øe, and although it nouri≈øh mutch yet is it hard of dige≈øtion, and is good for them that haue a hot ≈øtomack, and Liuer. The Liuer is hot and moi≈øt, heauie, and hard of dige≈øtion. I≈øaac ≈øaith that it ingendreth good blood, but ≈øpecially of young bea≈øtes that ≈øuck. But the Liuer of a Hen or Capon is better then of ≈øucklinges. The Hart, as h√©e ≈øaith, is of an hard ≈øub≈øtance, and is ≈ølowly dige≈øted, but being well dige≈øted: it nouri≈øheth mutch. The lights al≈øo, ≈øaith h√©e, is ea≈øely concocted, and ≈øoone departeth foorth of the ≈øtomack, by ‚Ä¢ ea≈øon of the lightnes, and rarenes of the ≈øub≈øtance therof. The Kidneis are naughty in two re≈øp ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tes, the one is for the hardnes, & gro≈ø≈øenes of their ≈øub≈øtance: the other is, for that they be nouri≈øhed by the fattines of the vrine, wherby they ingender gro≈ø≈øe and very √©euell blood. Rha≈øis in the place aboue cited ≈øaith,Rha≈øis. that read flea≈øh without fat, ingendreth dry blood, making but ≈ømall excrementes, and nouri≈øheth more then fat: Fat ingendreth very moi≈øte blood, cau≈øeth mutch ≈øuperfluity, and nouri≈øheth but litle. Flea≈øh interlarded b√©etw√©ene fat and leane, ingendreth temperate blood. The f√©ete augment ≈ølimie iuce. The foremo≈øt part of the rumpe is lighter and hotter, and the hinder-mo≈øt heauier and colder.

div.head: Chap. 18. Of Flea≈øh in Pa≈øties and Pies.
div.p: FLea≈øh, ≈øayth Rha≈øis, which is baked in Pa≈øties and Pies is √©euell,Rha≈øis. and nouri≈øheth litle, but is good for them that haue the ≈øower belchyng. And generally all ≈øortes of Pa≈øties and Pies y√©elde but litle nouri≈øhment in compari≈øon of meates made with brothes. Yet many times they do good to them yt are full of humours, & plea≈øure them that would dry vp, and make their bodies proper. Flea≈øh ro≈øted on the ≈øpit, is gro≈ø≈øe, and nouri≈øheth mutch, if it m√©et with a ≈øtronge and a hot ≈øtomack to dige≈øt it, it bindeth the belly, whiche is manife≈øtly prooued, if a man eate the leane only without fat.

Flea≈øh boyled with Egges and Pepper is hot, and is a good meate for winter, for it ≈øtrengthneth the body, and nouri≈øheth
aboue al other meats, it increa≈øeth al≈øo ≈ø√©ede, and bloud. It maketh a man well coulered, ≈øtrong, and well ≈øet. But in Summer it bringeth loth≈øomne≈ø≈øe, heateth, and br√©edeth the ≈øtone.

div.head: Chap. 19. Of Foules in generall.
div.p: I≈øaac.AL Foules generally, as I≈øaac reporteth, are lighter and finer then the bea≈øts that go on the earth, but they nouri≈øh le≈ø≈øe. And the wilde Foules are better then the tame foules, their flea≈øh is more tender, & ‚Ä¢ a≈øier of dige≈øtion. The cau≈øe wherof is the lightnes and rarenes or their flea≈øh proc√©eding of their often flying, and the drine≈ø≈øe of the ayre. But the tame Foules nouri≈øh more, and make commendable blood, and are more temperate by rea≈øon of the good temperature of their moy≈øture and exerci≈øe. But aboue all foules the≈øe are the fine≈øt the Stare, younge Pertredges, and hou≈øe chickens, and next vnto them the elder Pertredge, the Fea≈øant, the hou≈øe Hen, and the Capon. Chickens are lighter of dige≈øtion then other Foules, and ingender good blood. They comfort the appetite, and vnto all natures and complexions they are mo≈øt agreeable, e≈øpeciall the Cockrel chickens nietheir to fat nor to leane.Auerrois. And Auerrois in the fift of his Collections writeth thus: amonge Foules the Hen is principall in≈øomutch that the broth thereof is good Medicine for tho≈øe that haue the Lepro≈øie, and ≈øome ≈øay, that a Hens Braine augmenteth the ≈øub≈øtance of a mans braine, and ≈øharpneth the wyt.

div.head: Chap. 20. Of the Hen.
div.p:
I≈øaac.THE Hou≈øe Hen, ≈øaith I≈øaac ‚ñ™ is not althing ≈øo moi≈øt as is the Chick, & for that cau≈øe if it be compared to the temp ‚Ä¢
rament of the chickins, it is hard of dige≈øtion, but if it be wel dige≈øted it nouri≈øheth mutch, and ≈øpecially if it b√©e ≈øhewed or boyled in fine broth, by which orderinge it taketh a certaine moi≈øtur of the water, and comforteth the ≈øtomack, and y√©eldeth much nutriment.Rha≈øis. Moreouer, mine aucthour Rha≈øis in the
place often before alleaged, ≈øaith thus: The flea≈øh of ye Stare is fownde by experience to be be≈øt of all other foules, and mo≈øt fit for tho≈øe that meane to liue with a fine, and ≈øubtile diet. Next to this is the flea≈øh of the Quayle, which ingendreth but litle ≈øuperfluitie, and is ≈øuppo≈øed not to be very hot. Then after this cumth the flea≈øh of Chickens, and next of Pertredges which is more gro≈ø≈øe, bindinge the belly, and nouri≈øhinge mutch.

div.head: Chap. 21. Of yong Pigeons.
div.p: YOung Pigeons are very hot, ingendringe inflamed blood, and ≈øoone bringing an ague. And I≈øaac mine auctour ≈øaith,I≈øaac. that yong Pigeons are hot, and full of moi≈øture, wherfore they make gro≈ø≈øe nutriment, a witne≈ø≈øe wherof is their heauines and ‚Ä¢ naptnes to flye, but when they b√©egin to flye they waxe lighter and more acceptable to dige≈øtion, they b√©e m√©ete for flegmatick per≈øons, but naught for the collericke. And al≈øo as the ≈øame writer ≈øaith: Duckes are the woor≈øt of al foules, for their flea≈øh, ≈øaith Rha≈øis, ingendreth mutch ≈øuperfluity, and de≈øtroieth apetite, and is very warme,Rha≈øis‚ñ™ but if nouri≈øheth more then Hennes flea≈øh doth. To conclude, the flea≈øh of all water foules in generall br√©edeth mutch ≈øuperfluitye, and if it haue therwith an √©euell ≈øauour: theÃÑ is it iudged much the woor≈øe.

div.head: Chap. 22. Of partes of foules, as they bee eaten.
div.p:
THe Gi≈øerd of all foules, ≈øaith I≈øaac, I≈øaac. is full of ≈øinewes and hard of dige≈øtion, but b√©eing dige≈øted it make mutch nutriment. But of all Gi≈øardes the Goo≈øes is be≈øt, bicau≈øe of the plentie of moi≈øture in it, and next vnto that is the Hennes or Capons Gi≈øard. Likewi≈øe their Liuers is be≈øt commended, and mo≈øt nouri≈øhing. The Winges of all foules are better then any other part of the body, bicau≈øe of their often moouing and exerci≈øe, for moouing con≈øumeth the ≈øuperfluitye of moi≈øture. The Goo≈øes and Hennes neckes are be≈øt of all other foules neckes, and all partes of carued foules are better
then of the ≈øtoned, which maketh the Capon to b√©e mo≈øt excellent, and to y√©elde be≈øt nutriment, and to ingender perfect blood. The Braines of foules are le≈ø≈øe moi≈øt and ≈ølimy, but drier, then of foure footed bea≈øts, and therfore more to be lyked, chiefly of young Stares, Partredges, Hennes, & Cockes before they crowe, or come to b√©e carued.

div.head: Chap. 23. Of Egges, and their properties.
div.p: I≈øaac.FOra≈ømutch as Egges, ≈øaith I≈øaac, do y√©eld mutch nutriment for that their whole ≈øub≈øtance is conuerted into good iuce, by rea≈øon of the affinity which they haue to mans nature, and ≈øpecially the yolke: therfore in re≈øpecte of their temperament they b√©e mo≈øt like vnto mans body. In this qualitye, ≈øaith Rha≈øis, Rha≈øis. aboue the re≈øt are Hen egges, and Pertredges egges, both which augment ≈ø√©ede in man woonderfullye, and prouoke him to Lechery: next vnto which are Ducke egges, in goodne≈ø≈øe not mutch inferiour, but makinge √©euell iuce. G√©e≈øe egges are loth≈øome, & haue an √©euell ≈ømell. Hen egges, and Pertredge egges are mo≈øt temperate, and conuenient. The yolke being temperate in heat, cau≈øeth good nutriment. The white is cold and ≈ølimy, and hardly concocted. But concerning the yolke,Auerrois. in Cant. Auicen. Auerrois vpon the Canticles of Auicen ≈øheweth, how ≈øome bee of opinion, that it ingendreth as mutch blood in weight, as it ≈øelfe is of. And Rha≈øis ≈øayth, that egges that are ≈øodden or ro≈øted hard, are more hard to dige≈øt, and de≈øcend, ≈ølowlier out of the ≈øtomack. But ≈øoft egges are more quick to de≈øcend, being good for tho≈øe that are troubled with a bloody fluxe, who≈øe ≈øtrength thereby is mutch decaied. As for r√©ere egges which are nether hard nor ≈øoft, are as it were in ye middes betwen both ye other. Moreouer, egges are good again≈øt roughnes in the throat, and by them is ingendred teÃÑ perate blood, and much ≈øtrength. What ≈øhal I ≈øay more? they are as good as flea≈øh, and many times ≈øtand in ≈øteede therof, wherfore tho≈øe per≈øons yt be very fat ought not to v≈øe them.

div.head: Chap. 24. Of Milke.
div.p:
OF Milke al≈øo it is I≈øaacks opinion, that it is very like vnto blood.I≈øaac‚ñ™ For in d√©ed it is none other theÃÑ ye milk ye ≈øecond time
coÃÑcocted in the brea≈øts or vdder, wherof it receiueth whitnes, ta≈øt, and ability. Rha≈øis likewi≈øe ≈øaith,Rha≈øis. that new milk commeth n√©ere to the temperment, although it decline a litle vnto coldnes and moi≈øture, wherby it fatteth and moi≈øtneth the body. It is medicinable vnto tho≈øe that haue the feuer He≈øticae, and the drie cough, and the burning of the vrine. It mini≈øtreth excellent good nouri≈øhment vnto drie bodies, & bringeth them to temperature: it al≈øo increa≈øeth blood, and ≈øeede. But in that it is ≈øoone altered, it is noi≈øome for tho≈øe that b√©e haunted with ≈øharp feuers, or ar troubled with headache by accideÃÑt of ≈øicknes, and to them that are ≈øubiect to the collick, or vnto any other di≈øea≈øe comminge of cold. Cow milke of all bea≈øtes milke is counted the gro≈ø≈øe≈øt, and is good for theÃÑ that woulde fain b√©e fat of body. And A≈ø≈øes milke is the ≈øubtile≈øt of anye bea≈øts milke, & is good for all that are di≈øea≈øed in ye Lungues. Goates milke k√©epeth a mediocrity beetweene both, but Eewe milke cau≈øeth more ≈øuperfluities then any of them all.I≈øaac. I≈øaac writeth of milke in this maÃÑner: Milke of bea≈øts that be ≈øouÃÑd & not ≈øicke, if it be not eaten often, nor mutch, but moderatly: ingendreth coÃÑmendable blood, moi≈øteneth the belly, healpeth the brea≈øt, Lungues, & bladder, e≈øpecially if the watri≈øhnes therof, be ≈øumway corrected: as altred with bread, flouer, oatmeale, rice, or ≈øuch like and then eaten. Rha≈øis writeth, ye Butter milke is good again≈øt ye La≈øke proceding of red choler, and helpeth theÃÑ yt are leane, and haue weak bodies, & the rather, if there be a piece of hot iron or ≈øt√©ele often queÃÑched in it‚ñ™ whey extingui≈øheth red choler, it cureth ye ≈øcab, whelks, bli≈øters, the yelow iaundice, & healpeth theÃÑ yt are hurt wt drinking ≈øtrong wines. He ≈øaith al≈øo that Butter being raw, a≈øwageth the ≈øharpnes of the throat, helpeth the Letters and ringworms, taketh away the rednes of the face, and cleereth the ≈økinne, maketh whole pimpels and quiddles yt are ≈øharp & dry being therwith annointed, but it breedeth loth≈øomnes, & a≈øcendeth vp to the mouth of the ≈øtomack. SeddeÃÑ butter weakneth ye ≈øtomack, ≈øoftneth hard impo≈øtumacions, laid vnto them plai≈øter wi≈øe: it re≈øi≈øteth ye mo≈øt venemous bityng of Vipers. Who≈øo
v≈øeth to f√©ede mutch on butter ≈øhall continually be troubled with di≈øea≈øes cumming of fleame. It nouri≈øheth mo≈øt of any vnctuous thing, an ‚Ä¢ is of great facultie.

div.head: Chap. 25. Of Chee≈øe.
div.p: LYkewi≈øe hee ≈øayth that gr√©ene Chee≈øe is colde and gro≈ø≈øe, and thought vnm√©ete for colde natures. But ould Ch√©e≈øe is e≈øteemed of, according to the age. Tange Ch√©e≈øe which ta≈øteth ≈øharp of ye rennet is hot, burning, br√©edeth thir≈øt, and nouri≈øheth √©euel. But if a man eate a litle therof after meat: it ≈øtrengthneth the mouth of the ≈øtomack, al≈øo it taketh away ≈øatietie, and lothinge of the meat, which chaunceth many times in the mouth of the ≈øtomack after ≈øw√©ete meates, but it mu≈øt b√©e neyther to newe Ch√©e≈øe nor to olde. Moreouer I≈øaac ≈øaith,I≈øaac. that all Ch√©e≈øe in generall is naught, noi≈øum to the ≈øtomak, and hard of dige≈øtion, ≈øo that they which commonly eate it fall into the collick, and are greued with the ≈øtone in the kidneis. Howbeit the better the Ch√©e≈øe is, the le≈ø≈øe harme it doeth.

div.head: Chap. 26. Of Fi≈øshes
div.p:
I≈øaac.THe temperament of Fish generally, as ≈øaieth I≈øaac, is cold and moi≈øt, ingendring fleame, mo≈øt agr√©eable vnto hot and drie complexions in Summer time, and in hot regions. And vnconuenient vnto colde & drie complexions, in winter time, and in colde Regions. Al Fi≈øhe is either of the Sea, or of the fre≈øh water. Tho≈øe that are of the Sea remaininge in the d√©epe not neere the ≈øhoare in grauely and ≈øandy places, are mo≈øt ≈øubtile and commendable and ea≈øier of dige≈øtion then the other ≈øea fi≈øhe and ingender better bloud, but they di≈øcend ≈ølowly out of the ≈øtomack and intrailes for lack of moi≈øt ≈ølimines. Fre≈øh water fi≈øh are vniuer≈øally more gro≈ø≈øe and ≈ølimie, & ≈ølow of dige≈øtion, but they voide out of the ≈øtomack with more facilitie then the ≈øeafi≈øh, and nouri≈øh more. The be≈øt of the≈øe are they which remaine in dowfalles and ≈øwift running ≈øtreames, who≈øe bottome is grauelly or ≈øandie,
and far of from the filthines of any towne or citie. Pond Fi≈øh is of all other the wor≈øt, of √©euell ≈øauour and hard of dige≈øtion, e≈øpecially if they be far from the ≈øea or any running ≈øtreame. Rha≈øis, Rha≈øis (mine aucthour (≈øaith: all Fi≈øhes are hard of concoction, and tary longe in the ≈øtomacke, and make a man thir≈øtie. The bloud which younge Fi≈øh ingendreth is flegmaticke, br√©edyng vicious ≈ølimine≈ø≈øe in the body, wherof ≈øpryng ≈øundrie di≈øea≈øes. Wherefore wee ought to choo≈øe ≈øutch fi≈øh who≈øe ≈øub≈øtance is not clammy, nor very gro≈ø≈øe, nor haue any √©euel ≈ømel, nor wil quickly putrifie, nor that abide in pondes, Lakes and M√©eres, that yeeld foorth a ≈øtinkyng ≈øauour. For they that are conuer≈øant in filthy places are not fit to bee eaten, neither ≈øutch as liue in waters aboundyng with vnhol≈øome weedes wheron the Fi≈øh do feede, for they bee made therby vnapt to bee eaten. Saltfi≈øh ought not in any ≈øort be ≈øet on the boorde, nor to bee fead on, vnle≈ø≈øe it were when a man for medicine ≈øake would cau≈øe him≈øelf to vomit. But if any bee de≈øirous to eate therof, let him eate but a ≈ømal quantitie, dre≈ø≈øed with ≈øome ≈ølippery or vnctuous thinge, whiche may loth the ≈øtomack. The Crafish of the riuer is very good for weake per≈øons, as ≈øaieth Auicen, Auicen. theyr flea≈øh is good for them that haue a con≈øumption, ≈øo is their broathe, and A≈ø≈øes Milke. And ≈øome ≈øay, that they will breake great impo≈øtumarions if they bee layde therto.

div.head: Chap. 27. Of Pul≈øe.
div.p:
COn≈øequently wee mu≈øt intreate of Pul≈øe, I≈øaac. in all ≈øortes and kindes, and fir≈øt of Rice, of which I≈øaac in the fir≈øt booke of the woorke b√©efore alleaged, ≈øayeth thus: Rice is drie in the fourth degree and hot in the fir≈øt, whiche beyng ≈øodden with water is good again≈øt the Collick that holdeth but one day. But being ≈øodden with Almond milke it l√©e≈øeth the binding facultie, and nouri≈øheth well, and ingendreth good blood, and augmenteth ≈ø√©ede. And if with the Rice or with the broth of it you wa≈øh freckles, it taketh them away, and clen≈øeth the ≈økin. Auicen writeth, that the hu≈øke of Rice is thought to bee
poi≈øon, for if it b√©e geuen in drinke to any man, immediatlye h√©e f√©eleth paine in his mouth, and his tongue wilb√©e bli≈øtred.

I≈øaac. Beanes, after I≈øaac, that bee gr√©ene: are cold and moi≈øt in the third degree, and nouri≈øh but litle, they ingender gro≈ø≈øe and rawe humours, and br√©ede winde in ye vppermo≈øt part of the belly. Dry beanes are colde and dry in the fir≈øt degr√©e, ingendring thick windes in the vppermo≈øt part of the belly, from whence there ari≈øe hurtfull fumes into the brain. They cau≈øe ≈øundrye gro≈ø≈øe and corrupt dreames, and are hard of concoction. The great white beane not b√©eing old, is the be≈øt, and if it b√©e ≈øodden in water there is mutch of the windines taken away therby, and of the gro≈ø≈øenes likewi≈øe, ≈øpecially if the fir≈øt water be throwne away, ‚Ä¢ nd they be boyled again in another. B√©eing ≈øodden with Mintes, Organ, Cumin, and ≈øutch like, and ≈øo eaten, theyr windines is mutch amended. Who≈øo is de≈øierous to clen≈øe the ≈økin of his body: let him v≈øe to wa≈øh him≈øelf with the meale of Beanes, and he ≈øhall haue his will.Rha≈øis. Rha≈øis, ≈øayth, that gr√©ene beanes ingender gro≈ø≈øe and raw humours, augmentyng fleame in the ≈øtomacke and intrayles, whiche breedeth mutch windine≈ø≈øe. Lentles al≈øo ≈øayth hee are colde and drie, ingendring melancholick bloud, and dryinge the body, they darken the eye≈øight, and nouri≈øh Melancholicke di≈øea≈øes, if a man v≈øe them mutch. I≈øaac ≈øaith, they fill the Brayn with gro≈ø≈øe fumes and Melancholie ≈ømokes, cau≈øing payn, and fearful dreames. I≈øaac deuideth Chitch Pea≈øen into white,I≈øaac. and blacke. The white is hot in the fir≈øt degr√©e, and moy≈øt in the middle of the ≈øame, hard of coÃÑcoction, ingendryng wynde and fumo≈øitie in ≈øutch quantitie: that it puffeth vp the flea≈øh, and driueth the ≈økin abroad, ≈øo that they which v≈øe it haue a fayre white ≈økin, for when the ≈økinne is borne vp and ≈øtretched abroad: it ≈øheweth white, and cl√©ere. The blacke Chitch is hotter then the white, but not ≈øo moy≈øt and is good agayn≈øt oppilation of the Liuer, if it bee boyled with Smaledge and Radi≈øh, and the iuce therof drunken, it al≈øo increa≈øeth Milke,Arnold. and ≈øeede, and prouoketh Vryne. Pea≈øon, according to the famous Arnoldus de villa noua, in his
gouernment of health: are of this nature: if they or Chitche ‚Ä¢ b√©e laide a ≈øt√©epe all night in fre≈øh water, and bee boyled next day in the ≈øame, a two or three wallops, and then b√©e ≈øtrayned and kept, and when y√©e goo to meat there be put vnto the liquor a litle white wine, and a ≈ømall quantity of Spikenard in pouder, and ≈øaffron, and a litle ≈øalt Indie, and then once boyled togither one wallop, and mini≈øtred at the beginning of the meale to b√©e drunken or eaten, crummed like potage. It clen≈øeth the ≈ømall veines, and the pa≈ø≈øedge of the vryne, e≈øpecially if the Pea≈øen and Chitches be layd in ≈øoke, and boiled with Per≈øley in the ≈øame water. The vn≈økilfull ≈øort ≈øay that they ≈øhould bee layd a ≈øoke in Lie, but that ≈øoking taketh away all the openyng facultie, and the fine≈øt part of the ≈øub≈øtance of them.

div.head: Chap. 28. Of Pothearbes.
div.p:
NOw let vs ≈øay ≈øumwhat of Pothearbes accordinge as order and doctrine requireth, and fir≈øt of Garlike, whiche, as ≈øaith Rha≈øis, is hot and drie, and taketh awaye thir≈øtines,Rha≈øis. and increa≈øeth flea≈øhly lu≈øt, breaketh winde, and heateth the body. In hot regions, hot times, and vnto hot complexions it doth harme, and Galen calleth it the hu≈øbandmens triacle.Galen. Beanes or Lentles ≈øod & eaten take away the ≈øtinking ≈ømell of it, and ≈øo doth Rue b√©eing chawed, and a litle therof eaten downe. So lkewi≈øe doth Setwall, or Mintes of the garden or wilde, if it be broken betw√©ene the teeth, and after it a litle quantity of vinegre bee receiued. To the ≈øame purpo≈øe ≈øerueth the roote of Beetes, ≈øaith Plinie, beeing ro≈øted, and eaten after it. Sorrell in Rha≈øis iudgment is cold and dry,plinie. it bindeth the belly, and ≈øharpneth the ≈øtomack,Rha≈øes. extingui≈øhing red choler, and thir≈øt. Auicen ≈øaith, that it taketh away toothach if they be wa≈øhed with the iuce therof. Dill, according to I≈øaac in the ≈øecond booke is hot and dry, and being drunken in wine:Auicen‚ñ™ re≈øolueth windines, puffines, and ≈øwelling in the ≈øtomack,I≈øaac. and belly. The branches therof boiled in Oile, di≈ø≈øolue ≈øwellings beeinge outward anoynted, a≈øwage payne, and bring ≈øleepe.
The ≈ø√©ede drunken prouoketh vrine, increa≈øeth milke, clen≈øeth the ≈øtomack from putrified humours, it healpeth the hicket proc√©eding of the long abiding of meat in the ≈øtomack, and the often eating therof weakneth the eie ≈øight.

I≈øaac.Garden Smalledge by the aucthoritie of I≈øaac, being eaten openeth oppilations, prouoketh vrine, bindeth the bellie, is √©euell for the falling ≈øicknes, and hurteth w√©emen with child: and ≈øutch as are wt childe & frequent the eating of it, it ingendreth in the childes body biles, and rotten impo≈øtumacions. Neither may we commeÃÑd ye v≈øe of Smalledge, for it draweth humours togither from all partes of the body vnto the ≈øtomack, wherof in≈øueth vomiting. The ≈ø√©ede prouoketh vrine aboue the branches,Rha≈øis. and as ≈øaith Rha≈øis, Smalledge openeth oppilacions and puffeth vp there withall, it mooueth to venery, and taketh away ye eeuel ≈øauour of the mouth. Arredge al≈øo, ≈øayth hee, is colde and moi≈øt, loo≈øing the belly, nouri≈øhinge well, and is good for them that haue an hot liuer.

Plinie. Plinie in his ≈øecond booke writeth, that it ingendreth ≈øundry ≈øickne≈ø≈øes,Lib. 2. and therfore the liquor wherein it is boyled, ought many times to bee chaunged, or els it ingendreth pu≈ø≈øhes, and foule ≈øpots in the ≈økin. Per≈ønep, as ≈øaith Rha≈øis, is hot and windy, ≈ølowly dige≈øted, it maketh the ≈ø√©ede of man hot, and expelleth vrine, and farther ≈øaieth I≈øaac, it helpeth fle≈øhly lu≈øt, prouoketh the termes, and ingendreth di≈øcoÃÑmendable bloud.

Plinie.After Plinie in the ≈øecond booke, Beetes are of two ≈øortes, white,Lib. 2. & red. The roote of the red ≈øod in water killeth the itch, the iuce appea≈øeth the auncient paine in the head, & the da≈øeling, and the ≈øinging in the eares, it driueth foorth vrine, it appea≈øeth the toothach, it prouoketh to venerie, and is good again≈øt poi≈øon.Con≈øtantinus. Borage, as ≈øaith Con≈øtantinus, is hot & moi≈øt in y‚Ä¢ fir≈øt degr√©e, it purgeth red choler, it helpeth yt hart burning, and being ≈øt√©epedin wine and drunken: it maketh them mery that are ≈øad by rea≈øon of Melancholie, and the hea rbe it ≈øelfe eaten raw, as ≈øome ≈øay, ingendreth good bloud.

Colewortes, according vnto Rha≈øis opinion, br√©edeth black choler,Rha≈øis. troubleth the ≈øleepe with √©euell dreames, but it lenifieth
the throate and brea≈øt, it maketh the belly ≈øoluble, and taketh away drunkennes. I≈øaac writeth of Colewortes, I≈øaac. that the iuce therof drunken loo≈øeth the bellie, but eaten without broath they doo bind, and therfore to amend their faute, the fir≈øt iuce wherein they were ≈øodden mu≈øt be ca≈øt away, & theÃÑ they mu≈øt be ≈øodden with good fat meate. Onions ≈øea≈øoned with oyle, do neither heaten nor coole, nor prouoke thir≈øt, but make an Appetite. And Dio≈øcorides ≈øaith,Dio≈øcorides. that if the iuce of them be receiued in at the no≈øe: it purgeth the head very wel, and ≈øtamped with Vineger taketh away ≈øpottes, prouoketh ≈øl√©epe, and ≈øoftneth the bellie.

The Gourd after Auicen, is good for the cholerick per≈øons,Auicen. and hurtfull to the melancholick and fleagmatick, and Dio≈øcorides writeth, that the iuce therof holden in the mouth a≈øwageth the toothach.Rha≈øis. Cummin according to Rha≈øis is hot and drie, becau≈øe it healpeth dige≈øtion, and breaketh wynde, & Dio≈øcorides reporteth, that being mingled with Vineger, it ≈øtayeth the termes, and being drunken or annointed ≈øtoppeth the bl√©eding at the no≈øe, and maketh pale and low coulered. The ≈ø√©ede drunken with water, doth effectually cure wringings, gripings, and windines in the guttes, and I≈øaac ≈øaith,I≈øaac. if it be mingled with windy meates, it rectifieth them, and killeth wormes being drunken. Fenell ≈øeede al≈øo ≈øaieth hee, increa≈øeth milke, it di≈øchargeth the ≈øtoppinges of the Liuer, and bladder, & expelleth the ≈øtone of the Kidneis, and is good again≈øt long agues, and ≈øaith Dio≈øcorides, Dio≈øco. being mingled with eie confections: it taketh away ye mi≈øtines froÃÑ them. Hy≈ø≈øop, after Rha≈øis, is hot, being eaten helpeth the eie ≈øight of weaknes, it remedieth ye wh√©ezing in the Lungues, it driueth foorth woormes and cau≈øeth abortion, and healpeth to di≈øge≈øt our meate. Garden Lettice, as ≈øaith I≈øaac, I≈øaac. is the be≈øt of all other Hearbs to ingender good bloud, and being vnwa≈øhed it is the better, and is ≈øoone concocted. It prouoketh vrine, it quencheth red choller in yt ≈øtomack, it cooleth the boyling of the bloud, it bringeth ≈øl√©epe, and increa≈øeth bloud, and ≈øeede. Mintes al≈øo, ≈øaith h√©e, is hot and drie in the ≈øecond degree, comforteth
the ≈øtomack, & prouoketh appetite. It clen≈øeth away al loth≈øoÃÑ nes of meate from ye ≈øtomack, proc√©eding of corrupt humors, al≈øo it clen≈øeth the roughnes of ye tongue being rubbed therwith. If it be ≈øodden in vinegre, and wt the liquor the chawes be wa≈øhed: it clen≈øeth the rottennes of the gummes, but they mu≈øt afterward be rubbed wt pouder of dried Mints. Cre≈ø≈øes as Rha≈øis ≈øaieth: are hot, and therefore heate the Liuer and ≈øtomack,Rha≈øis. they al≈øo molifie the bellie, and driue woormes out of the Maw, they prouoke de≈øier of w√©emens company, clen≈øe the Lunges, and take away the wh√©e≈øing, help ≈øtopping of the Milt, and procure abortion. Poppie, as I≈øaac deuideth it, is white, and black. The black is yt wherof they make Opium, the white is more commendable, & nouri≈øhing, of which Dio≈øcorides writeth thus: They that are wont to eate Poppie, it br√©edeth in them mutch ≈øl√©epe,Dio≈øc. and forgetfulne≈ø≈øe. Rha≈øis ≈øaith that the ≈ø√©ede of white Poppie is colde, good for the throate and brea≈øte, and maketh one ≈øl√©epe. Per≈øley al≈øo, ≈øaieth I≈øaac, is hot and drie in the end of the third degr√©e, it prouoketh vrine and W√©emens termes, re≈øoluing windines, and increa≈øing ≈øeede,Serapiour and, as Serapion ≈øaith, Per≈øley layd pla≈øterwi≈øe vppon wheles, ≈øcabbes, and morfew: cl√©ereth the ≈økin wonderfully, a≈øwageth the paine of the kidneis & bladder, rarefieth y‚Ä¢ pa≈ø≈øedges of yt body in opening the pores, prouoketh vrine & ≈øweat, clen≈øeth the Liuer, and re≈øolueth the windie collick. I eekes, as te≈øtifieth Rha≈øis, ar hot & dry although they prouoke appitite, yet make they the head to ake, and ingender √©euyll dreames,Rha≈øis. and are hurtful for them yt are commonly troubled with the continuall headach, and tho≈øe that are ≈øoone offended with heat. I≈øaac therfore giueth coun≈øell that it were good immediatly vpon them to eate Lettice, Pur≈ølain, or Endiue, that by the colones of one the heate of the other may b√©e delayed.I≈øaac. B√©eing eaten raw: they clen≈øe the pipes of the Lunges from gro≈ø≈øe humours, they open yt oppilacions of the liuer, & ≈øtop the ≈øalt rewme. Pur≈ølaine, according to Rha≈øis, by quenching thir≈øt and inwarde burninge, bindeth the bellie, and taketh away the chilne≈ø≈øe of the t√©eth, & bindeth the la≈øke, proc√©eding of red choler, and it dimini≈øheth natural ≈øede. If wartes
be rubbed therwith, ≈øaith Auicen, Auicen. they will come away by the rootes. Radish, as Rha≈øis writeth, is hot and drie,Rha≈øis. tareing long in the ≈øtomack, it maketh the iuce ≈øubtile, and lifteth it vp vnto the mouth of the ≈øtomack, and ≈øo prouoketh vomit. The leaues dige≈øt our meate, and prouoke appetite in vs, being receiued but in ≈ømall quantitie. And I≈øaac ≈øaieth, that if they be eaten after meate they breake winde, and by rea≈øon of their heauynes they make the meate to go downe. And Dio≈øcorides addeth, that the roote being eaten with ≈øalt:Dio≈øco. increa≈øeth milke, prouoketh vrine and the Flowers, & with a litle grated Ginger put into an hollowe tooth, a≈øwageth the toothach pre≈øently. The Rape, after ye iudgment of I≈øaac is hot in ye ≈øecond degr√©e, and moi≈øt in ye fir≈øt. It nouri≈øheth more theÃÑ al other hearbs, yet is it hard of dige≈øtion, it maketh ≈øoft and foggie fle≈øh, it ≈øtirreth vnto company of w√©emen, & increa≈øeth ≈ø√©ede. Plinie in ye ≈øecond booke writeth yt ye Rape being ≈øodden,Plinie. driueth cold out of ye f√©ete. And ye coÃÑmentarie writer Auorrois, in ye fift of his colections ≈øaith, yt the Rape hath a marueilous force to cl√©ere y‚Ä¢ eie ≈øight. Rue, as ye learned I≈øaac reporteth, is good for concoction, bicau≈øe it hath ye faculty to expell gro≈ø≈øe & claÃÑmie humors, it breketh windines, & moi≈øtneth ye belly. And Auicen ≈øaith, yt it taketh away ye loth≈øome ≈øauour of Garlick, L√©ekes, & Onions, ≈øharpnethe the ≈øight, and taketh away the de≈øier to weemen. Sage, after Dio≈øc. prouoketh ye termes, & procureth abortion. The broth wherin the twigs and leaues are boiled repres the thoughts of lu≈øt, and motion to venery. The iuce of ye leaues maketh heire black. Macer ≈øaith thus of Sage: Macer. If it be laid vpon the bite: It heales the poy≈øoned rankling quite. Spinage and Succorie are temperate, agreeable to the throate, Lunges, & ≈øtomack, the lenifie ye belly, & make very good nutriment. Tode≈øtooles, according to ye doctrine of Rha≈øis, are cold & gro≈ø≈øe, & ingender raw fleame. Tho≈øe of theÃÑ which be red are naught, for if they be eaten they ingender the collick, and at no time they mu≈øt be eaten without warme ≈øauces. Mu≈ø
‚Ä¢ hroms are farre wor≈øe then Tode≈øtooles whereof ≈øome be ≈øtark poy≈øon, and will choke a man, & kill him pre≈øently. But the be≈øt of them ingender fleame. I≈øaac ≈øaith thus of them:I≈øaac. by the≈øe tokens you ≈øhall knowe them that will kill men.
They be ≈øoft, ≈ølimy, and gro≈ø≈øe, and beinge ≈ølit in the middle and let to lye ≈øo all a night: the next morninge you ≈øhall finde them rotten.

div.head: Chap. 29. Of Frutes.
div.p: THus by experience the noble Galen writeth of Frutes, my father,Galen. ≈øaith hee, had his health all his life time bicau≈øe h√©e eate no frutes. And wheÃÑ he was dead I began to eate frutes, and by meanes therof I fell into ≈øundry, and long continuing di≈øea≈øes. And after that I ab≈øtained from rathe frutes, I had neuer any ≈øicknes ≈øauing an ague which helde m√©e one day. Then ≈øhewed I the ≈øame vnto my friendes, and they that beleeued m√©e ab≈øtained from rathe frutes, and in al their life time were neuer ≈øicke. This mutch of frutes in generall.

Figges, according to Rha≈øis, clen≈øe the kidneis froÃÑ grauell, b√©eing gr√©ene they br√©ed winde in the belly, and they loo≈øe the ≈øame, and make indifferent good iuce. If they b√©e drye, they nouri≈øh mutch, and do heaten, the often v≈øe whereof ingendreth the itch, and ly≈øe, and loo≈øe the belly b√©einge eaten b√©efore meate.I≈øaac. Of whom moreouer, myne aucthour I≈øaac ≈øayth, in his ≈øecond booke, that if they m√©et with a ≈øtomacke well clen≈øed from humours, they are then good of dige≈øtion, they ingender good blood, clen≈øe the ≈øtomack, lungues, kidneis, and bladder if they be eaten fa≈øting. Dates, ≈øaith h√©e, are hot and make gro≈ø≈øe nutriment, and if they be eaten oftentimes they ingender gro≈ø≈øe blood in the inner partes, they corrupt the teeth, and make ≈øteame and blood to abound. And in the ≈øecoÃÑd booke I≈øaac ≈øaith, that Dates being hot and dry in the ≈øecond degree, are better of digi≈øtion then Figs, & more prouoking vrine. But who≈øo accu≈øtometh him≈øelf vnto them: ≈øhall feele an hard ≈øwelling in his Liuer, & Spleene. Rai≈øens, as witne≈ø≈øeth Rha≈øis, Rha≈øis. whiche are very ≈øweete, are hot, but not ≈øo hot as Dates, neither ≈øo ≈øtopping as they are, they be windy and hurt mutch, they franke vp the body ≈øuddeinly, they al≈øo increa≈øe motion vnto venery, and woorke to the erection of the yeard. Tho≈øe which haue the thinne≈øt ≈økin, do ≈øoone≈øt de≈øcend, and br√©ede le≈ø≈øe windines, and the contrary do contrariwi≈øe.
Tho≈øe that are ≈øower do not heaten, but b√©eing wa≈øhed in cold water, and eaten before meate, do as it were extingui≈øh heat. Sower grapes are colde, they binde the belly, and they repre≈ø≈øe blood and red choler.
Rai≈øens are temperate in heat, which cau≈øing good nutryment, do br√©ed no oppilacion as Dates do, although they nouri≈øhe ≈øtronger and in greater quantity.

Pomegranates whiche are ≈øw√©ete, according to Rha≈øis, Rha≈øis‚ñ™ doo not coole, but puffe vp, and cau≈øe thir≈øtine≈ø≈øe, but they lenifie the throat. The ≈øower ones make the brea≈øt and throat rough, al≈øo they puffe vp the ≈øtomacke and Liuer, but alwayes they moderate the heat of blood and red choler,I≈øaac. they quench Feuers, and repre≈ø≈øe vomites. And I≈øaac ≈øaith, that Pomegranates are fitter for medicine then for meat, for they y√©elde but ≈ømal nouri≈øhment, but it is good. It is the property of tart Pomegranates to extingui≈øh the rage of humours, and to comforte the ≈øtomacke.Rha≈øis The iuce dropped into their eies that haue the yelow Jandies taketh away the yellow couler.

Quinces ≈øaith Rha≈øis, b√©e they ≈øw√©et or ≈øower, they ≈øtrenghthen the ≈øtomack, but principally the ≈øower, they prouoke al≈øo a good appetite, and binde the bellye. B√©einge eaten after meate, they make the ordure to di≈øcende quickely, and expell it out of the belly. And b√©einge eaten before meate they woorke the contrary effect. The ≈øower ones are ≈øtronge≈øt in bindinge the belly.

Peares after Galen b√©eyng eaten b√©efore meate, do bynde,Galen. but after meate they loo≈øe the belly. Peares that are very ≈øw√©et do not puffe vp, but they all binde the belly, vnle≈ø≈øe they bee eaten after meat. For b√©eing eaten after meat they driue the ordure foorth, and then they ≈øtrengthen the ≈øtomacke.

I≈øaac al≈øo ≈øaith, ye ≈øweet Peares are temperate, and if they bee boyled with Mu≈ø≈øhroms they take away all theyr clen≈øinge, e≈øpecially if they be wilde Peares, by rea≈øon of theyr tartnes. Appels, after the iudgement of I≈øaac: I≈øaac. are colde,
and bicau≈øe of their ≈øowerne≈ø≈øe do binde the more. And although they agr√©e well with the mouth of the ≈øtomacke: yet they fill it full of ≈ølimy humoures. Auicen ≈øaith that Apples do comfort, e≈øpecially tho≈øe that ≈ømell ≈øweete. Baked in a Pie they help the appetite, but the dayly eating of them cau≈øeth ouermutch heating of the ≈øinewes.

Peaches, accordynge to Auicen, if they b√©e ripe: are good for the ≈øtomacke, cau≈øinge good concoction vnto meate, but they may not bee eaten after other meate, for they corrupte it, but rather b√©efore meate. If the Appels bee drye they b√©e harde of dige≈øtion, and although they nouri≈øh mutch yet are they not good.I≈øaac. And I≈øaac ≈øaieth, that the greater Peaches, if they bee ripe they loo≈øe the belly, but otherwi≈øe they binde it. The le≈ø≈øe whiche are called in Latin Praecocia, and in Engli≈øh (as I thinke) Africoes, are hol≈øome for the ≈øtomacke, and take away loth≈øomne≈ø≈øe. Medlers, ≈øaith h√©e are cold and dry in the fir≈øt degr√©e, they comforte the ≈øtomacke, and take away the fluxe of choler, and repre≈ø≈øe vomitinge, they prouoke vrine, and beeinge taken beefore meate they comfort the ≈øtomack the more, and hurt not the ≈øinewne≈ø≈øe therof.Dio≈øc. And Dio≈øcorides writeth, that ≈øome ≈øaye they helpe mutch the toothach if they b√©e eaten while the teeth ake.

The Pome Citron, after the opinion of Auicen, beeing pared and the rine eaten or chawed:Auicen. maketh the mouth ≈ømell plea≈øantly. The ≈øower iuce beeinge anointed killeth ringewormes, the decoction drunken maketh a good couler, and fatteth the body. Mulberies which are ripe and ≈øw√©ete, as ≈øaith I≈øaac, loo≈øe the b ‚Ä¢ lly, are ≈øoone ca≈øt forth out of the ≈øtomack, and prouoke vrine. Being eaten fa≈øtinge out of coulde water, they are very cooling, they quench thir≈øt, and vnnaturall heat. Plummes, likewi≈øe, ≈øaith h√©e, are of two ≈øortes. Some white, which are harde of dige≈øtion, and noi≈øome to the ≈øtomake. The blacke of the gardein, b√©einge ripe, moi≈øten the ≈øtomacke, and make ≈øoft the bellye, and pourge red choler. But if they be eaten ouermutch: they hurt the
≈øtomacke, but they do le≈ø≈øe hurt eaten before meat.

Cheries al≈øo, as the ≈øame aucthour writeth, are ≈øoone conuerted, they engender gro≈ø≈øe fleam and ≈ølimy with in the hollownes of the Liuer and Splene. And therfore ingender longe agues, and are very √©euell euery way. The be≈øt time to eate them is b√©efore meat, for when they be eaten vpon a ful ≈øtomacke, they flit aboue, and turne to putrifaction.

Almondes, accordinge to Rha≈øis, are temperate in heate,Rha≈øis which although they make the throat ≈ømooth, yet are they heauy in the ≈øtomack, and tary long there, they open oppylacions, and a≈øwage the burning of the vrine, and b√©eing eaten with ≈øugar: augment ≈øeede of generacion.

The bitter Almondes, according to I≈øaacks iudgment,I≈øaac. are hot and dry in the end of the ≈øecond degr√©e, they clen≈øe, ≈øcoure, and comfort, they mooue vrine, and di≈ø≈øolue gro≈ø≈øe and clammye humours, by meanes wherof they clen≈øe the brea≈øt and Lungues from fleagmatick humours, and relea≈øe the oppilacions of the Liuer and Splene.

Nuts likewi≈øe, ≈øaieth the ≈øame aucthour, in a cholericke per≈øon, and one that hath a hot ≈øtomacke: are ≈øoone turned into cholerick vapours a≈øcending into the head, cau≈øinge the payne and giddine≈ø≈øe thereof. But if a man would correcte them and make them good, h√©e mu≈øt crack them, and blanche them, and lay them a ≈øtiepe a whole night in water, that they may get ≈øome moy≈øture.

Dio≈øcorides ≈øayeth, that two Nuttes, and two dry Figges,Dio≈øco. and twentie leaues of Rue, or Hearbe Grace, and one grayne of Salt pounded together, and beyng eaten fa≈øtyng: keepeth a man from infection of Poy≈øon, or Pe≈øtilence.

The Fildbeards, after Rha≈øis, Rha≈øes. are not ≈øo hotte as the other Nuttes are, but are heauier, and are good agayn≈øt the ≈øtynging of Scorpions. And Serapion ≈øaieth of them, that if Fildbeards b√©e roa≈øted with a litle Pepper and eaten, they ripen the Catarre or Rewme.

Chea≈øtnuts, as Con≈øtantinus writeth, are wyndie,Serapion. they mooue to the acte of the flea≈øh, they y√©eld mutch nutriment, they are
hard of dige≈øtion, and therfore accordin ‚Ä¢ vnto the coun≈øell of I≈øaac, I≈øaac. they mu≈øt bee ro≈øted, that their √©euell facultye may b√©e therby amended, and their ≈øub≈øtance rarified. Then do they a≈øwage the drine≈ø≈øe of the brea≈øt and all the body, and moderate the difficulty of makinge water. The Acorne al≈øo according to the ≈øame auctour, b√©einge di≈øobedient vnto dige≈øtion, bindeth the belly, but prouoketh vrine, and they do nouri≈øh. Beaten into pouder, and the pouder laide vpon the Vuula: drieth vp the rotten humours that v≈øe to haunte and hurt the ≈øame.

div.head: Cap. 30. Of Spices.
div.p: Rha≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . PEpper, by the aucthority of Rha≈øis, helpeth to concoct ye meat well, and di≈ø≈øolueth windines, and beeing very hot: heateth the ≈øtomack and liuer, and hurteth hot bodies e≈øpecially in Summer. Ginger al≈øo, according to the ≈øame Aucthour is hot and moi≈øt, and in helping concoction is profitable for tho≈øe who≈øe ≈øtomacks and Liuers are colde. It amendeth the dimne≈ø≈øe of ≈øight ri≈øing of moi≈øture,Auicen. and as Auicen writeth, it augmenteth the memory, and clen≈øeth the moi≈øture, of the head, and throat.

Con≈øtan. Zeadoarie, according to the ≈øame Auicen, is a triacle or pre≈øeruatiue again≈øt all poi≈øons, and as ≈øaith Con≈øtantinus, if con≈øumeth the ≈øwelling by winde, and comforteth the ≈øtomack: it prouoketh ye appetite, taketh away yt ≈øtinking of the mouth through eating garlik,Macro. and according to Macrobius, a≈øwageth the heat of the wine which wee haue drunken. Galingale likewi≈øe,Auic. as writeth Auicen, is hot and drye, it re≈øolueth windines, maketh the mouth ≈øauour well, helpeth the ≈øtomacke, concocteth the meate, augmenteth defier to weemen, and cureth the paine of the kidneis. Cloues al≈øo, ≈øaith h√©e, are hot and dry in the their degree, they make the body ≈ømell well, they ≈øharpen the ≈øight, they comfort the ≈øtomacke and Liuer. Cinamom, Rha≈øis. after‚ñ™ the opinion of Rha≈øis: is hot and dry, which in ≈øtrengthning mutch helpeth the ≈øtomacke, & liuer, it cau≈øeth good concoction,I≈øaac. and expelleth windines. Al≈øo, ≈øaith I≈øaac,
it openeth oppilacions, and prouoketh the termes. Saffron likewi≈øe, ≈øaith h√©e, beeing hot and dry in the fir≈øt degr√©e:I≈øaac. comforteth the ≈øtomack, openeth the ≈øtopping of the Liuer, helpeth them that are ≈øhortwinded, and comforteth the weake partes. And Rha≈øis thus ≈øpeaketh of Saffron in his Alman≈øor. Alman≈øor. A certen woman, ≈øaith hee, was very long in labour of childe bed, and could not bee deliuered. And I gaue vnto her one dramme of Saffron, and immediatly ≈øh√©e was deliuered, and this haue I tried often. And b√©eing drunken in wine, it is of ≈øingular force to make one merie.Plini. Plinie in his ≈øeconde booke ≈øaith: who≈øo drinketh Saffron fir≈øte,Lib. 2. ≈øhall not feele any ≈øurfet: and a crowne made therof and put vpon the head, relea≈øeth drunkenne≈ø≈øe. Carawaies, Con≈øtantinus. according vnto Con≈øtantine is hot and dry in the third degr√©e, it di≈ø≈øolueth winde, it ≈øtrengthneth the ≈øtomack, it killeth woormes, it helpeth concoction, and prouoketh vrine.

div.head: Chap. 31. Of Certen Sauces.
div.p:
MU≈øtard is hot and dry in the middes of the fourth degr√©e, it drieth vp the moi≈øture of the head and ≈øtomack.Auicen. And Auicen writeth, ≈øome ≈øay (quod hee) that if one that is fa≈øtinge drinke it, it maketh a good vnder≈øtanding, and it clen≈øeth the humours of the head. And Plinie ≈øaith in the ≈øecond booke,Plinie. that mu≈øterd≈øeede prepared with vineger, driueth forth grauell. Salt, ≈øaith Rha≈øis, is hot and dry, it taketh loth≈øomnes from meates, and maketh the ta≈øt ≈øharpe, and it prouoketh the appetite. But who≈øo eateth ≈øalt in any great quantity, it cau≈øeth mutch adu≈øtion in the blood: it weakneth the eie ≈øight, it dimini≈øheth naturall ≈øeede, and ingendreth the itche. Venigre, according to the ≈øame aucthour, is colde and drye, making a man leane, & weakning the powers, it dimini≈øheth the ≈ø√©ede, it ≈øtrengthneth Melancholye, and weakneth red choler and blood, and maketh the meat ≈øubtile and fine wherwith it is receiued. Honie, I≈øaac‚ñ™ as ≈øaith I≈øaac in the ≈øecond booke is hot and dry in the ≈øecond degree, it taketh awaye the cau≈øe why the body cannot bee nouri≈øhed, and altereth the √©euell
di≈øpo≈øition vnto better, and expelleth the aboundaunce of √©euell humours out of the pores, and clen≈øeth the filth of the veines, and therfore is very agr√©eable vnto them that are cold and moi≈øt of Nature, and vnto old men. And vnto hot complexions it is as poy≈øon, for it is ≈øoone conuerted into choller. If it be turned into ye warmnes of blood, it maketh it the warmer. So that Honie being eaten raw: ingendreth windines, and maketh a man to ≈øwell, br√©edeth the roughne≈ø≈øe of the throat, and prouoketh vnto vomite and ≈øiege.

Oyle Oliue, as Plinius writeth in the fourth booke, maketh euery body ≈øoft which it toucheth,Plini. giueth force and ≈øtrength, re≈øtraineth al manner of poy≈øons, driueth away payne, loo≈øeth the belly, clen≈øeth the face, appea≈øeth the ≈øwelling, cl√©ereth the eie≈øight, helpeth the headach, and a≈øwageth the heate of Feuers.Rha≈øis. The Oyle of Nuts, ≈øaith Rha≈øis, is very hot and di≈ø≈øoluing, and according vnto Auicen, it is good again≈øt the ringwoorme, inflamacions,Auicen. and pu≈øtles in any part of the eie. The Oyle of Almondes, after Rha≈øis, is temperate, and is good for the Brea≈øt,Rha≈øis Lunges, Bladder, and Kidneis, but if it be eaten it br√©edeth loth≈øumne≈ø≈øe, and departeth ≈ølowly out of the Stomack. And, as ≈øaith Dio≈øcorides, if it be mingled with Honie: it taketh away yt ≈øpots in ye face,Dio≈øco. & maketh ≈ømooth the ≈økarres where wounds haue bin, it clen≈øeth the mi≈øtines of the eies, and taketh away the ≈økales from the ≈økin.

Oyle of Poppie is to be iudged of, according to the nature of Poppie, wherof we intreated in the Chapter la≈øt goyng beefore. And thus endeth the fir≈øt Booke, the contents wherof I haue gathered out of the be≈øt approued Aucthours.

div.head: ¬∂The ≈øecond booke of Table Phylo≈øophy, which ≈øpeaketh of the manners, b√©ehauiour, and v≈øedge, of all ≈øutch with whom wee may happen to bee conuer≈øant at the TABLE.
The Preface.
div.p: HAuing ended the di≈øcour≈øe concerning the Nature of Meates and Drynkes, which are ≈øet before vs vpon the Table, it followeth now, that wee ≈øay ≈øumwhat touchinge the Manners and conditions of whom wee be matched at the Boorde. For as ≈øaith Macrobius in the third Booke of his Saturnalia: There is no part of wi≈ødome ≈øo great, as to applie a mans talke to the place, and time, hauing a regarde to the e≈øtimacion and calling of tho≈øe that are pre≈øent. For ≈øome will be incouraged with examples of Vertue, other with good turnes, and ≈øome with the commendation of Mode≈øtie, that ≈øutch as haue v≈øed them≈øelues otherwi≈øe, and hearing the ≈øame: may amende their liues. And therfore as touching them with whom we be ≈øet at the Table, I wyll ≈øay ≈øumwhat out of the auntient Records of our Elders, beginning with the mo≈øt woorthy Per≈øonagies.

div.head: Chap. 1. ¬∂Of Emperours.
div.p:
ANd fir≈øt to ≈øpeake of Emperours, how that ≈øome of that excellent calling haue bin very frugale & ≈øparing at their Boord,Sueton ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ lib. 3. as Suetonius in the third Booke of the liues of the. 12. Emperours, writeth of Iulius Cae≈øar, ≈øaying that he dranke verie litle Wine, whiche thinge his enemies could not deney, and was indifferent about the re≈øidue of his diet. Vpon a time when at the Table the good man of the hou≈øe where hee ≈øupped, had ≈øet before him olde pre≈øerued Oyle that was ranke & ≈øtale, in the ≈øteede of new and ≈øw√©ete, when other in company refu≈øed it, he only eate it greedely, for yt he would not ≈ø√©eme to reproue him yt had inuited him to ≈øupper, either of litle good manner or couetou≈ønes.
The ≈øame Aucthour al≈øo ≈øaith of Augu≈øtus, that h√©e was a man of ≈ømall feeding, and drunke but very litle wine, for hee v≈øed not to drink therof aboue thri≈øe at a meale. Neither v≈øed hee commonly to drink Wine, but when he was drie hee woulde dip a ≈øop of bread in faire colde water, or eate the ≈ølices of a Cucumber, or of a gr√©ene mellow Apple, who≈øe ta≈øt were tart, or ≈øumwhat like vnto wine. In the Iea≈øtes of the Romanes it is written, that the Emperour Augu≈øtus was a very ≈ømall f√©eder. For he would eate common bread, and litle fi≈øhes, or cruddes made of Cowmilke which he would wringe in his hand, or gr√©ene Figges which he lyked well, and the≈øe thinges would he eate in euery place, and when ≈øo euer his Appetite ≈øerued.

Helinan. Helinandus in his Booke of the in≈øtitutions of Princes, ≈øaith that Iulius Cae≈øer, Lib. 3 de in≈øti. committed his Baker to pri≈øon, becau≈øe hee gaue him better bread at his Table, then he gaue to the re≈øidew of his Souldiours. Suetonius al≈øo in his worke beefore alledged,Suetonius. writeth of the Emperour Tiberius, yt at his fir≈øt comming to the Empire he was very frugall and moderate, but afterward hee grue ≈øo glouttenous, and geuen to the bellie: that in ≈øt√©ede of Tiberius hee was called Biberius, for Claudius Caldius, for Nero, Mero, that is to ≈øay, one ouer much giuen to wine.
