And vpoÃÑ a time ≈øpending two whole daies and nightes with Pomponius Flacchus, & Pi≈øo: for a rewarde, he gaue vnto the one the gouerment of the Prouince of Syria, and to the other the Lieuetenant≈øhip of the ≈øame. He lyked better of one that pre≈øented him with a Mu≈øshrom and a kinde of Birde called Ficedula, then if it had bin a greater matter.

Eg ‚Ä¢ ≈øippusIt is al≈øo written of the Emperour Vitellius, by Ege≈øippus in his fourth Booke of the de≈øtruction of Iheru≈øalem. When hee knew there was ≈øecret wait layd for him,Lib. 4. in the meane time he gaue him≈øelf to fea≈øting and garmandize, bicau≈øe he would not lo≈øe the famous ignominie of the ≈øhame that hung ouer him. Hee was drawne from the banket, hee was contemptuou≈øly in≈øulted vpon, and ≈ølaine in the mid≈øt of the Citie, at one time together, both ≈øheading his bloud and vomyting his
≈øurfeat, who if h√©e had liued any longer: would haue deuoured the trea≈øure of the Romane Empire in riot, and banketinge. To conclude, h√©e had reigned but eight Moneths and fiue daies, and yet Rome was able no longer to ≈øerue his bellye.

div.head: Ghap. 2. Of Kinges
div.p:
FRrontinus in his fourth booke and third chapter of warlike Pollicies, reporteth how that Alexander king of Macedonia, Frontinus‚ñ™ was v≈øed to eate of ≈øutch bread as h√©e founde while h√©e traueiled vpon the waye.Lib. 4. Al≈øo in the fourth booke and vii. chapter, hee writeth in this manner. Alexander kinge of Macedonia, traueilinge by great iourneies through the de≈øertes of Affrica, both h√©e and all his armye beinge greatly athir≈øt, a ≈øouldiour offred him a draught of water in a Sallet, which in pre≈øence of them all hee powred on the ground, de≈øeruing more pray≈øe by that example, then if hee had drunke it. Helinandus in the place beefore recited,Helinand. telleth how that Pi≈øo de≈øiering Romulus to ≈øupper, and perceiuing how litle wine he had drunke at that meale: O Romulus, if euery man woulde do as thou doo≈øt, wine would be better cheape. Nay (quod h√©e) it would bee dearer if euerye man might drinke what hee would. Valerius Max. in his fift booke and ≈øixte chapter,Valerius Max. writeth that kinge Alexander vpon a time beeing repul≈øed from ≈øome purpo≈øe by a tempe≈øt in the winter, beeholding an ould Macedonian ≈øouldiour quaking and b√©enummed with could, and him≈øelfe ≈øitting in his regall ≈øeate by a good fier:Note. euen with tho≈øe handes wherewith hee was woont to be≈øtowe liberall rewardes, hee tooke the ould man that was crooked and doubled with colde, and ≈øet him in his owne place. What merueill was it then if it were plea≈øant vnto them to ≈øerue ≈øo many yeeres vnder that captaine, which e≈øteemed more of the goodhealth of a common ≈øouldiour, then hee did of his own dignitye? In the ≈øame place it is al≈øo writen, that Pyrrhus the king, ≈øayd that certen Tarentines had talked of him very broade, and vndutifull language at a banket. Then demaunded hee of one of the companye, whether they had any ≈øutch
talke or not? yea truly ≈øaid h√©e, w√©e had ≈øo ind√©ede, and vnles our wine had fayled vs the≈øe had bin but trifles in re≈øpect of that we would haue ≈øpoken. So plea≈øant an excu≈øe of their rioting, & ≈øo frank confe≈ø≈øion of the truthe, turned the Kinges wrath into laughter. By v≈øing of which clemency he obtayned this mutch, that his Subiectes the Tarentines thanked him when they were ≈øober, and praied for him when they were drunken.

div.head: Chap. 3. Of Princes.
div.p:
Plutrach. PLutrach of the in≈øtitutions of Princes, citeth the aucthoritie of Plato, which ≈øaith thus: when Potentates oppre≈ø≈øe their ≈øubiects, it is like as if the head of a body ≈øhould ≈øwell to ≈øutch hugines, that the other parts were able ≈øcarcely, or not at all, to beare it, but with great paine. Likewi≈øe when the hier powers do hate and per≈øecute the ≈øubiectes, it is lyke as if the tutor ≈øhould pur≈øue his pupil to ≈ølay him with the ≈øword which he gaue him to defend him again≈øt others.Helinan. Hel ‚Ä¢ nandus in his booke of the in≈øtitution of Princes ≈øaith, yt a Prince ≈øhould do as the Phi≈øition doth, which neuer geueth extreme medicines, but when he ≈ø√©eth that gentle pocions will neuer recouer the Pacients health. Vnto which purpo≈øe ≈øaid Lucius very well,Lucius. that it behoued a Prince to be an old man in manners, & to follow ripe and wi≈øe coun≈øell, and to imitate the order of good Phi≈øitions, which ≈øumtime cure by filllnge that which is emptie in ≈øpare bodies, & ≈øumtime by emptyinge yt which aboundeth to much in full bodies, a≈øwaging the greife many times with hot burning irons, & often with fomentacions, and ≈øumtime otherwi≈øe, vnto which intent hee ≈øetteth downe the≈øe ver≈øes:
To puni≈øh let a Prince be ≈ølow, and quick to giue reward:
And let it greeue him when he is con≈øtrained to be hard.

Ari≈øtotle. Ari≈øtotle in the third of the Politickes writeth thus: who≈øo would haue wit and vnder≈øtanding to gouerne (≈øaith he) it ≈øemeth he would haue God and the lawes to gouerne: but who≈øo will haue a man of him≈øelf without the≈øe to gouerne, putteth
a very ≈øauedge bea≈øt in aucthoritie. For when rage and lu≈øt beare ≈øway, then good men go to wrack, ≈øo that vnder≈øtanding without affection is as good as a written law. Likewi≈øe Vegetius in his fir≈øt booke and fir≈øt chapter of the art of war, it is decent for a Prince (≈øaith he) yt no man know mo things nor better things then he, for his knowledge may profit all his ≈øubiectes, and for that cau≈øe Princes ought to applie them≈øelues to the ≈øtudy of wi≈ødome.

div.head: Chap. 4 Of the Gentile Byshops.
div.p:
∆≤Alerius in his fift Booke and fift chapter, writeth of Horatius Puluillus, who being By≈ø≈øhop,Valerius. and as hee was after the gui≈øe at tho≈øe daies, con≈øecrating a great Church vnto Iupiter, while he was pronouncing the ≈øolemne woordes, & holding the po≈øt in his hand: woord was brought vnto him that his ≈øunne was dead: hee neither plucked his hande from the po≈øt, neither changed his countinaunce from the publique religion to his priuat ≈øorow, becau≈øe he would not ≈ø√©eme at that pre≈øent to ≈øu≈øtaine rather the per≈øon of a Father, then of a By≈ø≈øhop. In the ≈øame place likewi≈øe he writeth of Xenophon, who being offring a very ≈øolemne ≈øacrifice, it was tolde him that his elde≈øt ≈øunne was ≈ølaine. Then did he only put of the crowne from his head, demaunding of the me≈ø≈øenger in what ≈øort he was ≈ølaine. And vnder≈øtanding that he was killed fightinge very valiently: he put the crowne vpon his head againe, ≈øhewing that he tooke more ioy of his valiencie, then he did greif of his vntimely death. S. Ierome in ye ≈øecond booke again≈øt Iouinian, Ierome. writeth yt Zenon yt Stoick reporteth of the liues of the auntient prie≈øts of Egipt, how that ≈øetting all worldly care and bu≈øines apart, they alwaies remained in ye Church, ≈øearching the hid natures of things, & ob≈øeruing the motions of the ≈øtars They neuer companied wt their wiues, nor any woman, nor neuer ≈øaw their children nor kin≈øfolks after ye once they betooke theÃÑ≈øelues to diuine ≈øeruice. They ab≈øtained froÃÑ eating fle≈øh & drinking wine, chefly to auoid ye motion to ye fle≈øh, which coÃÑmeth by tho≈øe meats, & ye drink. They did ≈øeldome eate bread, but they v≈øed oyle both to driue away
loth≈øomnes, and to take away the roughnes of their throats. What ≈øhall I ≈øpeake of foules, ≈ø√©eing they e≈øchewed egs and milke as flea≈øh, wherof they ≈øayde the one was liquid flea≈øh, and the other bloud, the coulour onely being chaunged. They laide a foot≈øtoole vnder their heades in ≈øt√©ede of a pillow,Ari≈øtole. and fa≈øted two or thr√©e daies togeather. And Ari≈øtotle in the ≈øeauenth of his Politickes: the Prie≈øts ≈øaith h√©e, haue charge of althings appertaining to the God, and to ≈ø√©e that hou≈øes bee kept vp tight in repairacions, and tho≈øe which bee fallen downe may be builded vp agayne, and that others be appointed vnto their purpo≈øes, and for this cau≈øe they bee had in reuerence. Sum of the≈øe Bi≈øhops are termed by one man, Princes, by an other Kinges, ≈øum call them Pote≈øtates, Prouo≈øts, and Mai≈øters. S√©e then if the Prie≈øtes and By≈ø≈øhops of the Gentiles, were ≈øo religious, continent, and holie: what ought our Chri≈øtian Bi≈ø≈øhops to be?

div.head: Chap. 4. Of noble Per≈øonages.
div.p: Tullie TVllie in his booke of olde age, writeth that when a certen man in reproche ≈øaide vnto Themi≈øtocles, that hee had no honour of him≈øelfe, but that all his e≈øtimacion came vnto him by rea≈øon of his cuntrey: ≈øurely, ≈øaide Themi≈øtocles, if I were Sere≈øius I ≈øhould bee but a verlet, and if thou were an Athenian thou woulde≈øt neuer haue bin of any e≈øtimacion.

Cecilius. Cecil ‚Ä¢ us Balbus, of the toyes of Philo≈øophers writeth: that when one a time one being borne of the race of a Senatour and at that pre≈øent mutch imba≈øed, obiected to Epaminundas the vil ‚Ä¢ nes of his birth: I am glad (quoth he) that I am ry≈øen of my ≈øelfe, and thou art fallen of thy ≈øelfe, and wee both together are honour and di≈øhonour.

Salu≈øt. Salu≈øt in the Oracion of Marius again≈øt Iugurth, when one „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢ ery mutch in his owne conceit in re≈øpect of his owne „Äà‚óä„Äâ and therfore reproched Marius ba≈øene≈ø≈øe: although (≈øaith h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ) we haue one nature common vnto vs all, that eue
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ ma ‚Ä¢ , if he can, be mo≈øt valient and mo≈øt noble, yet if there ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ an ‚Ä¢ man that de≈øpice-me, let them do that which is a
agr√©eable to their manners, ≈øince the exerci≈øe of vertuous exploites, is the verie beginning of mine honour. They enuye at mine honour, let them al≈øo enuie at my paines, and mine innocency, and my traueiles, and my daungers, for by the≈øe haue I woon it. Now ≈ø√©e (I be≈ø√©ech you) how vniu≈øt they b√©e, they wyll not ≈øuffer me to get yt by mine owne vertue, which they boa≈øt in them≈øelues to haue bin gotten by another. And becau≈øe I haue no images, and my Nobility is new and now fir≈øt ri≈øen in my ≈øelfe, which better it is to get fir≈øt, then to di≈øhonour it being once gotten before. As for mee, in my iudgment, there can no mans talke hurt m√©e. For if they ≈øpeake ill of m√©e, my b√©ehauiour ≈øhal declare their report to b√©e fal≈øe. The Speare and Shield, En≈øigne, Barbed Armour for the Cour≈øer, with other rewards of the Fielde, and ≈øcarres in the fore parte of my body, the≈øe are my Images, this is my Nobilitie, not left vnto me by inheritance as theirs is, but gotten by mine owne aduentures and traueill.Iuuenall. And Iuuenall the Poet ≈øaith very well.

q.l: I rather had Ther≈øites ≈øun thou were, ≈øo that thou might
Like Pyrrhus beare Vulcanus Armes in mid≈øt of Martial fight.
Then if Achillus ≈øhould beget one like Ther≈øites foule,
A da≈øtard wretch, that could do naught, but prattle, ≈øcould & skoule.

div.p: And Albertus vpon the fir≈øt Booke of the Ethickes ≈øaith,Albertus. how it is read, that the Emperour of Rome Diocle≈øian, who gouerned that Empire very valiently, was taken from among ≈øh√©eperds. And he is a right Gentleman, ≈øaith Seneca, Senica. that is naturally di≈øpo≈øed vnto vertue.

div.head: Chap. 5. Of Knightes.
div.p:
∆≤Alerius Maximus in the third Booke and ≈øecond Chapter,Vale. Ma. writeth of a Knight that was Captayne of a band vnder Augu≈øtus, and had geuen many a ≈øharp ≈øhoure vnto Antonius, and went away euermore with the better hand. At length being taken by trea≈øon, and brought pri≈øoner to Alexandria, Antonius a≈øked hym what hee ≈øhould do to him? Then the
Knight, ≈øaid commaunde mee to bee ≈ølaine (quod hee) for neyther with hope of life, nor feare of death will I bee per≈øwaded, to for≈øake Cae≈øar and ≈øerue th√©e. Howbeit, the more con≈øtantly hee de≈øpi≈øed his life, ≈øo mutch the more ea≈øly hee obtained it. For Antonius pardoned his life for his vertuous ≈øake.Frontinus. Frontinus in the fourth booke and fir≈øt chapter of his warlike pollicies, reporteth, that when Flaccus and Varro were Con≈øuls then were Knightes fir≈øt dubbed, and admitted vnto that order by an othe, for before they were gouerned by the Tribunes. The tenour of their othe was after this ≈øorte, that they would neuer departe one from another, nor breake their aray in the field, vnle≈ø≈øe it were either to recouer their weapon or to ≈øtrike the enemie, or to ≈øaue a citizen.

Helinand.And our Knightes, ≈øaith Helinandus, march forth into the warres as it were to a wedding, for at Fea≈øtes they talke of Armes, and in the tentes they ≈øpeake of fea≈øtes. The arte of warrefare,Valerius. ≈øaith Valerius, in the ≈øecond booke and fir≈øt chapter, beeinge earne≈øtly followed, brought the whole Empire of Italy in ≈øubiection to the Romanes. And gat them the ≈øouerainity of many cities, pui≈øant kings, and mo≈øt valient kingdomes. That ≈øame opened vnto them the bo≈øome of the ≈øea, and broke vp the ≈øtreights and pa≈ø≈øedges ouer the Alpes, and Mount Taurus, and deliuered them into their handes. And Clearchus, Captaine of the Lacedemonians, ≈øaith the ≈øame acthour, was wont to ≈øay often, beating it into the ≈øouldiours eares, that ≈øouldiours ≈øhoulde ≈øtande more in feare of their Captayne then of their enemies.

div.head: Chap. 7. Of Squyres.
div.p:
Vegetius. VEgetius in the fir≈øt booke and fourth chapter, ≈øaith, that the things which ar learned in childhoode are not learned very ≈øp√©edely, but they ar retained very perfectly. And moreouer the nimblenes whiche beelongeth to a Souldiour, as in leapinge and runninge, is oftentimes to bee exerci≈øed, that the body waxe not vnweldye with age. For it is Swiftnes and nimblenes, which are gotten with daylye exerci≈øe,
that make a good ≈øouldiour. For vnto him that is ≈øo trayned vp it ≈øhalbe no feare to encounter with any enemy, but rather a plea≈øure.

And agayne in the ≈øame woorke and thirde chapter hee ≈øayth thus: I doubte not, ≈øaith h√©e, that anye man can b√©e of another opinion but that the common hu≈øbandman is fitte≈øt for the warres, that can abide to toyle in the ≈øunne and open ayre, careth not for the ≈øhadowe, knoweth not the baynes nor hothou≈øe, is ignorante of delicacies,Note. plaine meaninge, contente with a litle, able to abide all paynes, to beare armour, to ditche, or ca≈øt a trench, and of cu≈øtome to carye greate burdeins, not fearinge the Sunne or the Du≈øt. Wherfore, mee≈øeemeth wee mu≈øt for the mo≈øt parte take all our force out of the countrey, for mee thinkes hee mu≈øt needes care le≈ø≈øe for death that neuer felt anye plea≈øure or ≈øweetene≈ø≈øe in his life, and therfore ≈øuch are to bee trayned vp in the warres.

Likewi≈øe in the fir≈øt booke and fir≈øt chapter, wee ≈ø√©e, ≈øaith hee, that the people of Rome conquered al the world be none other meanes then by exerci≈øe of the minde, by di≈øciplyne of the fielde, and dayly practi≈øe of Chiualrye, whereby they ro≈øe to that greatnes. And when wee choo≈øe newe ≈øouldiours, wee mu≈øt choo≈øe nimble men, and furni≈øhe them with daylye practi≈øe, for the knowledge of the order of the warres maketh a man bould to fight. For no man wilbee a fearde to do that which hee knoweth that hee hath learned to do perfectlye. And when they come to the battayll, the ≈ømall bande that is well trayned, is mo≈øt like to haue the victorye. The rude and vn≈økilfull multitude lieth alwayes open vnto ≈ølaughter.

And Frontinus in the fourth booke, & ≈øecond chapter,Frontinus. lib. 4. ca. 2. writeth thus: Alexander Kinge of Macedonia, ≈øaith hee, with a fewe ≈øouldiours well trayned, which his father Phillip left behinde him, ≈øetting vpon the whole worlde: ≈ølew innumerable armies of his enemies.

div.head: Chap. 8. Of warriours.
div.p: Ari≈øtotle.AS the noble Philo≈øopher Ari≈øtotle writeth, in the ≈øeventh of his Politickes, many cities haue flouri≈øhed by makinge warre, but when they had once obtained the ≈øoueraintye; through peace they fell to decay, as iron gathereth ru≈øt with lyinge ≈øtill. Valerius in the ≈øecond booke, and ≈øixt chapter, writeth,Valerius. that Laelius Atticus Dentatus was an hundreth and twentie times in batteill, vnto which h√©e alwaies went with ≈øutch courage of minde and force of body, that h√©e ≈ø√©emed euer to pre≈øume of the victory. The ≈øame aucthour al≈øo reporteth that there was one which cut of the fingers of his left hand, bicau≈øe h√©e woulde not goo into the Italian warre. Then by the decr√©e of the Senate his goodes were openly ≈øolde, and him ≈øelfe ca≈øt into perpetuall pri≈øon, enforcinge him to y√©elde vp that gho≈øt mo≈øt loth≈øomly in cheines, which hee refu≈øed valiently to venture in the fielde.Frontinus. Frontinus in the fir≈øt booke, and ninth chapter reporteth, that one Seruius b√©einge a younge man, and pre≈øent in the batteill which kinge Tarquinius faught again≈øt the Sabines, perceiuinge tho≈øe that were about the Standards to fight very ≈ølowly: ≈ønatched away one of the Standards and thrue it among≈øt the middes of the enemies. To recouer which, the Romans fought ≈øo ≈øharply: that they obtained both ≈øtandard, and victory. H√©e telleth moreouer of Macillius which was Con≈øul, and at the warre which the Romans made again≈øt the Samnites, who perceiuinge the ≈øouldiours fleeing out of the batteill towardes their tentes: bent the force of his owne band which hee led, again≈øt them: ≈øwearing, that hee would fight again≈øt good Citizens if they would not fight again≈øt their enemies, and by that meanes brought them all again into the batteill.

div.head: Chap. 9. Of Philo≈øophers, and Oratours.
div.p:
Architarentinus. ARchitarentinus in the ≈øixt booke, writeth, that when on a time Ari≈øtippus the Socration Philo≈øopher being throweÃÑ into the ≈øea by ≈øhipwrack was ca≈øt a lande at the ≈øhoare of Rodes, and found there certain Geometricall figures and demon≈øtracions
drawne in the ≈øandes: hee cried aloud ioyfully vnto his Mates, let vs b√©e of good cheere Mates (quod hee) for I ≈øee heere the foote ≈øteppes of men. And foorthwith hee entred into the citie of Rhods, where di≈øputing in their ≈øcholes with profe≈ø≈øours of Philo≈øophy, hee was rewarded with many co≈øtly gyftes, wherwith hee not onely appayrelled him≈øelfe, but al≈øo al that were with him, and bore their charges ≈øufficiently for meat and drinke. And when his Mates, being willing to returne into their owne cuntrey, demaunded of him what ≈øeruice hee would commaunde them home: tell my cuntrey men (quod h√©e) that I wi≈øh they ≈øhould prepare ≈øutch po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions and inheritances for their children, as if they chaÃÑ ced to e≈øcape ≈øhipwrack, might e≈øcape with them, and not be taken awaye neither by violence of conque≈øt, neither by change of fortune, nor by any other aduer≈øitie. Behold h√©ere a Philo≈øophicall and hol≈øome document, moouing men more to the ≈øtudy of learning and wi≈ødome, then to heaping vp of Monye. In the olde time when cities weare in peace, ≈øayth Eu≈øtacius vpon the fir≈øt booke of the Ethickes, the noblemen and politick gouerners, prouided of the common charge,Eu≈øtacius. for ≈øutch as were ≈øtudentes in Philo≈øophy, that they ≈øhould bee voide of all cares and troubles, and onely applye them≈øelues vnto contemplacion.Hermes. Hermes ≈øurnamed Tri≈ømegi≈øtus in his ≈øecond booke of Con≈øtellacions, reporteth that Politinus the Philo≈øopher, b√©eing, as it were, made vnto all ornamentes of vertue, to the intent hee might expre≈ø≈øe that which he taught by his owne example, and not by any others, and to a void all the in≈øultes of Fortune: cho≈øe him a ≈øecret place of re≈øt, where h√©e was far from the trouble of humane conuer≈øation onely b√©e≈øtowing his time in diuine contemplacions. And fir≈øt hee contemned all titles of honour, accoumpting tho≈øe to b√©e the true honours which by perfection of wi≈ødome h√©e had gotten. Hee coueted after no worldly thing, but iudged that to bee the true ritches, namely whereby a garni≈øhed minde may finde out the originall of it owne aucthoritye.Ari≈øtotle. Ari≈øtotle in the Secrets of ≈øecrets, a≈øketh th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ que≈øtion, what (≈øayth hee)
hath ≈øo aduaunced the Empire of the Gr√©ekes to b√©e perpetually renowmed ouer all the world? Surely that did the dilygence of ≈øtudents, and the vertue of the wi≈øemen which loued knowledge, and ≈øcience aboue all mea≈øure.

Aulus. Gellius. Aulus Gellius in his booke of the Nightes of Athens, writeth, that it is one of the greate≈øt poincts of commendacion which was in Phillip kinge of Macedonia, father vnto Alexander the Great, that h√©e cau≈øed him whom h√©e thought ≈øhould b√©e his heier, to bee deliuered in charge vnto the mo≈øt excellent Philo≈øopher Ari≈øtotle, to bee in≈øtructed in wi≈ødome, and learning. And, ≈øaith Seneca, in that world, which men coÃÑmonly call the golden world, Po≈øidonius affirmeth that wi≈øe men gouerned kingdomes, the≈øe contayned their handes from othermens goodes, and defended the weake from the more mighty, they per≈øwaded men from di≈øhone≈øty vnto hone≈øty, and through their wi≈ødome they declared what was profitable, and what otherwi≈øe.

div.head: Chap 10. Of Phi≈øicions.
div.p: ISidorus in the third chapter of his Etimologies, writeth, that Apollo is reported to bee the fir≈øt finder out of Phi≈øicke amonge the Gr√©ekes.I≈øidor. Which his Sun E≈øculapius broughte more into the light, who was ≈øtrickeÃÑ with a tempe≈øt of lightning and ≈øo died, and by that meanes both the art and the authour peri≈øhed together, and lay vnknowne the ≈øpace of fiue-hundred y√©eres, vnto the time of Artaxerxes king of the Per≈øians, at what time it was reuiued agayne by Hippocrates, ≈øunne to A≈ø ‚Ä¢ ulapius.

Valerius writeth, that when Alexander kinge of Maced ‚Ä¢
nia fell ≈øick at Thar≈øis, Valerius. Phillip the Phi≈øition made him a potion with his owne handes, and mini≈øtred it vnto him. For this Phillip was both an Earle, and a Phi≈øition. And while h√©e was thus attendant vpon the kinge, there were certen letters receiued and opened, written to this effect, That the king should take heede of Phillip, as one of corrupted by Darius to poi≈øon him. But ≈øo ≈øoone as the king had read the letters,
without any ≈øtaying h√©e dranke of the Medicine, and deliuered them vnto Phillip to read, for whiche good opinion of his tru≈øtie friende and Phi≈øition, h√©e receaued of the Gods an immortall reward. Howbeit I wote very well, that Quintus Cur ‚Ä¢ ius in the hy≈øtorie of Alexande ‚Ä¢
the great,Quin. cur. telleth this ≈øtorie otherwi≈øe, namely, how that Alexander returnynge from Babilon, and ≈øpendyng longe time in re≈øt and idlene≈ø≈øe, h√©e renued the ≈øolemnitie of Fea≈øtynge and Banquettinge, whiche of longe time h√©e had omitted, and thus in a ioylitie h√©e ≈øpent an whole day and a night, when The≈ø≈øalus his phi≈øition inuited him and his companions agayn to drinkynge a fre≈øh. And takyng the Pot in his hand, when hee had drunk, as it were, half a draught, h√©e ≈øuddenly ≈øtayde in the middes and cried out: and his friendes reported that ≈øame to be the cau≈øe of his death. But the trueth is, there was Trea≈øon wrought agayn≈øt him, the infamie whereof was couered by the puni≈øhment of his ≈øucce≈ø≈øours. And in d√©ede Antipater was ch√©eif of the con≈øpiracie, and gaue the poy≈øon vnto him. Thus died Alexander in the xii. ye√®re of his reygne, his traitrous nobles fal≈øly accu≈øinge his faithfull Phi≈øition of poy≈øonyng him.

div.head: Chap. 11. Of youngemen.
div.p:
MAcrobius in his fourth booke of Saturnalia, reporteth, how that Papirius when h√©e was but a childe,Macrob‚ñ™ came into the coun≈øel court with his Father. And when he returned home, his mother demaunded of him what his Father had doone or ≈øayd in the Senate coun≈øel. The child an≈øwered, that he might not tel. But when his Mother threatned to beate him vnle≈ø≈øe he would declare it: immediatly he deui≈øed a fine & plea≈øant lye to ≈øtop his mothers mouth withal, ≈øaying, yt it was di≈øputed in the Coun≈øel hou≈øe, whether it were more expedient for man to haue two wiues, or for a woman to haue two hu≈øbaÃÑs. This news told ≈øhe immediatly vnto other MatroÃÑs & go≈ø≈øips of hir acquaintaÃÑ
‚Ä¢ e. And ye next day there came a great flock of them to ye Coun≈øel hou≈øe, de≈øiring ye honourable a≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢
ÃÑbly, ye one womaÃÑ might rather haue .ij. hu≈øbands, then one maÃÑ .ii. wiues
The Senatours wondringe at that ≈øtrainge reque≈øt: merueyled at their ≈øo vnrea≈øonable, and di≈øhone≈øt importuniti. Then the childe re≈øolued the Senat of that doubt, ≈øhe winge them what hee had tolde his mother. The Senate imbraced the childes wit and faithfulnes, and made an Act, that heareafter there ≈øhould no children come into the Senate with their fathers, but hee onely.

Vale. Valerius al≈øo in the ≈øixt Booke and fift Chapter, writeth of Manlius Torquatus, yt while he was yong: he was of ≈øo blunt and dul a wit, that his father iudgeing him neuer like to bee profitable member to gouerne in the common wealth, ≈øent him into the cuntry to follow hu≈øbandry. But afterward hee deliuered his father from danger of iudgment. And likewi≈øe his cuntrey in the tumult among the Latines, which was welnigh con≈øumed in the conflict, and obtayned therefore a mo≈øt excellent triumph.Valerius. I ≈øuppo≈øe, ≈øaith Valerius, that he was imba≈øed with this blemi≈øh of Fortune in his youth, wherby the excellency of his old age might appeare more bewtifull.

And againe in the ≈øame place he ≈øaith, Scipio ≈øurnamed Affricane, whom the Gods would haue to be borne to the intent all vertue ≈øhould be effectually expre≈ø≈øed vnto men in him, is reported to haue ≈øpent thriftely his younger yeares, but farthe≈øt of all other from ≈øu≈øpicion of la≈øciuious di≈ø≈øolutne≈ø≈øe.

Fabi‚ñ™ MaxAnd this al≈øo ≈øaith he, hath Fabius Maximus pu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a≈øed vnto his po≈øteritie, that there was neuer any of better fame then hee while he was young, neither did our Citie of Rome euer bring foorth one that in his age was of greater honour and e≈øtimacion.

div.head: Chap. 12 Of olde Men.
div.p:
‚Ä¢ ro. pom. TRogus Pompeius in his ≈øecond Booke, writeth of Alexander the great, that on a time when hee was goinge foorth in a daungerous expedition: he leuied his armie not of Cutters and lu≈øty youthes, but of ≈øuch antient ≈øouldiours as had ≈øerued his father and his cuntry in foretimes, to the intent hee might haue no common ≈øoldiers, but rather teachers of Chiualrie about him. Hee made no Captaines but men of thr√©e≈øcore
y√©ere olde, ≈øo that no man thought of fl√©eing, but of haueyng yt victory. And Valerius ≈øpeaking of the old Romanes, Valerius. ≈øsith in tho≈øe daies yong men honoured old age, as though all olde men had bin their fathers. Cicero in his Booke of old age,Cicero. reporteth, that in a certen controuer≈øie when Pi≈øi≈øtratus the tirant demanded of Solon, for what cau≈øe he dur≈øt re≈øi≈øt him ≈øo boldly, he an≈øwered, becau≈øe of mine olde age.

Io≈øephus in the fir≈øt booke of Antiquities:Io≈øeph. Let no man (≈øaith h√©e) thinke that to be fal≈øe which is written concerninge the long liuing of our forfathers in the old time. For in re≈øpect of their vertues, and the ≈øingular profits which they deui≈øed for mankinde, as are the Artes of Geometrie, A≈øtronomie, and ≈øuch like: GOD inlarged the tearme of their life, for el≈øe they could neuer haue come vnto that perfection in them. It is read in the Cronacles, that about the y√©ere of our Lorde a thou≈øand an hundred twentie nine, IoaÃÑnes de temporibus which liued in the time of Charles the Maine, and who≈øe Squire h√©e was, died.

Papius in the beginning of his Romane hi≈øtorie,Papius. writeth that the ≈øame Romulus which builded the Citie of Rome, and called it after his owne name, cho≈øe into his coun≈øell an hundred Senatours who≈øe aduice hee might v≈øe in all matters, whom by rea≈øon of their y√©eres, and for the likenes of the charge, he called Fathers.

div.head: Chap. 13 Of Citizens.
div.p:
ARi≈øtotle in the third booke of his Politickes defineth a Citie after this maner.Ari≈øtotle. A Citie (≈øaith he) is an vnitie of tho≈øe that be like, m√©eting together to liue in happy ≈øocietie. And felicitie is a certen trea≈øure ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing all other thinges, and the very exerci≈øe of all vertues. And the≈øe be the things without which there can be no Citie, for why the lyfe of man requireth many nece≈ø≈øaries. The fir≈øt is foode, then Arts, next weapons to ≈øubdue the di≈øobedient: the fourth ≈øtore of mony: the fift in≈øtructions in religion whom they call Prie≈øtes: the ≈øixt a company of Judges to confer togeather what is right and what not, & if any of the≈øe be lacking it is no perfect city.
And therefore there mu≈øt n√©edes bee Hu≈øbandmen to prepare Victuales, Handycrafts men, Warriours, ritchmen, Prie≈øtes and iudges. And moreouer (he ≈øaith) who≈øo hath abilytie to participate or communicate, that is to geue or take coun≈øell, to rule or to bee ruled: the ≈øame is a perfecte Citizen.

Likewi≈øe Citizens ought to agr√©e and not to fall out, for as ≈øaith Oro≈øius in the ≈øecond Booke of his Orchme≈øtra, Oro≈øius. the mo≈øt wi≈øe Citizens of Athens, beinge taught by their owne harmes, haue ≈øaid that ≈ømal things grow greater by concord, and great things are de≈øtroyed by di≈øagr√©ement, and what≈øoeuer was done well or yll in their Commonwealth, their Dome≈øticall contention at home, and their continuall warringe abroade ≈øubuerted all, wheerby they left to their po≈øterytie an example of ruine with ≈ømall hope of recouery, but yet a mo≈øt certen le≈ø≈øon to learne, that it is good to folow that coun≈øell in pro≈øterytie, which ≈øeemeth be≈øt vnto vs when we were in aduer≈øitie.

Vitarbius. Vitarbius in his worke of Architecture or Building, writeth that the Temple of Mars was builded without the walles of the Citie, becau≈øe their ≈øhould be no bloudy di≈ø≈øention among the Citizens, but their force ≈øhould ≈øerue them to defend their walles in time of warre.

div.head: Chap. 14 Of Marchantes.
div.p:
Valerius.
∆≤Alerius in his ≈øeuenth Booke and fourth chapter, maketh mencion of one Claudius Centimmalus, who hauinge an Hou≈øe ≈øtandinge very high vpon the top of the hill Celius in Rome: was commaunded by the Colledge of South≈øayers, to take downe ≈øumwhat of the height therof, for that it hindred ≈øumdeale the perfect view of their South≈øayinge. But hee immediatly ≈øolde it vnto Calphurnius Lauarius. Then Cato beinge a man of greate integritie, condempned the ≈øeller in the law, for that h√©e toulde not faithfully to the byer
both the commodities and di≈øcommodities like to en≈øue of the purcha≈øe, whiche hee ought to haue doone.

Lykewy≈øe, the ≈øame Aucthour in the fyr≈øt Booke and ≈øecond Chapter, writeth, how that in the Prene≈øtine Siege it fortuned that one which cought a Mou≈øe, ≈øould him to another for two hundred Pence, ≈øutch was the ≈øcarcytie of victuales there. But it chaunced not longe after that hee whiche ≈øould it dyed for hunger hym≈øelfe, and he that bought it e≈øcaped a liue. The lyke Example is reported by Frontinus, Frontinus, of the Ca≈ø≈øeline Siege.

Ari≈øtotle in the fir≈øt of the Politickes writeth,Ari≈øtotle. that vpon a time a certen man reprochfully ca≈øt Mille≈øius in the teeth that hee was a Begger, as though Phylo≈øophie were a knowledge vnprofitable to it ≈øelfe, and in no re≈øpect benificiall to the Profe≈ø≈øours thereof. Then Mille≈øius perceyuinge by the iudgement of A≈øtronomie, that the next yeare there woulde bee but verye fewe Oliues, in the Winter while there was great ≈øtoare hee gaue Monye in earne≈øt vnto the Fruiterers and Mai≈øters of Gardeines in Miletum and Tyrus, vpon a price for all their Oliues the yeare following, as though hee di≈øtru≈øted not but that there woulde be great ≈øtoare. But when the tyme came, and there were inde√©de but fewe, and manie called for them, hee ≈øoulde them all ≈øuddainlye togeather, makynge what price hee ly≈øt, and by that meanes gatheryng a great ≈øumme of Monie, declared thereby how ea≈øie a matter it is for Phylo≈øophers to bee rytch when they ly≈øt, but Ritches is not the thing that they ≈ø√©eks for.

In the ≈øame place it is al≈øo ≈øet downe that in the Ile of Sicil a certayne Marchaunt ≈øuddaynlye bought vp all the Iron that was there aboute, or that was to bee gotten out of the Mines. Afterwarde there came ≈øtrainge Marchauntes vnto the Marte, and no man ≈øoulde Iron but hee onely, not mutch ray≈øing the price, but of euery fiue Talentes hee gayned tenne Pence, re≈øeruing vnto him≈øelf a compotent profit.
But Dioni≈øius the Tyrant tooke his goodes from him, and would not ≈øuffer him (as a finder out of wealth, which thinge was mutch again≈øt his profit) to dwel any longer in siracu≈øis. For as the expo≈øitour ≈øaith vpon that place, tyrants may not abide to haue their ≈øubiectes ritch.

div.head: Chap. 15. Of husbandmen and Husbandrie.
div.p: IN the commendacion of hu≈øbandry, Oro≈øius in the ≈øeuenth booke ≈øaith,Oro≈øius. that in the thr√©e hundred foure≈øcore and eleuen y√©ere, after the building of the citye of Rome, Quintus Cincinatus, which was Di≈øtator, was found in the cuntrey, and taken from the plough, and taking the honoure vpon him, and mu≈øtering his Armye: obtained a great conque≈øt ouer his enemies. And Valerius writeth,Valerius that they which were ≈øent vnto A≈øtilius to come take the whole gouerment of the army vpon him, found him in the fieldes going after the plough tayll, ≈øowing of corne. Howbeit tho≈øe handes whiche were worne with exerci≈øe of hu≈øbandrye, e≈øtabli≈øhed the ≈øure welfare of the commonwealth, and vanqui≈øhed hugie armies of raging enemies. And tho≈øe handes which not longe b√©efore guided the yokes of the drawing Oxen, held then the reignes of the triumphant charret.

And Plinius in the xviii. booke of the hi≈øtorie of nature, it is the ≈øaying of Marcus Curius, Plinie. ≈øaith hee, that the≈øame is a naughty Citizen, that cannot bee ≈øufficed to liue with ≈øeuen acres of lande. What was the cau≈øe then that they had ≈øutch plenty? For≈øooth their generalles, and gouerners tilled the lande with their owne handes, and the grounde reioyced at a Laureat ≈øhare, and a triumphant ploughman. And looke with what diligence they went into the warres: with the≈øame they tilled their fieldes. And ordred their land with as mutch care, as they did their Camps. Many times captaynes, yea, and whole Senates haue bin fet out of the cuntrey. And now bond≈ølaues till the≈øame ground, and damned handes, and pro≈øcribed countnances.

Valerius Valerius in the ≈øeuenth booke and tenth chapter, telleth of
Valerius Coruinus, how h√©e b√©eing an hundred y√©ere olde,Vale. and in good ≈øtrength of bodye, left beehind him not onely a wi≈øhed example of dealing in Publique functions, but al≈øo in tilling the land, and all maner hu≈øbandrie.

And Noble Cicero in the fifte of his offices ≈øaith,Cicero. that among all trades, wherby a man may liue: ther is none to bee preferred beefore hu≈øbandrye, nothing ≈øweeter, or more plentifull, nor fitter for a gentleman.

div.head: Chap. 16. Of Handicraftes men.
div.p:
ARi≈øtotle in his booke intitled ≈øecrets of ≈øecrets,Ari≈øtotle. ≈øheweth of the wonderfull operation of the influence of ye Planets in the natures of men and other things, by that which hapned vnto a childe the ≈øunne of the kinge of India. For when the childe his ≈øunne was growne to ≈øome yeeres, the king would haue had him brought vp in learninge, for which intent hee ≈øent him throughout all India and other Prouinces adiacent, very honourably accompanied, as it was bee≈øittinge for the ≈øunne of ≈øutch a Prince. But the fathers diligence profited him nothing at all, for why, the childes di≈øpo≈øition could not b√©e brought vnto anye other thing, but to b√©e an handicrafts man. Wherwith the kinge beeinge mutch troubled in his minde, ≈øent for all the wi≈øe men of his Realme to come vnto him, and when hee had told them that the cau≈øe why h√©e ≈øent for them was to knowe their opinions, concerninge his ≈øun: They an≈øwered him, that h√©e ≈øhould applye him to that wher to he was mo≈øt inclined, and ≈øo h√©e did. In the ≈øame place al≈øo hee telleth of a certen weauer that had a ≈øunne, who≈øe natiuity fore≈øhewed that h√©e ≈øhould bee a greate wi≈øe man, full of graue coun≈øell, and in fauour with Princes. And when his father would haue in≈øtructed him in his own art of weauing: hee could not learne it. Then did hee whip him, and beat him and gaue him vp vnto his owne will, and the b ‚Ä¢ y ioyninge him≈øelfe vnto learned men, obtayned knowledge, and vnder≈øtanding of the heauenly motions, and of the gouerment of Princes, and at length was made one of the kinges Coun≈øellers
Macrobius telleth in the ≈øeconde of his Saturnalia, Macrob. that when Augu≈øtus returned from the Acticane victory: amonge tho≈øe that went to gratulate his returne, ther was one which caried a Chough whome he had taught to ≈øay: God ≈øaue thee Cae≈øar our Empe. vanquisher of Antonius &: being likewi≈øe ≈øaluted by a Parrat, hee willed y‚Ä¢ they ≈øhould both bebought. And wondring at the ≈øame in a Pie, commaunded that to bee bought al≈øo. Which thing a poore Cobler b√©eholding, taught a Crowe to ≈øpeake in the ≈øame maner. And b√©eing ouercharged with co≈øt, and ≈ø√©eing that his birde would not an≈øwere, was woont to ≈øay often, all my labour is lo≈øt, all my labour is lo≈øt. But at length when the birde had perfectly learned the ≈øalutacion: h√©e offred her vnto the Emperour, who an≈øwered that h√©e had already enow ≈øutch Birdes at home, which ≈øaluted him after that ≈øort. Then the Crowe by chaunce remeÃÑbring the other ≈øpeach which his Mai≈øter, mi≈øtru≈øtinge his docility, had often times vttred: b√©egan to ≈øpeake aloude before the Emperour ≈øaying: I haue lo≈øt my labour, I haue lo≈øt my labour, wherat Cae≈øar laughed, and commaunded him to b√©e bought likewi≈øe.

div.head: Chap. 17. Of Ritch men.
div.p:
Aemelius. AEMilius Probatus in his booke, of Captaines of forrein Nacions, telleth a ≈øtorie of the Princes ≈øunne of Athens, how meruelous liberall h√©e was, who hauinge fermes and grainges in many places of the cuntrey: hee neuer put anye k√©epers ouer his corne or frutes, but ≈øuffred euery man to take what h√©e li≈øt, his ≈øeruants followed him with monie to giue away if any lacked immeadiatly, le≈øt h√©e ≈øhoulde ≈ø√©eme to deney it by deferring it. If hee ≈øaw anye man ill apperrelled, h√©e woould giue him his owne clothes from his backe. Hee alwayes prepared great plenty of meat, that tho≈øe whom h√©e found vnbidden in the ≈øtr√©ets, he mighte haue them all home vnto his hou≈øe, which hee did euery day and mi≈ø≈øed not. His credite, his helpe, his goods, neuer was failinge to any that had neede. He encritched many, and buried many poore
folke of his owne co≈øt. Cecilius Balbus of ye Philo≈øophers toies,Cecili. bal. reporteth that Agathocles kinge of Sicilia ≈øaid, that a man ought to v≈øe plate of gold as h√©e would cuppes of clay, for it is far more better to ≈øhine in good maners, then in ritches. He v≈øed at his meales to dine and ≈øuppe in earthen ve≈ø≈øels, and on a time when one demaunded of him the cau≈øe, h√©e an≈øwered in this ≈øort:
Of Sicil though I now bee Kinge, a Potter was my ≈øier.
Who≈øo to ritch and high e≈øtate ≈øhalt happen to a≈øpire,
Ari≈øing eft from ba≈øe degree: v≈øe fortune reuerently,
And call to minde what was thy ≈øtate beefore thou ro≈øe ≈øo by.
And therfore this kinge con≈øidering the ba≈øenes of his parentage, was content to f√©ede in earthen ve≈ø≈øel as other poore men are.

Valerius in his third booke, and fift chapter,Valerius reporteth that Marcus Curius, at what time the Amba≈ø≈øadours of the Samnites came to ≈øpeake with him, bid that they ≈øhould come into him, wher they founde him ≈øittinge vpon an euell fauoured fourme, very homely. Who merueiling at his pouerty, and deliuering vnto him a great ≈øumme of Mony which they de≈øiered him to accepte and to v≈øe it at his n√©ede and plea≈øure:Marc. Cu. h√©e refu≈øed it, willing them to tell the Samnites, yt Mar. Curius had rather rule ouer ritch men, then be ritch him≈øelf. And remember this, (quod hee) that I can neyther bee ouercome in batteill, nor corrupted with monie. The ≈øame aucthour likewi≈øe telleth of Frabricius, who was greater then any man in all the City in honour and aucthoritye, and match with the poore≈øt in wealth and reuenue, who al≈øo ≈øent backe vnto the Samnites many great giftes, in who≈øe tuition and charge they were. Hee was ritch without mony, and kept a great family, for why, it made him ritch not to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe mutch, but to de≈øier ≈øufficient.

div.head: Chap. 18. Of Poore men.
div.p:
FRontinus in his fourth booke & fir≈øt chapter telleth how that Scipio after ye hee had atchiued notable exploits in Spaine, Frontinus.
writeth, that according vnto a law made by Seleucus again≈øt adultrie, his ≈øunne, who was apprehended in the ≈øame, ≈øhould haue lo≈øt both his eies. And when the whole City for the honour and duty which they bare to the father, deured that the puni≈øhment might bee remitted, long time refu≈øing to b√©e intreated, but at length relenting at the peoples ≈øute, fir≈øt putting out one of his owne eies, and next one of his ≈øunnes: notwith≈øtanding fulfilled the whole puni≈øhment, deuiding him≈øelfe, as it were, beetw√©ene a mercifull father, and a iu≈øt iudge.

In Policratus the fift booke, and ≈øecond chap. it is ≈øet down, that when on a time there aro≈øe a certen controuer≈øie b√©etweene King Alexander and certen of his ≈øouldiours,Policra. and the kinge had the foyle in the field iudgment: h√©e thankefully accepted the iudgment, and gaue great thankes to the iudges, who≈øe faith hee had experimented in preferring iu≈øtice, b√©efore the re≈øpect of any Potentate.

div.head: Chap. 23. Of Lawiers.
div.p:
AVlus Gellius in his Nightes of Athens, telleth an hi≈øtorie of a young man,Aul. Geli. who cumming to Pithagoras to be in≈øtructed in eloquence, promi≈øed him a great ≈øumme of mony for his paine to bee payd that day, when hee fir≈øt pleaded cau≈øe beefore the Judges and obtained it. But when hee had well profited in the art, and would take the handlinge of no cau≈øes vpon him: Pithagoras conuented him beefore the iudges, ≈øaying vnto him, now will I haue my reward, whether ≈øentence go with thee or again≈øt thee. For if ≈øentence go on ≈øhy ≈øide, then my rewarde is due: and if it go again≈øte thee, then is it due al≈øo, for haue I iudgment on my ≈øide. The ‚Ä¢ an≈øwered the ≈øchollar, vnder≈øtand this mutch Mai≈øter (quod hee) if ≈øentence go on my ≈øide then owe I nothinge vnto you by vertue of the ≈øentence: and if it go again≈øt mee, then by our bargaine I owe you nothing bicau≈øe I preueill not, and am not well taught. Which controuer≈øie the iudges perceiuing to bee very litigious, and doubtfull, deferred the Matter
vnto a very long day, ≈øo that I iudge the ca≈øe is not yet di≈øcu≈ø≈øed.Helinand. Heylinandus in his ≈øecond booke of the in≈øtitucion of Princes, telleth how on a time Demo≈øthenes demaunded of Ari≈øtodius what reward hee had receiued to ≈øpeake, who an≈øwered, a Talent: and I, (quod Domo≈øthenes,) had a more to hould my peace. Thus a man may ≈øee that ≈øome Lawiers tungues may do hurt vnle≈ø≈øe they b√©e tied with a ≈øiluer chein, and many times they ≈øell a≈øwel their ≈øilence, as their words. Valerius writeth in the ≈øeuenth booke and third chapter,Valerius. howe that two men which were gea≈øtes in a hou≈øe, brought certen mony and deliuered it vnto the goodwife with this promi≈øe, that ≈øhee ≈øhould deliuer it againe vnto them both togither. And a good while after, the one of them came and deceiued the woman, requiringe the monie, and ≈øayinge that his fellowe was dead, which ≈øhe foorth with deliuered. Not long after the other came al≈øo, and demauÃÑded the mony. Wherat the poore woman beeing in di≈øtre≈ø≈øe: made the oratour Demo≈øthenes of her coun≈øel, who made this an≈øwere in her behalf. My friend (quod hee) this woman is redy to tender the mony, but ≈øhee may not pay it to you vnle≈ø≈øe your fellow come with you, for as you ≈øay, this was the agreement beetweene you, that it ≈øhuld not bee payd to the one of you without the other.

Cecilius Balbus in the place beefore recited,Ceci. Bal. telleth of an auncient ≈øouldiour of Rome, who on a time being in ≈øome daunger beefore the iudges, bee≈øought Cae≈øar to come avrode into the court to helpe him. Vnto whom Cae≈øar appointed a good lawier. Then the ≈øouldiour ≈øaid, (O Cae≈øar quod hee) when thou wa≈øt in danger in the A≈øiane warre I ≈øought not a deputy, but I fought my≈øelf for thee, and there with all hee di≈øcouered vnto him the ≈økarres of the woundes which hee had receiued there for him. Immediatly Cae≈øar ≈øprang foorth and came to helpe him, fearing le≈øt he might ≈øeeme not ≈øo mutch proud, as vnthankefull.

div.head: Chap. 24. Of great mens Bailiffes.
div.p:
IO≈øephus in the thirtenth booke and twelueth chapter of Antiquities,Io≈øephus. writeth how that the Emperour Tyberius was
≈øumwhat hard and waiward in all his bu≈øines and affaires, and looke what Receiuers hee had appointed in Prouinces, hee ≈øeldome or neuer changed them. And beinge demaunded why hee did ≈øo: hee an≈øwered, bicau≈øe hee ≈øpared the poore people. For if the Receiuers knewe that they ≈øhoulde haue their office but ≈øhort time, then would they ≈øucke vntill the blood folowed, and how mutch the ≈øhorter time they ≈øhoulde bee in office: ≈øo much the more intollerable they would deale, and they that came new would de≈øtroy all that they founde. Which ≈øaying of his, hee confirmed by the example of a man that lay wounded by the way, in the Summer ≈øea≈øon, and would not haue the flies driuen away which were about the wounde. And one which came vpon the way, ≈øuppo≈øing that of weaknes hee had let them alone: draue them away. Ah, (≈øayd he) you haue done ill, for the≈øe flies were now full of blood and troubled mee but litle, and the fre≈øhe ones whiche come will ≈øting mee more ≈øharpely. Euen ≈øo new appoynted officers do pinche the commons more eagerly.

Ari≈øtotle. Ari≈øtotle in the Secretes of Secrets, writeth in this wi≈øe vnto Alexander: Neuer ≈øet ≈øutch a Bailiffe to rule in anye place which wil bee corrupted with mony, for in ≈øo doinge thou ≈øhalt ≈øubuert thy realmes, and bee≈øides thou can≈øt repo≈øe no a≈ø≈øurance in ≈øutch a one as gapeth after trea≈øure, and commodity. For hee ≈øerueth thee for the golde, and giueth vp his ≈øences vnto mony, and by pouling of others: ≈øeeketh to fill vp vp his bottomle≈ø≈øe bagges. And looke how mutch his mony increa≈øeth ≈øo mutch the loue therof groweth, and perhaps the loue of mony may induce him to ye de≈øtruction of thy ≈øelfe, and thy kingdome. And ≈øhortly after in the ≈øame place, hee ≈øetteth downe fift√©ene conditions generally to bee required when wee would get, or choo≈øe a Bailiffe. The ≈øame Aucthour likewi≈øe in ye ≈øecond booke of his Rethorickes, prouing that Procuratours, Rent gatherers, Bailiffes & Receauers ought not vpon ≈ømall occa≈øion to be chaunged, wher hee v≈øeth for proofe E≈øops fable of the wounded Foxe goinge vpon the way, and the flies which ≈øate vpon him and ≈øucked his blood.
Then the Vrcheon comming by, & mooued with compa≈ø≈øion would haue driuen them away. To whom ≈øaid the Fox, do not ≈øo I pray you, for the≈øe are now full of blood, and if new ≈øhould come they would mole≈øt mee more, as new Bailiffes and Stuewards doo.

div.head: Chap. 25. Of Frindes, and Frindship.
div.p: VAlerius in the fourth booke and fourth chapter,Valerius writeth of a paier of frindes, called Damon and Pithias, which were ≈øo faithfully linked in frind≈øhip, that when Di ‚Ä¢ ni≈øius the tyrant would haue put one of them to death, and had giuen him re≈øpite before h√©e died to go home and di≈øpo≈øe his goods in order, the other of them doubted not to y√©elde his life in pleadge for his frinde. And when the day of his returne approched, and h√©e was not yet came, euery man condemned this fooli≈øh ≈øuerty, of folly. Howbeit h√©e ≈øayd, that h√©e doubted nothing of his frindes con≈øtancy. But at the verie ≈øame houer and moment when his friend ≈øhould haue died in his ≈øt√©ede, h√©e came and offred him≈øelf ‚Ä¢ to death. Who≈øe frind≈øhip and con≈øtancy the tyrant wondring at: forgaue the puni≈øhment, and moreouer reque≈øted them to let him bee the third frind, and to receiue him into their con≈øtant band of amity.

Likewi≈øe the ≈øame Aucthour in the fift booke and ninth chapter, reporteth how that one Pretolius denyinge the reque≈øt of a certen frinde of his, why then, quod his frind what n√©ede haue I of thy frind≈øhip? Nay, (quod Pretolius) what n√©ede haue I of thine, if I mu≈øt do a di≈øh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e≈øt d√©ede for th√©e? Tullie in his Booke of frind≈øhip writeth ‚Ä¢ y‚Ä¢ when Tarquinius the proud was expul≈øed out of his kingdome, h√©e then vnder≈øtoode who were his tru≈øty frinds, and who vntru≈øti, when he could neither b√©e √©euen with them, nor requite their benefits.

Seneca al≈øo in the ≈øecond of one of his woorkes,Seneca. writeth yt the philo≈øopher Arthe≈øius had two frindes, a poore man, and one that was ≈øicke, but both of them for ≈øhamefa≈øtnes ≈øake, di≈ø≈øeÃÑ bled their frind≈øhippe. Whiche thinge when the Philo≈øopher vnder≈øtood: h√©e thought ye h√©e ought to ≈øuccour them with out ≈øhamefa≈øtnes, and that with ≈øp√©ede. He priuely put a bag
of mony vnder one of their Pillowes, the other not knowing thereof, that laying a≈øide all fooli≈øhe and vnprofitable ≈øhamefa≈øtnes, his frinde might ≈ø√©eme rather to finde that which h√©e wanted, then to receiue that which h√©e a≈øked.

div.head: Chap. 26. Of Kinsfolkes.
div.p: Valerius. VAlerius writeth in the fir≈øt booke and fir≈øt chapter, that in the old time men were woont to make ≈øolemne fea≈øts, which they called Cari≈øtia, whereat were none pre≈øent but kin≈øfolke and alies, that if chance there were any controuer≈øie or breatch b√©etw√©ene any of them at that ≈øolemnitye, in that time of making mery, the matter might b√©e propo≈øed, and heard, and frindly ended.

Likewi≈øe h√©e writeth in the eight booke, that wheÃÑ Decius the Generall or Emperour for the time, would haue ≈øet the imperial Diademe vpon his ≈øun Decius head, h√©e refu≈øed it, ≈øaying, I feare mee lea≈øt when I am Emperour I leaue to be a ≈øun, rather let my father haue the gouernment, and let it b√©e my dignity to be obedient vnto him.

Moreouer in the fift booke and fift chapter, hee telleth of Ce≈øetius‚ñ™ who beeing commaunded by Cae≈øar, the conquerour both of all abroade, and at hom, to bani≈øhe his ≈øunne for that h√©e had mini≈øtred ≈øome occa≈øion of di≈øtru≈øte that hee affected the kingdome, an≈øwered him ≈øaying: truly Cae≈øar (quod hee) thou ≈øhalt ≈øooner take all my ≈øunnes from m√©e, then I will ≈øend away one of them at thy commaundement. S√©e what great bouldnes this was, that h√©e would not y√©eld vnto him to whom all the world was in ≈øubiection. Likewi≈øe the ≈øame aucthour in the fourth chapter writeth, that on a time the Praetor deliuered a malifactour, which was a woman, borne of a good family, vnto the Jailer to b√©e executed in the pri≈øon, who b√©eing mooued with compa≈ø≈øion towards the woman, put her not to death immediatly, but gaue leaue vnto her daughter to come vnto her, lookinge vnto her that ≈øhee ≈øhould bring her mother no foode, to thintent hee might kill her by famine. And when certein daies were pa≈øt, merueyling how ≈øhe liued ≈øo long, in the ende h√©e perceiued how the
louing daughter reliued her mothers hunger with the milke of her bre≈øts, which ≈øtrange fact being reported to the Coun≈øell, procured the womans pardon. For what will not loue & duty finde out? and what is ≈øo rare to be ≈ø√©ene, as the daughter to giue the mother ≈øuck? A man would thinke that it were again≈øt nature, vnle≈ø≈øe it were the fir≈øt and principall lawe of nature, to loue our parentes.

div.head: chap. 27. Of good Weemen
div.p:
A Good Woman ought fir≈øt of all, to ≈øet light by temporall goodes: touching which poinct Valerius, Valerius. in the fourth booke and fir≈øt chapter telleth the ≈øtory of Cornelia, which was mother vnto ye Gracchi: the ≈øame vpon a time receiued into her hou≈øe of ge≈øtred a gentlewomaÃÑ of Campania, who ≈øhewed her very beutifull Jewels and ornaments, which ≈øhe had in ≈øtore made according to the fa≈øhion in tho≈øe daies, but ≈øhe gaue her a quip for it: For when her children came home from ≈øchoole, and al the≈øe be my iewels & ornaments, quoth Cornelia. For truly, who ≈øo coueteth nothing, hath althing, & in greater a≈ø≈øuraunce then he that hath mutch goods in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. And ≈øince worldly goods are but ca≈øuall, yet are the vertues of ye minde ≈øutch as are ≈øubiect vnto no mi≈øaduentures of Fortune. Secondly ≈øhe ought to ouercome all carnall de≈øire.Oro≈øius. Touching which poinct, Oro≈øius writeth in his fift Booke, that when the Germanes were ouercome by Marius, their weemen with a more con≈øtant courage then if they had bin the conquerours, de≈øired the Con≈øul that he would ≈øaue their virgins liues vppon condition yt they might pre≈øerue their cha≈øtyty, and be re≈øerued to mini≈øter vnto the Gods. But when they could not obtaine ≈øo much of him: they da≈øhed the braines of their yong children again≈øt the ≈øtones and hanged them≈øelues.Vale. Thirdly ≈øhe ought to pre≈øerue her loyaltie, & the tokens of her goodwill towards her hu≈øband, whereof Valerius writeth in his fourth booke and fift chapter, that at what time the Spartanes kepte certen Lacedemonians in pri≈øon, whom they deteined there to put them to death, their wiues being w√©emen of noble blood, came thither, and de≈øiring to ≈øpeake with their hu≈øbands before
they were executed: obtained licence of the Gailer to go into the Pri≈øon vnto them. And when they were gone in they exchanged their apparel with their hu≈øbands, and ≈øo the men departed out of the pri≈øon in their wiues atyre, muffled, as though they had couered their faces for grief & heauines. Moreouer a woman ought to geue her hu≈øband good coun≈øell.

Seneca.The like example as touchyng the force herof, is by Seneca ≈øet foorth, ≈øhewyng yt when Augu≈øtus the Emperour of Rome bethought him how he might reuenge him≈øelf on one whiche ≈øought his death, the Empre≈ø≈øe adui≈øed him that he ≈øhould follow the trade of all good Phi≈øitions, who ≈ø√©eyng that they can not preuayle with Medicines of the ≈øame qualitie with the di≈øea≈øe, apply the contrary. Wherfore ≈øayd ≈øhe, ≈ø√©eynge that you cannot preuayle by ≈øeueritie, proue to win by gentlenes, which h√©e did willyngly, and tooke effect.

div.head: Chap. 28. Of wicked Women.
div.p:
Oro≈øius. ORo≈øius in his fir≈øt booke of the woork before alleaged, ≈øetteth it downe, that when Ninus kyng of the A≈ø≈øyrians was dead his wife and Qu√©ene Semiramis reygned in his ≈øt√©ede, blouddely embruing the kyngdome with ≈ølaughter the ≈øpace of .xly. y√©eres. The ≈øame burnyng in lu≈øt, and thir≈øtyng bloud, amoÃÑg ≈øo many horrible murders and abominable whoredomes, hauyng quatted her gr√©edy de≈øier with ≈øo many whori≈øh deui≈øes and ≈øtrange maners of couplyng, at length hauyng conceaued a ≈øonne by ≈øhamefull dealyng, and nouri≈øhing him vp by vngodly meanes, and hauing had with him ince≈øtious medling, ≈øhe ≈øought to couer her priuate ≈øhame with publique wickedne≈ø≈øe. For ≈øhe gaue forth in coÃÑmaundement that there ≈øhould be no ≈øutch reuerence nor re≈øpect betw√©ene parents and children, nor no di≈øcretion v≈øed in taking of wiues or ob≈øeruinge of matrimonie, but in that point it ≈øhould be lawfull for euery man and woman to take whom they lu≈øted. S. Ierome wryting again≈øt Iouinianus, S. Ieaom. reporteth that the wife of Sylla was a common woman, or as they terme them a good fellow. And likewi≈øe Pompeius that ouercame welnigh the whole world,
had an incontinent Lady to his wife.Cato Cato al≈øo which was called Cen≈øorinus, married a very baggage of a meane parentage, yet was ≈øhe a ≈øhrew and a whore, and that more ≈øtrange is, proud and ≈øaucy to her Lord and hu≈øband.

Iu≈øtinus the abridger of Torgus Pompeus writeth,Iu≈øtinus. that when Grippus which was ≈øun to Deme. had recouered his Fathers dominions, & had quite ended al forrein dangers, he was afterward a≈ø≈øaulted by ye trea≈øon of his owne gr√©edy mother. Who for the de≈øire that ≈øhee had to reigne hauing betrayed one of her ≈øunnes and by that horible d√©ede puttinge of all motherly affection, ≈øuppo≈øed now that her dignitie and honour was mutch emba≈øed by the conque≈øt and renowme of her other child. Wherefore vpon a time ≈øhe watched opportunity, and preparing a cup of deadly poy≈øon, pre≈øented him therewith when he came hot and thir≈øty from exerci≈øe. But her attempt tooke contrary effect. For Grippus, as it were offeringe dutyfull courte≈øie to his mother, de≈øired her to begin vnto hym. At the la≈øt he vrged her ≈øo far, that he found out great proofes of her purpo≈øe, wherewith the Qu√©ene b√©eing ouercome, and turning the mi≈øcheif vnto her ≈øelf, died with the poy≈øoned potion which ≈øhe had prouided for her ≈øunne.

div.head: Chap. 29 Of maried Weemen.
div.p: ∆≤Alerius writeth in the fourth booke and third Chapter,Valerius. that when Iulia, who was daughter vnto Cae≈øar & wife to Pompeius the great, beehelde her Lorde and Hu≈øbandes Gowne brought home all bloody out of the f√©elde, beinge ≈øtroken with ≈øudden feare that ≈øome violence had befallen vnto him, fell downe in a ≈øwonde and was delyuered of Childe beefore her time, not with out great lo≈ø≈øe and detriment of the whole Empire.

And Cecilius Balbus in the place before recited,Cecili. bal‚ñ™ writeth a ≈øtorie of a certen man who≈øe name was Damelius, to whom a companion of his obiected that he had a ≈øtinking breath. TheÃÑ departed he home vnto his Wife di≈øcontented, & chiding with her for not telling him therof before. TheÃÑ his wife ≈øaid ≈øurely
I would haue done ≈øo (quod ≈øhe) but yt I thought that al men ‚Ä¢ breathes had ≈ømelt in that ≈øorte, and therfore very like it is that ≈øhee had neuer ioyned her mouth vnto any other mans.

Valerius. Valerius al≈øo writeth in the ≈øixt booke, and third chapter, of Tercia Emilia the wife of Scipio African, who≈øe ≈øinguler good will and pacience toward her hu≈øband was ≈øo great, that perceininge that her Lorde bare good affection vnto one of her Handmaides: ≈øhe di≈ø≈øembled the matter and would not ≈øee it, for that ≈øhe would not ≈ø√©eme to ≈øu≈øpect or blame her Lorde of incontinency, or to moue him to impaciencie which was conquerour of the worlde. Yea after her Hu≈øbands decea≈øe, ≈øhee made her handmaid fr√©e, and be≈øtowed her in mariadge with one of her fr√©e men.

Lykewi≈øe Sulpitia was mo≈øt diligently kept by her mother Iulia, becau≈øe ≈øh√©e ≈øhould not follow her hu≈øband Lentulus into Italy, who was pro≈øcribed and condemned to dye. Howbeit ≈øhe chaunged her atire, and put one the garment of a ≈øeruaunt, and taking with her two Handmaides, and two men, ≈øtole away ≈øecretly vnto him, not refu≈øing to bani≈øh her ≈øelfe, that her faith might be knowne to her condemned hu≈øband.

div.head: Chapter. 30. Of good widowes.
div.p: THe word Vidua which ≈øignifieth a Widow, ≈øoundeth as it were Diui≈øa, that is to ≈øay, one that is deuided and parted fom her Hu≈øband. And Valerius writeth in the fir≈øt booke & fir≈øt chap. that in the old time tho≈øe w√©emen yt were contented with one hu≈øband & once marrying, were crowned wt a Garland of cha≈øtyty, ≈øuppo≈øing that the ta≈øting of many and often wedlockes, was a token of a certen kinde of intemperancy.

Ierom.Saint Ierome in his woorke again≈øt Iouinianus reporteth that when Catoes Daughter had mourned foure w√©ekes for the death of her Hu≈øband, a certen Matron demaunded of her when ≈øhe would make an ende of mourning? who an≈øwered, when ≈øhe made an ende of lyuing.

Likewi≈øe ye ≈øame Aucthour in his booke de Anima, writeth o ‚Ä¢ her, that when on a time a frind of hers per≈øwaded her to
marry another hu≈øband ≈øince ≈øhe was yet but young, and her beuty fre≈øh & flouring: ≈øhe an≈øwered that ≈øhe would not: For, ≈øaid ≈øhe, if I chance to finde as good an hu≈øbaÃÑd as I had before, I will not ≈øtand in feare to l√©e≈øe him: but if hee bee √©euel, what n√©ede I to trouble my≈øelf with ≈øutch an one? And agayne in the ≈øame place, when one in the pre≈øence of Porcia, pray≈øed a certen woman which had buried one hu≈øband and Married the ≈øecond, ≈øhe an≈øwered, that a good and an hone≈øt woman neuer marrieth but once. And ≈øemblably Valeria which was ≈øi≈øter vnto the Me≈ø≈øalas, after the decea≈øe of her Hu≈øbande would neuer marry agayn, and b√©eing demaunded the cau≈øe, ≈øhe an≈øwered that her hu≈øband alwaies liued vnto her. Arthemi≈øia al≈øo which was Qu√©ene and wife vnto Mau≈øolus kinge of Caria, although in re≈øpect of her fidility towards her hu≈øbands ≈øh√©e bee ≈øingularly commended, yet is ≈øhe mo≈øt pray≈øed for that ≈øhee loued her Hu≈øbande alwayes as deerely when hee was dead, as if hee had bin liuing: and in the honour of him ≈øhee builded a mo≈øt bewtyfull and renowmed Sepulcher, in ≈øo mutch that thereof all greate and ≈øumptuous Sepulchers are called Mau≈øolea, that is to ≈øay, like Mau≈øolus monument.

div.head: Chap. 31. Of Virgins.
div.p:
COncerning Virgins, Saint Ierome writeth again≈øt Iouinianus, that it appeareth in how great honour virgins were had among the people of Rome, for a≈ømutch as Con≈øuls and generalles of Armes ≈øitting in their triumphat chariots wheÃÑ they returned home with conque≈øt ouer their enemies, and finally all kinde of degrees were accu≈øtomed in meetinge them, go out of the way, and giue them place. Nichanor when hee had ouercome and ≈øubuerted the City of Thebes, was taken in the loue of a captiue virgin. And de≈øiringe her imbracinges and company in the commendable lawe of wedlocke, which thing a captiue might well haue liked of, hee found by triall that vnto cha≈øt mindes virginity is more deare then a kingdome. Whom the louer when ≈øhee was ≈ølayne held in
his owne hand, lamenting his owne greif, and her mo≈øt mi≈øerable condition.Seneca. Seneca in his ≈øixt booke of declamacions reporteth that a ve≈øtale virgin wrote the≈øe ver≈øes folowing:
O happy married wiues, your life is fraught with ioy,
For that I may not ta≈øte your ≈øtate, I die in great anoy.
Again≈øt which, there was alleaged an an≈øwere in this ≈øort:
As one that tried ha≈øt a man, thou yeelde≈øt vp the gho≈øt,
Or die≈øt bicau≈øe thou art denide the thing thou couet≈øt mo≈øt,
both which thinges ought to b√©e farthe≈øt from a woman of that cote. For vnto th√©e the Magi≈øtrates do ca≈øt downe their faces in token of reuerence, vnto th√©e the Con≈øuls and Pretors giue the vpper hande in the ≈øtr√©etes, and it is no ≈ømall callinge to bee both a virgin and a prie≈øt: and that which hath bin ≈øpoken with ≈øo great affection that it ≈øeemed to proc√©ede froÃÑ the very hark & intrailes mu≈øt needes bee true, that what woman ≈øoeuer wi≈øheth the act, euen without the act doing is an harlot.Valerius. Valerius in the ≈øeuenth booke and third chapter, writeth of a certen ve≈øtale virgine in Rome called Tuccia, who≈øe cha≈øtity beeing ob≈øcured with a ≈øini≈øter report of incontinency, and ≈øhee her ≈øelfe beeing priuy of her owne innocency, tooke into her handes a ≈øiue, and thus prayed vnto the godde≈ø≈øe Ve≈øta, ≈øaying: Ve≈øta, if I haue alwayes touched thy ≈øacrifices with cha≈øte and vndefiled hands, commaund that I may take water out of the riuer Tyber with this Siue, and cary it into thy Temple. Which indeede ≈øhee accompli≈øhed, the common cour≈øe of Nature giuing place to her boulde attemptes.

S. Ierom.Likewi≈øe Saint Ierome in the place b√©efore alleaged, writeth of another ve≈øtale virgin named Claudia, who b√©einge ≈øu≈øpected that ≈øh√©e had playd the harlot, and at that pre≈øente the Image of the mother of the Gods ≈øtuck fa≈øt in the Oa≈øe of Tyber in a ≈øhippe, to giue example therfore of her integrity, it is reported how ≈øhee tied her girdle vnto the ≈øhippe and that ≈øh√©e drew it ≈øo away, more theÃÑ many thou≈øand men were able to accompli≈øh.

And, Saynt Augu≈øtine in his woorke de ciuitate Dei, s. Augu≈øt‚ñ™ writeth that the antient Romanes were wount to bury aliue the ve≈øtale virgins that were corrupted, and what≈øoeuer other W√©emen were taken in adultrye, they were one way or another puni≈øhed, but none were put to death: ≈øuppo≈øinge it m√©ete to puni≈øh more ≈øeuerely the breach of a deuine vowe, then of humane cha≈øtity. And thus as I iudge I haue runne ouer all ≈øortes of men with whom a man may happen to b√©e conuer≈øant with all at the table.

div.head: ¬∂The third Booke of Table Phylo≈øophy, which containeth certen delectable and plea≈øant Que≈øtions, to be propounded while wee be at meate, or at any other time.
The Preface.
div.p:
NOw, ≈øince we haue already breifly intreated concerning the manners and behauiour of tho≈øe, with whom wee may chaunce to be accompanied at the table, next it remaineth that with like breuity we run ouer certen plea≈øant que≈øtions of table talke. For as witne≈ø≈øeth Macrobius in his fir≈øt booke of Saturnalia: A well nurtered minde cannot ≈øolace it felfe with more profit or ≈øeemelines, then in taking opportunity to di≈øpute and demaund que≈øtions after a learned and vertuous manner, and if neede be to an≈øwer with courte≈øy, and men cannot que≈øtion of any thing with greater delight then of matters of learning. And therfore as ≈øaieth, the ≈øame Macrobius in the third booke, the fir≈øt thing which we ought to ob≈øerue at the table is to weigh the e≈øtimation
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
and callinge of euery gea≈øt, and the next to take occa≈øion when he ≈øeeth it offred to ≈øpeake, not to poure forth our own ≈øecretes amonge the cuppes, neither yet to mini≈øter crabbed and vnplea≈øant talke, but rather profitable and delight≈øome Que≈øtions.

div.head: ¬∂The fir≈øt Chapter containing fiue ≈øeuerall Que≈øtions.
div.p:
FIr≈øt therefore and foremo≈øt, this may bee demaunded: whether that the Aier or Meate bee more nece≈ø≈øarie for the pre≈øeruation of the lyfe of Manne? And it ≈ø√©emeth of the twayne that Meate is more nece≈ø≈øary, ≈øince that is more nece≈ø≈øarie whiche ≈øupplyeth that ≈øub≈øtaunce whiche is lo≈øt, and whiche may be a member or part of a member of the bodie,Auicen. Con≈øtan. of whiche nature is our Meate according to the a≈ø≈øertion of Auicen. But indeede Con≈øtantinus is of the contrary opinion, sayinge, that Aier is more nece≈ø≈øary, to the body, prouing the ≈øame both by Rea≈øon, and experience. By Rea≈øon thus: Life con≈øi≈øteth in naturall heate, becau≈øe naturall heate is the beginninge of lyfe, wherfore that thinge which tempereth naturall heate, retayning it in the naturall temperature is more nece≈ø≈øary, but the Aire which by way of breathinge wee drawe in, is of ≈øutch ≈øort: wh ‚Ä¢ rfore it is more nece≈ø≈øary. By experience thus: If a man be ≈øuddenly brought out of a ≈øtinkinge clo≈øe pri≈øon, fir≈øt he de≈øi ‚Ä¢ eth to take the fre≈øh Aier, and afterwarde calleth for Meate, and Drink. But again≈øt the rea≈øon fir≈øt alleaged it may bee an≈øwered negatiuely, for lyfe con≈øi≈øteth in two points, the one is a beginning ≈øumwhat far of, as re≈øtoringe that which is lo≈øt, and the con≈øeruation of all the members and parts. In re≈øpect of which, the nouri≈øhing of natural heat
is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øarie, whiche is immedyatly and principally maintained by the qualities of the Aire. And therefore Aier is more nece≈ø≈øary to the pre≈øeruacion of lyfe, for that it re≈øpecteth the life principally and immediatly.

Secondly, it may be demaunded which of the two, Meate, or Drynke, is more nece≈ø≈øarie vnto life? To this may bee an≈øwered that Meate is, although that Drinke bee commonly more de≈øired then Meate. The rea≈øon of the fir≈øt is, that that is more nece≈ø≈øary which re≈øtoreth the thinge whiche is lo≈øt, then that which ≈øerueth onely to conuey the iuce about al the body. But Meate is ordained to re≈øtore the parts, and Drink to cary the meate about the body: wherfore the conclu≈øion is manyfe≈øt. And that Drink is more gr√©edely de≈øiered: the rea≈øon is, for that drink delayeth the vehemency of natural heat, in which re≈øpect it is more nece≈ø≈øary vnto lyfe then Meate, as is ye Aier al≈øo. Thus Drinke hath two offices, fir≈øt it conueieth the Meate vnto all partes of the body, and ≈øo is Meate a thing more nece≈ø≈øary then drink. Secondly, it mitigateth the naturall heate, and pre≈øerueth it in the iu≈øt temperature, and is therby more nece≈ø≈øarie then meate. Wherfore any lyuinge creature can longer liue without meate, then drinke.

Thirdly, this que≈øtion may be demaunded: Wether euel Aier or euell Meate do more hurt the bodye? Whereunto it may be ab≈øolutely an≈øwered, that √©euell Aier hurteth more, for, that it is more noi≈øome vnto the hart, which is the fowntaine of Naturall heat, and of the ≈øpirites. Howbeit wee may v≈øe a di≈øtinction herein, that a thinge may do harme after diuers manner of wayes. Fyr≈øt, if it touche ≈øome noble and princypall part, and the other thing do not ≈øo. Secondly, if it alter it often times and it cannot otherwi≈øe be avoyded. Thirdly, if it touch it immediatly. And by the≈øe three meanes √©euill Aier hurteth more then √©euell Meate. For it toucheth a principall parte, and it is often drawne in, and it toucheth the part immediatly. Fourthly, a thinge may hurte the more, becau≈øe it maketh a ≈øtronge impre≈ø≈øion. Fiftly, if it continnue there longe, and cleaue longe time vnto the
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ber. And by the≈øe la≈øt meanes, corrupt meate eaten a
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ more then naughtie Aier drawne in.

‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ urthly, this demaund may be moued: Whether Meate ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ pe do more comfort the bodye? It may bee an≈øwered, „Äà‚óä„Äâ lack of Meat doth more gr√©eue the body then lack of ≈øl√©ep, and therby concluded that Meat is more nece≈ø≈øary then ≈øl√©ep. And the rea≈øon is this, for ye ≈øl√©epe re≈øtoreth not that which is lo≈øt, neither appea≈øeth the vehemency of natural heate from woorking vpon the natural moi≈øture, which being con≈øumed, then death is at ye dore, which meat doth: wherfore it is more nece≈ø≈øary. Moreouer, there be thr√©e powers, the Vitall, Naturall, and Animall. The Animall is not ≈øo mutch appertayning vnto the ≈øub≈øtaunce and effecte of lyfe, as the other two are. Wherfore, nutriment which belongeth vnto the Natural and Vitall faculties: is more n√©edefull then ≈øl√©epe, which belongeth vnto the Animall vertue onely.

Fiftly, it may come into que≈øtion: whether the Aier or Meat do more nourish the body? Vnto this may b√©e an≈øwered, that there is ≈øome kinde of Nutriment which goeth into the ≈øub≈øtance of that which is Nouri≈øhed, and is conuerted in to the ≈øame, and after this maner the mo≈øt fine≈øt and ≈øubtile≈øt partes of the meate is nutriment vnto the ≈øpirits, and not the Aier. Secondly, a thinge may bee termed a nutriment vnto the ≈øpirites, becau≈øe it comforteth them, and thus wee call that the temperature or temperameÃÑt of any thing which pre≈øerueth the ≈øame and nouri≈øheth it, hauing ≈øome proportion with that which is nouri≈øhed. And in this manner, Aier nouri≈øheth the ≈øpirites, refre≈øhinge, and pre≈øeruing them in their naturall temperature. And this mutch concerning this Que≈øtion.

div.head: The ≈øecond Chapter containinge 12. Que≈øtions.
div.p:
THe ≈øixt Que≈øtion mooueth this demaunde: Whether euell Meate can ingender good iuce? And accordinge vnto the opinion of Haly ≈øuper tegni, Haly. &c. It is an≈øwered that there may bee engendred good blood out of √©euell Meate, & contrarywi≈øe
al≈øo. The rea≈øon is this, good Meate may be √©euelly dige≈øted, and ≈øo therof become √©euell blood. And contrarywi≈øe, naughty meat well dige≈øted, and ≈øo conuerted into good blood. So yt in euery kinde of meat, yea if it were of a venimous qualiti are found two natures. The one, wherein it is vnproportionable vnto the nature of the partes of the body, and by this meanes eeuel meat ingendreth √©euel iuce, and this is the proper effect which √©euel meate worketh. The .y. nature is wherby meats haue the qualitie to become proportionable vnto the partes & like vnto them, and in this ≈øort naughtie meates may ingender good iuce. For when Nature is ≈øtronge, ≈øhe is able to remoue the other qualitie whiche is n√©ere≈øt vnto her, to wit in the ≈øame meate which is receiued, and when it is altered ≈øhe bringeth it vnto her owne qualitie, and ≈øo of √©euel meate engendereth good blood. And contrarywi≈øe, if Nature be weake and feable, ≈øhe is not able to ouercome the meates, & to bring it vnto good effect, which of it ≈øelf is of power to be conuerted into commendable nutriment, & therefore fayling for want: turneth good meate into √©euell iuce.

Seuenthly it may be demaunded: Whether a ≈øimple, or a compowned Meate be ea≈øie≈øt of dige≈øtion? To this wee mu≈øt an≈øwer with Dya≈øanus, Dya≈øanus. as appeareth in ye la≈øt of the Saturnalia that ≈øimple meate is the ea≈øie≈øt. For cruditie and ≈øurfeit commeth two maner of waies, either by the qualitie or quantitie of the meate. By the qualitie, into which the meat is conuerted if it be not agreeable vnto the re≈øt of the humours of ye body, & by ye quantitie therof, if ther be more receiued into ye body then nature is able to dige≈øt. Then, for as much as the diuer≈øitie of meats hath diuer≈øity of Natures, & ≈øome are ≈øoone dige≈øted and conuerted into iuce, whiles the harder lye boylyng in the ≈øtomack: the fir≈øt waxeth ≈øower and vnprofitable and is perceiued by ≈øower & euell ≈øauouring belching, & there whiles that which is harder of concoction procureth gulping, & boyling in ye belly, euen as gr√©ene wood lieth ≈ømoking when it taketh heat of the fire. Be≈øides that, the diuer≈øitie of meats prouoketh gurmandize, & a de≈øire to eate more then enough,
≈øo that Socrates coun≈øelled very wi≈øelye that men ≈øhoulde ab≈øtayne from ≈øutch meates as ≈øeeme to prouoke appetite when the belly is full, or to increa≈øe thir≈øt, when a man hath drunken ≈øufficient.

Eightly, it may b√©e demaunded whether it be good to walk immediatly after meate or not? And hereunto it is to b√©e an≈øwered, that there is two ≈øorts of Motions, or exerci≈øes. The one may b√©e termed a toyle, and that is not good after meate. The other is a kinde of walking either within doores, or abroad downe ≈øum hill,I≈øaac. wherof I≈øaac intreateth, and the ≈øame moderately driueth the me ‚Ä¢ te down vnto the bottome of the ≈øtomack, to the intent that ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ turall heate, which b√©efore was as it were a ≈øl√©epe may bee awakened and ≈øtirred vp, which is requi≈øite after meat.

Ninthly, ≈øome man may demaund whether it bee good to ≈øleepe immediatly after meate or not? wherto I an≈øwere, that ≈øl√©epe is not hol≈øome while the ≈øtomacke is burdeined, for it procureth the meate to b√©e burned,Auicen. as witne≈ø≈øeth Auicen, li ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ as the bread burneth when the Ouen is ouer heated, as al≈øo bicau≈øe it procureth the reume and payne in the head, wherfore mo≈øt expedieÃÑt it were to deferre ≈øl√©eping vntill the meat b√©e departed out of the ≈øtomack.

Tenthly, What is the cau≈øe that if a man ≈øtay lenger for meat then his accu≈øtome houre, hee lee≈øeth his appetite? It mu≈øt b√©e an≈øwered, that when the ≈øtomack hungreth and findeth no meat to worke vpon, it draweth √©euil humours from al parts of the body & feedeth vpon them, and is therby fal≈øly and couÃÑ terfaitly ≈øati≈øfied, and ≈øo de≈øiereth no more, wherfore in this ca≈øe Rha≈øis giueth adui≈øe,Rha≈øis. to drinke a draught of warmewater or ti≈øane, wherby to prouoke the party to vomit if it may b√©e.

Eleuenthly, Are our bodies warmer beefore meat or after? Galen ≈øaith in his ≈øecond booke of the ≈øumme of Phi≈øick,Galen. that naturall heat is augmented thr√©e waies: either in quantity, as in applying ≈øw√©ete and warme furres, or the bellye of a young whelp vnto the ≈øtomack: or in quality by medicines, or ioyntly by both meanes in meates, and by this meanes the
body is warmer after meate then it was before.

Tweluethly: whether doth fa≈øting hurt more a cholerick per≈øon or a flegmatick? I an≈øwere according to Hyppocrates, Hyppocr. that it hurteth mo≈øt a cholerick, the rea≈øon is, for that heate more abouÃÑdeth in a cholerick per≈øons ≈øtomack then in a flegmaticke ≈øo that the ≈øame heat con≈øumeth more, and con≈øequently maketh him more to de≈øire foode. Moreouer, fleame may be turned into blood, but choler can neuer, ≈øo that the flegmatick per≈øon containeth in his body the matter and ≈øub≈øtance of blood, and may therby the better ≈øati≈øfie the appetite. As for the cholericke, he hath in him no ≈øutch mattter, wherfore hunger is more grieuous vnto him then to the flegmatick, as experience in them both proueth to b√©e true.

div.head: The .iii. Chapter, conteinyng. x. que≈øtions.
div.p:
NOw in this que≈øtioÃÑ i ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ alleth out that many are de≈øirous to vnder≈øtand, what should bee the cau≈øe that many men are very hungrie, and looke when they ≈øit downe to their meat, they are immediatly ≈øati≈øfied with a litle. Again, ≈øome haue but ≈ømall appetite, and when they bee ≈øit at their meate, they eate greedely: Whereunto w√©e mu≈øt an≈øwere, that this chanceth according to the diuer≈øity of ≈øtomackes. For ≈øome mens ≈øtomockes are ≈ømall & hot, and in yt the ≈øtomak is hot de≈øireth much, and in that it is ≈ømall the heat di≈øper≈øeth ≈øoone the meat ouer all the capacity therof, and maketh a fanta≈øticall fulnes, ≈øo that litle meat ≈øufficeth ≈øutch. Other ≈øome haue large ≈øtomackes and could, and in that their ≈øtomackes are cold, a litle meat filleth them, but in that their ≈øtomackes are large, they feede much and a long time.

Secondly: which of the twayne, tho≈øe which haue a ≈øtronge heat or a weake, are able longe≈øt to abide hunger? Surely I ≈øuppo≈øe that they which haue the ≈øtronger may fa≈øt longe≈øt, ≈øince for the more part ≈øutch per≈øons are of the ≈øtronger con≈øtitucion. Howbeit this di≈øtinction is to be noted, that there b√©e two poincts to b√©e con≈øidered in fa≈øting, to wit, ye re≈øolution of natural heat, & the vtter quenching of the ≈øame, & the ≈øtroÃÑge≈øt nature is able be≈øt to ≈øu≈øtaine them both. And ≈øecondly, the
di≈øcoÃÑmodities ar to be weighed which en≈øue fa≈øting, of which the ≈øtronge≈øt nature ≈øu≈øtayneth moe then dooth the weake.

Thirdly: how chanceth it that tho≈øe who≈øe powers be ≈ømall and narrowe, can abide honger better then they which haue wider? Bicau≈øe through wide and large pores, the body is more aboundantly re≈øolued, & le≈ø≈øe through the narrowe and ≈ømall pores, wherfore ye remayneth which ≈øhould prouoke appetite.

Fourthly: doth choler nourish or not? vnto this demaunde wee an≈øwere,Galen. I≈øaac. Auicen. that although Galen and I≈øaac ≈øay, that it nouri≈øheth not, bicau≈øe blood onely nouri≈øheth: yet Auicen holdeth opinion that choler nouri≈øheth al≈øo, which two opinions of ≈øingular learned men, we mu≈øt make to agr√©e after this maner. Ther are two ≈øortes of choler, wherof the one, which is conteined within the gall cannot nouri≈øh: the other nece≈ø≈øarely concurreth with the blood, wherwith the partes of the bodye which are of a cholerick con≈øtitution, are as well nouri≈øhed, as the ≈øanguine partes are with the blood.

Fyfthly, whether can the ≈øicke or the whole be≈øt indure hunger? Some hold opinion that the ≈øicke can, bicau≈øe naturall heat in a ≈øicke per≈øon is bu≈øie in re≈øoluing mo fumo≈øities, breathes, and vapours ri≈øing from the humours, then in an whole per≈øon.
