Howbeit this rea≈øon is weake, fir≈øt bicau≈øe there can b√©e no partes nouri≈øhed, nor ≈øpirites engendred by corrupt humours, and ≈øecondly if this were ≈øo, then ≈øhoulde there b√©e moe ≈øpirites in a ≈øicke body then in an whole, and bicau≈øe the ≈øpirits are the carriers of the powers and ≈øtreÃÑgth into althe parts, the ≈øicke ≈øhould b√©e ≈øtronger then the whole, which is euidently fal≈øe. But to growe to the purpo≈øe, w√©e an≈øwere that whereas the ≈øicke tollerateth hunger better then the whole per≈øon, there are thr√©e cau≈øes to b√©e giuen: the fi≈øt is bicau≈øe nature is occupied about the ≈øicknes, and the cau≈øe therof: the ≈øecond, for that the partes of the body are infected and cheaked with the corrupt matter, and therfore do not de≈øire nutriment: and the third is bicau≈øe the ≈øtrength of the ≈øicke party b√©einge, as it were, layd a ≈øl√©epe and weakned, ‚Ä¢ au≈øeth them to haue no appetite vnto meat.

Sixtly, whether in the force of a ≈øtrong or weake ≈øtomacke
be≈øt able to abide hunger? The force of a ≈øtrong ≈øtomack de≈øireth mo≈øt, but it may be≈øt ≈øu≈øtaine forbearing of meate, and contrariwi≈øe the appetite of a weake ≈øtomack looketh le≈ø≈øe for meat, & is not ≈øo well able to abide delay from it.

Seuenthly, which of the twayn is be≈øt able to indure hunger hee that is accu≈øtomed to eate much meat or litle? It may bee an≈øwered that h√©e that v≈øeth to eate much meat may be≈øt fa≈øt for by rea≈øon of his great rauening hee hath but ≈ømall heate, and therfore may be≈øt indure hunger, & ≈øo likewi≈øe contrariwi≈øe, bicau≈øe of the contrary cau≈øe.

Eighthly, whether doth fa≈øting more grieue men in hoate or cold ≈øea≈øons of the yeere? It is more noy≈øome in Summer then in winter, bicau≈øe the body is more re≈øolued in Summer then it is in winter, and therfore ought then to b√©e fead more aboundantly and very often, and in winter it ≈øufficeth to eate once in a day. Ninthely, why are tho≈øe that feede griedie≈øtly ≈øoone≈øt filled? Hereunto w√©e mu≈øt an≈øwere as it is writteÃÑ in the Saturnalia, that they which feede griedely eate in mutch aier with their meat by rea≈øen of their wide gapinge, and often fetchinge of their breath. And therfore when the veines are filled with aier, the appetite is fully ≈øati≈øfied.

Tenthly, wherfore are wee able to abide hoat meates and drinkes in our mouth, which wee cannot for heat ≈øuffer in our handes? w√©e an≈øwere as appeareth in the place b√©efore alleaged, for that the naturall heat which is conteined with in the inner partes of the body is very ≈øharpe and vehement, and therfore it ouercommeth & weakneth what≈øoeuer other hoat ≈øub≈øtance cummeth within the mouth, wherfore then when thou putte≈øt eny extreme hot thing into thy mouth, gape not wide nor fetch not thy breath in ofteÃÑ, thinking therby to coole it, but rather ≈øhut thy lips almo≈øt clo≈øe togither, to ye intent yt the greater heat which cuÃÑmeth out of ye belly, may help the mouth, and that greater heat ouercome the le≈ø≈øer, as for the hand that can abide no hot thing bicau≈øe it is holpen by no other heat then is in it ≈øelf.

div.head: The. 4. chap. conteining. 7. que≈øtions.
div.p: SOme man may haply moue this que≈øtion: what is the cau≈øe that when a man which is hungry drinketh, thereby he a≈ø≈øwageth his hunger? but if hee bee a thir≈øt and eate, his thir≈øt is not therby ≈ølaked? Vnto this demaund there is an≈øwere made in the Saturn‚ñ™ that there is no impediment but that liquor may pa≈ø≈øe into euery part of the body, and repleni≈øhe the veines therof. But the ≈øub≈øtance of meat is more gro≈ø≈øer, and it cannot pa≈ø≈øe into the veines vntil it bee dige≈øted by litle and litle, ≈øo that it cannot ≈ølake the thir≈øt which it findeth, yea rather it ≈øoketh vp ye moi≈øture which it findeth, wherby thir≈øt which is the want of moi≈øture, is more increa≈øed.

Secondly, Such as are fa≈øting, whether bee they more an hungred then a thir≈øt? By the ≈øame place I an≈øwere yt they thir≈øt mo≈øt, fora≈ømuch as naturall heat worketh continually vpon the foode and nutriment which w√©e receiue, con≈øuming it away. Which al≈øo appeareth in children whiles they be infaÃÑts which con≈øume and concoct great ≈øtoare of nutriment by rea≈øon of their vehement heate. But contrariwi≈øe w√©e perceiue how ea≈øely old men can ≈øu≈øtaine fa≈øting, by rea≈øon of the defaute of naturall heat in them. But in the middle age, if naturall heat b√©e ≈øtirred vp with exerci≈øe, it procureth a ≈øtroÃÑger appetite vnto meat, for want of naturall heat. Wherfore, if there b√©e alwaies heate in appetite, & moi≈øture b√©e the peculiar ≈øub≈øtance wheron heat worketh, if when a man is hungry h√©e de≈øireth meate, ≈øurely heat e≈øpeciallye requireth his own nutriment, which being receiued, the whole body is therwt refre≈øhed, & caÃÑ yt lenger tary for more ≈øouÃÑder ≈øu≈ø ‚Ä¢ enaÃÑce

Thirdly, why is it that wee conceiue more delight in drinking when wee are a thir≈øt, then in eating when wee be hungry? Drinke, as a ≈øub≈øtance more liquid theÃÑ meat, ≈øoner perceath into the ≈øtomack & the re≈øt of ye body, and at one time make ‚Ä¢ h a great & ≈øen≈øible delectation of the body to ari≈øe in eueri part therof, wheras meat by ≈ømal and ≈ømall recomforteth ye want and weaknes of the ≈øame, wherby the delight therof is much dimini≈øhed. Fourthly: why doth the ≈øelf ≈øame drinke ≈øeeme ≈øtroÃÑger to one tha ‚Ä¢ is fa≈øting, theÃÑ to one that is full? HuÃÑger emptieth
ye veines, & fulnes ≈øtoppeth theÃÑ, and therfore wheÃÑ as the drink pa≈ø≈øeth through the empty partes, it is farre more euident perceiued, and cau≈øeth more ≈øtrong ≈øen≈øe of delectation vnto the ta≈øtinge.

Fiftly, If a man be thir≈øtie and haue a drie ≈øtomack, whether may a litle drinke ≈øuffice him or not? It is hereunto to be an≈øwered according vnto Galen, Galen. tho≈øe which haue drie ≈øtomackes are ≈øoone a thir≈øt, and a litle drinke ≈øufficeth them. The rea≈øon wherof may be this, for that euery member which is dry, ≈øhrinketh togither and waxeth to be of le≈ø≈øe capa≈øitie then it was before, whiche hapneth vnto the ≈øtomack which is drye, and therfore is ≈øoone filled, and with a litle drink. And in the ≈øtomack there is ingendred great thir≈øtines, when the mouth therof waxeth drie and de≈øireth to bee moi≈øtned with drinke, and then a litle drink ≈øufficeth it. For when that which was drie and hard, is ≈øhrunken togither, the capacitie thereof is ≈øoone filled with drink and a litle extingui≈øheth the thir≈øt, in≈øomutch as it f√©eleth not it owne emptynes, and this thir≈øte ≈øoone returneth againe.

Sixtly, May the ≈øtomack be ouer charged and troubled with to mutch drink? Surely Galen affirmeth the ≈øame,Galen. and the re≈øon may appeare out of the premi≈ø≈øes. For if a dry ≈øtomack by rea≈øon of the narrownes therof, be full with a litle drinke, if then the drink be more then the capacitie of the ≈øtomacke be able to conteine, n√©edes, as Galen ≈øaith, mu≈øt much drink ouer flow and runouer in it.

Seuenthly, why can a moi≈øt ≈øtomack beare mutch? A moi≈øt ≈øtomack is in all points contrary to a drye, for it is very ≈øoft, like vnto a ≈øoft bottle or bladder, & for that cau≈øe is able to coÃÑ teine more, for it y√©eldeth euery way as the meate which is receiued chanceth to fall or ≈øway in it, & al≈øo apparent it is to ≈øence, that a moy≈øt bladder will receiue more then wyll a dry one, and ≈øo likwi≈øe wil a moy≈øt ≈øtomack. And moreouer for≈øomutch as it is moi≈øt without any driene≈ø≈øe, which may procure thir≈øte, therfore it mutch de≈øireth not drinke, howbeit it receiueth much and is nothinge gr√©eued therewith, as is the
drie ≈øtomack. And for this cau≈øe, the Danes, Polonians, Flemmynges, yea, and the Engli≈øhmen can beare mutch drink, bicau≈øe their ≈øtomackes are wide, procured by the ≈øoftne≈ø≈øe of moy≈øture. But in hoat Regions as are Spayne, Barbarie, and ≈øutch like, the inhabitants do thir≈øt mutch, and drinke but litle, bicau≈øe of the drine≈ø≈øe of the mouth of the ≈øtomacke, and in ≈øutch their ≈øtomackes can receiue but litle, bicau≈øe of the drine≈ø≈øe therof.

div.head: The. 5. Chap. of Thir≈øtine≈ø≈øe, conteining 4 que≈øtions.
div.p: NOw are w√©e occa≈øioned to moue this que≈øtion concerning Thir≈øtines, Whether the cau≈øe therof proceede ≈øumtime from the Lungues or no? Which Galen affirmeth, for that wheÃÑ the Lungues are hoat and drie,Galen. they longe to b√©e moy≈øtned, which drines is ≈øpecially a≈øwaged by drawing in of cold aier, and cold and moy≈øt.

Secondly, what is the cau≈øe why thir≈øtines, which cummeth froÃÑ the Lungues, is appea≈øed by drawyng in cold and moi≈øt aier? And the drine≈ø≈øe of the ≈øtomack by drink? It is thus to be an≈øwered, that there be two pa≈ø≈øages, the one for ayer, which is directed vnto the Lungues: the other for meate and drinke, & that pa≈ø≈øeth into the ≈øtomacke. And for this cau≈øe the thir≈øtine≈ø≈øe which cummeth of the Lungues, is abated by drawyng in of colde aier, and that which ri≈øeth of the ≈øtomack, is ≈ølaked with drinke.

Thirdly, Is thir≈øt a de≈øire of that which is colde and moi≈øte, or of that which is hoat and moi≈øt? There are in the body two appetites or de≈øires: the one in re≈øpect of meat, to re≈øtore that which is lo≈øt, which appetite is ≈øati≈øfied with that whiche is hoate and moy≈øt, accordyng to the nature of the partes to b√©e nouri≈øhed. The other looketh for that which is cold and moi≈øt, to repre≈ø≈øe the flame and firines of naturall heate, whiche is accompli≈øhed by drinke only, and ≈øutch drinke as men ≈øeldom v≈øe but in the way of medicine, or when they b√©e ≈øicke.

Galen.Fourthly, Which quencheth the thir≈øt be≈øt of wyne or water? Thir≈øt, as ≈øaith Galen de ≈øimplici medicina, is cau≈øed two maner
of wayes: the one by emptine≈ø≈øe: the other by heate & drought of the heart. That which coÃÑmeth by emptine≈ø≈øe of the partes, is cheifly a≈øwaged by Wine which is both meat and drinke, for it requireth ≈øutch drinke as is able to re≈øtore that ≈øub≈øtaÃÑce which is lo≈øt, which qualitie ≈øince it is in Wine, that is the only drinke then wherby that thir≈øt is appea≈øed. But as for the other thir≈øt which is cau≈øed by heat & drought of the heart that is again double, the one cummyng of heat only, whiche is quenched with colde only, as with Vineger and ≈øutch like. And likewi≈øe ≈øome is cau≈øed by driene≈ø≈øe, & is ≈ølaked by moy≈øture. Againe, thir≈øt which is ingendred by heate, is of thr√©e ≈øortes: The one ri≈øeth forth of the ≈øtomack: the other foorth of the Lungues, and the third from the parts which are farther of. So that whiche cummeth from the Lungues is ≈ølaked by drawing in of colde Aier, and that which proc√©edeth from the ≈øtomack and other partes neare therevnto, is quenched with colde water, but that which ≈øpringeth of ≈øome √©euil di≈øpo≈øition of ye parts and members which are far di≈øtant, as are ye Liuer and ≈øutch like, is delayed with water wherwith ≈øum pear≈øing and ≈øubtile thinge is mingled to cau≈øe it the ≈øooner to go vnto the place, as is vineger or ≈øutch like, for water of it ≈øelf is but ≈ølow and dull in operation, wherfore it is needefull that ≈øome ≈øharper thing b√©e ioyned with it.

div.head: The 6. Chap. of Hurtes which come after meate, conteing. 15 que≈øtions.
div.p:
HEreafter w√©e meane to intreate concernynge certen accidents which chance after meate and drink, And fir≈øt to begin with the ≈øower belching, it may be demaunded wherof it coÃÑ meth? And vnto this point w√©e an≈øwere with Galen, Galen. that the Sower belching proc√©edeth of a fainting heat, which fayleth & decayeth by meanes of colde. For heat is the beginning of the ≈øowernes which beginneth to dige≈øt, but is not able to accompli≈øh it, which defaut cuÃÑmeth e≈øpecially by hinderaÃÑce through cold. Secondly, why is not this ≈øowernes felt in the ≈øtomack‚ñ™ immediatly vpon the receiuing of meat? At ye fir≈øt falling of the meat into the ≈øtomak, it remaineth a while in ye ≈øame nature
Which it had before it was eaten, and caÃÑnot ≈øo ≈øoone be ≈øower, but when once the heate beginneth to work vpon it, there in≈øueth indige≈øtion, and after that the ≈øowrnes.

Thirdly, Why hapneth this ≈øowernes rather, and in more aboundance to them that ≈øleepe, then do wake? In ≈øl√©eping the meate di≈øcendeth not downe foorthwith vnto the bottome of the ≈øtomack where the dige≈øtion is wrought, but remaineth in the mouth of ye ≈øtomack, fl√©eting there about, & ingendring windynes. But for the more part while men be awake, they be ≈øtirringe about or walkinge, whereby the meat is driuen downe, and enforced into the bottome of the ≈øtomack, whiche is the mo≈øt effectuall place of dige≈øtion, and repugnant to the cau≈øe of ≈øowernes.

Fourthly, Why (≈øaith Auicen) do ≈øwete things ≈øoone≈øt wax ≈øower in the ≈øtomack,Auicen. as milk, and ≈øutch like? Milke, and ≈øweete blood are ≈øoone altered, and when ye ≈øtomack a≈ø≈øaieth to dige≈øt them and cannot, then turne they to be ≈øower.

Fiftly, Why will wine wax ≈øower quickly in the ≈øtomack? Wine and Milke of their owne nature are very ≈øoone conuerted into ≈øowerne≈ø≈øe, & the ≈øtomack v≈øeth to bring thinges from power into acte, and ≈øo maketh them ≈øower.

Sixtly, ≈øince all Wines be hote: How chanceth it, that they ingender colde di≈øea≈øes, and not hoat? Wine of it ≈øelfe br√©edeth no di≈øea≈øe, but by filling the ≈øinewes and braine, and ≈øutch repletions in≈øue indige≈øtion, and indige≈øtion nouri≈øheth colde ≈øickne≈ø≈øes, and by this meanes Wine br√©edeth none but colde infirmities.

Seuenthly, Wherof commeth wringing, and griping in the bellie? Wringing and gripinge chanceth in all partes of the body, and it is of diuers ≈øorts. One cummeth of gro≈ø≈øe windine≈ø≈øe, and this happeneth in the bottome of the ≈øtomack: anoof gro≈ø≈øe & tough humours, and another of cholerick ≈øuperfluities. And this la≈øt kinde of gripinge in what≈øoeuer it beginneth, for ye mo≈øt part it endeth in ye ≈øtomack, the bottom therof being a place of great ≈øen≈øibilitie, notwith≈øtandinge that this griping al≈øo may paine any other place of ye guts wher≈øoeuer.

Eightly, May a ≈øick Man eate as much meat as he was won ‚Ä¢ to do when he was in good health? Cu≈øtome is a ≈øecond nature and h√©e that is accu≈øtomed to eate mutch when h√©e is whole, cannot fa≈øt when hee is ≈øicke, and therfore mu≈øt b√©e more often refre≈øhed with meat, euen as often as hee v≈øed to b√©e b√©eing in good health, and more abundantly then h√©e that eateth litle.

Ninthly, whether doth bread or fleash more hurt vnto ≈øutch as are recouering out of ≈øicknes? Rha≈øis. Rha≈øis ≈øaith that flea≈øh is le≈ø≈øe hurtful then bread vnto them, and among all flea≈øh, Swines flea≈øh nouri≈øheth mo≈øt, and b√©eing light of dige≈øtion it is mo≈øt agr√©eable vnto them.

Tenthly, whether is bread or fleash mo≈øt meete≈øt for theÃÑ that haue an Ague? Concerning flea≈øh, ther b√©e two poincts to b√©e con≈øidered in the dieting of Agues. The one is light dige≈øtioÃÑ, and herein flea≈øh excelleth: the other is ea≈øie conuer≈øion into nutriment, and herein bread is better then flea≈øh, for that flea≈øh by rea≈øon of the oylines therof is ≈øoone inflamed.

Eleuenthly, whether is it good to permit ≈øutch as recouer out of ≈øicknes to drinke wine immediatly after their fleash, or afore? In this poinct the common people is deceiued, for the flea≈øh ≈øhould fir≈øt b√©e eaten, and afterward the wine drunken bicau≈øe aboue all things wine is ≈øoone≈øt conuerted into blood, and ≈øpirits, & augmenteth natural heat, and therefore ought to bee giuen later then flea≈øh.

Tweluethly, whether ought one that is recouering out of ≈øicknes, to be dieted & gouerned two daies, like as when he was ≈øicke? verely h√©e ought ≈øo, and that for thr√©e cau≈øes. Fir≈øt, for the debility of naturall power: Secondly, bicau≈øe of cu≈øtome: Thirdly bicau≈øe of ≈øome di≈øtemperature remaining yet with in the body ≈øince the ≈øicknes. This al≈øo may be a rea≈øon, that it is not good to change ≈øuddenly from that whereto a man is accu≈øtomed but by litle and litle, and therfore the recouerer ought for a while to reteine the ≈øame diet.

Thirtenthly, Is gro≈ø≈øe meat good for ≈øuch as recouer out of ≈øicknes? According vnto the iudgment of Hyppocrates, it is not
for, ≈øaith h√©e, it is conuenient that they b√©e nouri≈øhed two or thr√©e daies with the ≈øame diet which they v≈øed b√©efore. For otherwi≈øe they would ≈øoone bee altered by feeding on gro≈ø≈øe meates, which were not good for them to do.

Fourt√©enthly, which of the≈øe two alterations hurteth a man mo≈øt, from emptines to repletioÃÑ, or from repletion to emptines? The ≈øudden change from emptines to fulnes is more hurtfull then from fulnes to emptines, according to the opinions of Hyppocrates and Auicen. Hypp. Auicen. The rea≈øon is, for that through the emptines which went before, the ≈øtrength of the body is ouerthrowen, the naturall heat and ≈øpirites beeing re≈øolued, ≈øo that hee cannot beare a great quantity of meat, nor a ≈øudden change vnto fulnes.

Fiftenthly, how chanceth it that ≈øome meates of euell iuce as Eeles, fresh Beefe, and ≈øutch like, do many times free many men of the Ague? It fortuneth ye ≈øundry, many times are deliuered by ≈øuch contraries in their f√©eding, both by the prouocation of nature, who after the receiuing of ≈øutch meates is much lightned, and therby a≈ø≈øaying to di≈øburden her ≈øelf doth often ca≈øt her≈øelf headlong, ≈øumtime to better, & ≈øumtime to wor≈øe: and al≈øo for the comforting of nature as taking greate ≈øtrength by ye receiuing of cu≈øtomable meats, & ≈øo the powers beeing ≈øtrong, the pacient is ea≈øed and freed by ≈øuch meates: but b√©eing weake, are ouerthrowen, and quite extingui≈øhed.

div.head: The. 7. Chap. of Bread, conteining. 8. que≈øt.
div.p: BRead is in diuer≈øe places made of diuers & ≈øundrie ≈øortes of corne, and therfore it may b√©e demaunded, why bread, which is made of wheat, nouri≈øh more then that which is made of Barly? vnto which Ari≈øtotle an≈øwereth in his problemes, bicau≈øe it hath more moderate clammines, which it b√©ehooueth all good nutriment to haue, whereby it may be ioyned and cleaue vnto ye body, al≈øo it ≈øticketh fa≈øt togither in the moulding, and is therfore the more commendable.

Secondly, why doth ≈øtale bread ≈øeeme whiter and fairer theÃÑ new? Moi≈øture is the cau≈øe of the blacknes which is more abounding in new bread then in ≈øtale, for in the new bread it
yet remaineth, but in the ≈øtale it is exalted away, and departed togither with the heat.

Thirdly, why is vn≈øalted bread heauier then ≈øalted? Salt drieth & by it things are pre≈øerued from putrifaction, ≈øo yt by ≈øalt the moi≈øture is con≈øumed & is expelled away by exhalatioÃÑ, which maketh ≈øtale bread to be lighter then new, and again, in new bread the moi≈øture yet remaineth and maketh it heauy.
Fourthly, why is not bread made of wheat, hard wheÃÑ it is cold? wheat naturally coÃÑteineth in it a ≈øw√©et ≈ølimy humour, which is as it were the ≈øoule therof, & will not permit it to bee hard.

Fiftly, why doth wheaten pa≈øt ri≈øe, and barly pa≈øt fall both in woorking and baking? Barly meale when the water cummeth vnto it ≈øhrinketh down, bicau≈øe it lieth houer and thin, and is full of hu≈økes. And wheaten meale ri≈øeth vp, bicau≈øe beefore it lay very neere togither: but when once it cummeth to heat, theÃÑ dooth it puffe vp, and ri≈øe vp into a greater heap.

Sixtly, Why looketh the dough which is of wheat, white when it is wrought, and barly dough blacke? For two cau≈øes, fir≈øt for that that which is in the vppermo≈øt of the wheaten bread is ≈øooner altered by the heate of the ouen as b√©einge a thing hot and is conuerted into whitenes: And ≈øecondly bycau≈øe the hu≈øky part of the barly reteineth in it more moy≈øture then doth wheat, which cau≈øeth the blacknes.

Seuenthly, Since hony is a more clammye ≈øub≈øtance then water, how chanceth it that pa≈øte which is made vp with hony is more brittle in the baking? Water is ioyned & glewed togither by heat of the fire. But hony glueth togither & drieth with al, and therfore is more brittle, for brittlenes coÃÑmeth of drine≈ø≈øe

Eightly, why is bread which is made of new corne wor≈øe theÃÑ that which is made of olde? In new corne there yet remayneth much watri≈øh and ≈ølimy clammine≈ø≈øe, wherby it is le≈ø≈øe commendable then that which is made of old grain.

div.head: The. 8. chap. Of Wine, conteining. 13. Que≈øt.
div.p:
COn≈øequently I thinke it m√©ete to intreat of wine, concerning which ther may be many profitable que≈øtions mooued,Auicen. & likewi≈øe re≈øolued not wt out delite, as fir≈øt, if, according vnto ye a≈ø≈øertioÃÑ of Auicen in his caÃÑtickles, & Rha≈øis in Alman≈øor
it be good once in a month to be drunken with wine? Vnto this an≈øwereth Auerois, Auer. Auicen. Galen. in his coÃÑmentarie vpon the Canticles of Auicen, yt this opinion of drunknes is but a drunken opinion, & erroneus. For although accordinge vnto the iudgement of Galen, Wine is as agr√©eable to the mayntenance of naturall heate, as Oyle in the Lampe to pre≈øerue the burnynge light: notwith≈øtanding like as to mutch oyle rather hindreth the light and extingui≈øh the candle, ≈øo doth ouermutch Wine quench natural heat altogether. Howbeit if it be delayd with water it is more conuenient, but it hurteth the animal heate and the ≈øen≈øible organes therof, both the brain, and ≈øinews.

Secondly, why ≈øurfet they ≈øooner that drink delaid Wine, theÃÑ they which drink it pure? Concerning pure Wine generally, Galen ≈øaith,Galen. that for ≈øutch as naturally haue weake veynes, it is better to drinke water then Wine. And to come nearer to the purpo≈øe,Ari≈øtotle. Ari≈øtotle in the third part of his Problemes giueth a thr√©efolde cau≈øe vnto this demaunde: the fir≈øt, bicau≈øe that which is tempered or mingled by rea≈øon of the ≈øubtilitie thereof entreth into more narrow pa≈ø≈øages then doeth that which is not tempered: ≈øecondly, bycau≈øe men drinke le≈ø≈øe of that which is mingled as liking not ≈øo well of it as of yt which is not tempered, and thirdly, that which is impermixt and without minglyng is hoater and dige≈øteth the re≈øidue of the meat, which is in the ≈øtomack, ≈øooner, then the delayd Wyne is able to do.

Thyrdly, Why doth Wyne which is vnmingled with water ≈øooner cau≈øe a mans head to ake then that which is mingled? The vnmingled Wine is thick, and ≈øticketh in the pa≈ø≈øages, ≈øendyng vp the vapours and fumes with heat into the head: and the mingled Wine beeing thinner and al≈øo delayd, bothe perceth ≈øooner, and fumeth le≈ø≈øe.

Fourthly, what is the cau≈øe that mingled wine moueth a man more to vomite then the cleane wine doth? The ≈øwimminge of the watri≈øhnes of it about the ≈øtomacke, procureth lothe≈øomne≈ø≈øe, and maketh apt to vomit.

Fifthly, why do not children which are hoat of complexion,
loue wyne, which aged per≈øons, and men of perfit ≈øtrength beeing hoat al≈øo, do greedely de≈øire? Men are hoat and drie, and children hoat and moy≈øt, and the de≈øire vnto Wine is the appetite vnto moy≈øture, which moy≈øture abundyng in children k√©epeth them from drinkyng, and the drieth which is in aged men & ≈øtronge per≈øons, prouoketh them to a de≈øire of drinke.

Sixtly, when wine is clen≈øed from the Lees why is it ≈øtronger and not durable? Macrobius in his Saturnalia the fourth booke,Macrobius writeth that hauing no ≈øtrength nor matter to cleaue vnto, it is on euery ≈øide expo≈øed vnto dangers: for the Lees is as it were the roote wherby the Wine is ≈øtrengthned & pre≈øerued?

Seuenthly, why doth wine immoderatly taken ingendre both hoat and cold di≈øea≈øes? It is to be noted that there be two qualities in Wine: the fir≈øt is to heaten, and in this re≈øpect it rather procureth hoat then colde ≈øickne≈ø≈øes: the ≈øecond is to ≈øtuf the brayne, and to fill the ≈øinews. Thus when cold vapours ari≈øe from the Wyne, they cau≈øe vnlu≈øtine≈ø≈øe, fulne≈ø≈øe, and vndige≈øtion, and con≈øequently procure cold di≈øea≈øes.

Eightly, Whether doth Wyne ingender mo≈øt of Fleame or Blood? S√©eing as w√©e haue b√©efore concluded Wine br√©edeth colde humours, doubtle≈ø≈øe it breedeth al≈øo more Fleame then any other humour. The rea≈øon is, that when wine is quaffed in great abundance, it is not perfectly dige≈øted & cau≈øeth likewi≈øe the re≈øidue of the meat to fayle in concoction, thereby ingendring abundance of Fleame: But ind√©ede if it bee moderatly drunken, it increa≈øeth blood aboue other humours.

Ninethly, Doth Wine hurt the brayne? I≈øaac ≈øaith yea.I≈øaac. Galen. And Galen al≈øo affirmeth that it hurteth the brayne, and helpeth the ≈øtomack. And albeit that at the fir≈øt drinkyng wyne doth properly warme, yet bicau≈øe it fumeth mutch, it anoyeth the brayne, fillyng it with vapours and ≈øtoppyng the ≈øinews.

Tenthly, Why doth ≈øtrong Wine hurt the braine and comfort the ≈øtomacke, and weake wyne worketh the contrary effect? Bicau≈øe Wine heateth the ≈øtomacke whereon con≈øi≈øteth dige≈øtion, ≈øtronge Wine is of greater effect in this ca≈øe then is the weake. But agayn, how mutch ≈øtronger the Wine is, ≈øo
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
mutch the more it ≈øendeth vapours vp into the head, ≈øo that the ≈øtrength therof br√©edeth inconuenience.

Eleuenthly, Why doth the v≈øe of Wine ingender the ≈øower gulpyng or belchyng in the ≈øtomacke, more then water? The ≈øower belchyng neuer hapneth in the ≈øtomacke but when dige≈øtion is beegun, and Wyne ≈øtirreth vp naturall heate, and is as ≈øoone dige≈øted as Milke. Wherfore, like as when they b√©e out of the ≈øtomack they ≈øoone waxe ≈øower: ≈øo do they likewi≈øe in the ≈øtomack.

Tweluethly, Whether doth wine or meate comfort naturall caliditie? I≈øaac ≈øaith that wine doth, and the rea≈øon is, bicau≈øe it is very ≈øwiftly conuerted into natural heat,I≈øaac. comfortinge it mutch more then any meat doth. But meate when it is conuerted into nutriment, doeth more re≈øtore that which is lo≈øt, and comforteth and pre≈øerueth the body longer.

Thirtenthly, and la≈øtly, If wyne mu≈øt needes be giuen vnto the ≈øicke, whether were it mo≈øt expedient to giue them new wine or olde? Although the common people do contrary and mutch ami≈ø≈øe, yet new wine is far more hol≈øom for them then olde. The rea≈øon is, for that how mutch the newer the wine is, ≈øo mutch the le≈ø≈øe it is inflatiue or windy, and for that cau≈øe is more conuenient for them, then are the old wines.

div.head: The 9. chap. Of Flea≈øh: conteinyng. 4. que≈øt.
div.p:
HEnceforward now let vs ≈ø√©e what may b√©e ≈øayd of Flea≈øh. And fir≈øt it may demaunded, why ≈øtrong Fleash is ≈øoone≈øt dige≈øted? It is an≈øwered in the Saturn. that naturall heate is ≈øtrong in a man which ≈øtoutly inuadeth the matter and ≈øub≈øtance which re≈øi≈øteth it, con≈øuming & di≈ø≈øoluing the ≈øame, and that which is tendre & light it burneth ≈øooner into a≈øhes, then turneth it into iuice. For like as ≈øound wood being hewen in to pieces is ≈øoone conuerted into coales, & if chaf fal into ye fier there ≈øcarce remaineth any a≈øhes therof to be found: ≈øo fareth it in the dige≈øtion of ≈øtrong and light meates. So likewi≈øe an heauy mil≈øtone breaketh the greate≈øt cornes, and letteth the ≈ømale depart whole. The ≈øtrong windes al≈øo throw downe hie Firtrees & mighty Oakes to the ground, & letteth the low
≈øhrubs, & bu≈øhes to ≈øtand: Euen ≈øo naturall heat dige≈øteth the hard flea≈øh, and ouerpa≈ø≈øeth the fine and tendre nutriment.

Secondly, Why be Cullices which are made of Fleash, harder of dige≈øtion then the fleash it ≈øelf? The lightnes which it getteth by pounding, cau≈øeth it to ≈øwim vpon the top of all kynde of moy≈øture which it findeth in the ≈øtomacke, ≈øo that it cannot cleaue vnto the ≈øides of the ≈øtomack, the truth wherof is perceiued if ≈øome portion of the cullice be thrown into water, for it will alwaies fl√©ete vpon the toppe, and for that cau≈øe is the ≈ølowlier concocted in the ≈øtomacke.

Thirdly, which is moi≈øter of ro≈øted or ≈øodden fleash? W√©e mu≈øt an≈øwer hereunto with Ari≈øtotle in the. 4. booke of the Meteors, Ari≈øtotl ‚Ä¢ . that the ro≈øted is moi≈øte≈øt: for in ro≈øt flea≈øh by rea≈øon of the fire the outward parts are hardened, and con≈øequently ye the pores are ≈øtopped, ≈øo that ye inmo≈øt moi≈øture cannot i≈ø≈øue foorth. But in ≈øodden flea≈øh the outward pores are re≈øolued through the heate and moy≈øture of the water, and ≈øo opened yt al ye moi≈øture departeth. Thus it hapneth that ro≈øted flea≈øh ≈øemeth drie without and is moi≈øt within, and ≈øodden flea≈øh contrarywi≈øe. Fourthly, why do the beames of the Moone cau≈øe fleash ≈øooner to putrify, then of the Sunne? There can b√©e no putrifaction vnle≈ø≈øe heat and moy≈øture do m√©ete. And the putrifaction of flea≈øh is nothing els but a certain ≈øecret di≈ø≈øolutioÃÑ conuerting the ≈øodility of the fle≈øh into moi≈øture. And heat if it b√©e temperate, nouri≈øheth humours, but being immoderate drieth theÃÑ vp, & doth extenuate. So yt the Sun beeing hot, draweth all ye moi≈øture out of ye fle≈øh and drieth it. But ye beames of ye Moone, in whom ther is no manife≈øt heat but an hidden warmth, increa≈øing the moi≈øture, ingendreth quickly therin great putrifactioÃÑ. For ther abideth in the beames of ye Moone a certen natural propriety to moi≈øten bodies, & to imbrue theÃÑ as it were with a mi≈øty dew, wherunto ye heat which ≈øhe hath being ioyned, corrupteth ye fle≈øh which lieth any time in it.

div.head: The. 10. chap. Of Egges, conteining. 9. que≈øt.
div.p:
THis Chapter requireth now ≈øome ≈øpeciall treatice of Egges, wherin the fir≈øt que≈øtion which offreth it ≈øelf mo≈øt fitly to be demaunded, is this:
which is the hoater of the yolke or the white? Amonge all humours blood is warme≈øt in temperate warmth, ≈øo that the yolke as cuÃÑming neere≈øt vnto the blood, is ≈øurely ye warmer. Moreouer, the Liuer is hoater then the brea≈øtes, and the blood warmer then the milke, and the yolke in the egge is in temperature vnto the white, as is the blood in the Liuer.

Secondly, why doth the yolke beeing ca≈øt into water, ≈øinke downe to the bottom, and the white fleete on top? The white is very ≈ølimy, and cleaueth vnto that which is next vnto it, and by rea≈øon of the ≈ølimines ≈øwimmeth aboue the water, and the yolke bicau≈øe of the ≈øoundnes and want of pores, ≈øinketh downe.

Thirdly, why haue birdes fewer egges and bigger then the fishes, and they haue moe and ≈ømaller then birdes? The greatne≈ø≈øe in a thinge which is continuall,Auicen. is procured by a ≈øtrong heate: but a multitude in that which is diuided is long of the matter, bicau≈øe the matter is the beginning of diui≈øion. And bicau≈øe birdes haue more heat then fi≈øhes haue, therfore haue they great egges in continuall, and but few in diui≈øion, and contrariwi≈øe it fareth in fi≈øhes.

Fourthly, why haue birdes egges an hard shell, and fishes egges a ≈øoft? Fi≈øhes lay their egges in a moi≈øt place, and therfore they n√©ede no hard ≈øhell. But birdes lay their egges in hard and ≈øound places, as vpon the ground, ≈øtones, trees, and ≈øuch like, and therfore haue n√©ede of an harde ≈øhell to keepe them froÃÑ hurt, vntil ≈øuch time as the chick or bird be hatched.

Fiftly, why are birdes egges ≈øpeckled and of diuer≈øe coulers, and it is not ≈øo in fishes? In birdes ther is a ≈øtrong naturall heat which is able to ≈øeperate thinges of diuer≈øe natures a≈øunder, as the yolke from the white, and in fi≈øhes this heate is ≈øo weake that it is not able to worke the like effect.

Sixtly, why are birdes egges long, and fishes egges round? Heat moueth from the centre, and e≈øpeciall cau≈øeth a forme like a piller, broad beneath and ≈øharpe aboue, as appeareth in flame of a fire which ri≈øeth vp into a ≈øharp poinct. Wherfore, heat b√©eing more abundant in birdes then in fi≈øhes, the birds
Egges are long, and fi≈øhes round, for the weake heat carieth the matier equally round.

Seuenthly, what breaketh the eggeshell when the chicke is hatched? There b√©e two cau≈øes hereof alledged, the one is, for that by long and continuall lyinge the ≈øhell waxeth ≈øofte and thin, as it is if an egge b√©e ≈øtieped nine daies in vineger: the ≈øecond is, for that when the young bird lacketh nutrimente, h√©e breaketh the ≈øhell to s√©eke meat.

Eightly, why doth the yolke of an egge which is layd in the full of the moone, and in the light therof, Rha≈øis. ≈øcoure ≈øpottes out of cloth? The fatty drop in the middes of the egge b√©einge the meanes of the generation, conceiueth a pearcinge and a diuiding heat both by the great light, and the moi≈øture which the Moone moueth, which it can not do at another time.

Ninethly, why do ≈øome egges crack when they bee laid into the fire and ≈øome not? Such crack as haue within them windines, which is perceiued when the ≈øhell reueth, to i≈ø≈øue forth with great noi≈øe and force. And this hapneth when the fire is great. For if a birds egge were ca≈øt into the middes of the fire, the ≈øhell would ≈øoone breake, & the windines would ≈øtart forth with great noi≈øe and force, which it would not do if the fire were ≈ømall. But proportionably, there is mutch more windines in the egges of fi≈øhes, and therfore they make a great noy≈øe when they bee ca≈øt into the fire, as appeare for example in the rowe of an hearring.

div.head: The. 11. chap. Of Fishes, conteining 4. Que≈øtions.
div.p: NOw let vs a litle come to demaund a few que≈øtions concerning the nature of Fi≈øhes, and fir≈øt, whether Fishes do feed vpon their owne frie or not? wherto it is to b√©e an≈øwered affirmatiuely, both bycau≈øe they bee rauenous by rea≈øon of their cold ≈øtomackes, and al≈øo bicau≈øe they haue blunt ≈øences and cannot di≈øcerne their owne frie from other, deuouring vp all a like.

Secondly, do Fishes chawe their meat? No, for if they did, ≈øuperfluous water would enter into them with their meate,
and ≈øuffocate them. Againe, they bee rauenous, and feede gr√©edely and eat downe their meat whole as it cummeth.

Thirdly, why doth the raine profit fishes, and hurt birdes? Sw√©ete water nouri≈øheth onely, and therwith are fi≈øhes nouri≈øhed beeing mingled with mud and clay. As for birdes they liue in the aier, and ≈ø√©eke their liuinge by flying about, and the feathers of their winges will clod and cleaue together with the rain, and ≈øo are hindred in their flying. Wherof it may b√©e gathered, that abundance of raine hurteth a≈øwell fi≈øhes as foules, for in ≈øuch times they fall into oppilations of the nutritiue partes, by rea≈øon of the ≈øw√©etenes of ≈øutch water. For ≈øw√©ete thinges, as ≈øaith Galen, do ≈øtop the parts nutritiue.

Fourthly, Why do the Roes of fishes crackle more in the fire then other thinges do? When the fire is ≈øo hot that it re≈øolueth more then it con≈øumeth then do they break in ye fire, as it al≈øo appeareth by the example of the che≈øtnut: But wheÃÑ it is ≈øo temperate that it con≈øumeth as much as it re≈øolueth, then do they neither r√©eue nor breake: b√©e≈øides that fi≈øhes egges or Roes do crackle by rea≈øon of windines included wi ‚Ä¢ hin them, which i≈ø≈øuinge foorth at a litle hole, cau≈øeth a noy≈øe.

div.head: The 12. Chap. Of Pultes or Podware conteining. 3. Que≈øtions.
div.p: NExt w√©e maye take a conueniente occa≈øion to di≈øpute of Podware,Galen or graines contained in a Cod or ≈øhale, wherin w√©e may fir≈øt demaund the rea≈øon, why Galen ≈øuppo≈øeth that ≈øutch as v≈øe to feede on that kinde of ware are mutch ≈øubiecte vnto the gowte? And the cau≈øe is for that b√©einge harde and windy, they b√©e of euill dige≈øtion and are ≈øoone turned into fleame, and of fleame ≈øpringeth the gowt.

Secondly, Beanes beeing windy, why do they not lo≈øe that euill quality by boyling, as well as barly? Beanes are naturally more windy then barly. Or this may b√©e the cau≈øe, for that beanes are of a harder, more compacte and gro≈ø≈øe ≈øub≈øtance then barly which is light and houer, and is ≈øooner di≈øcharged
of the windines.I≈øaac. Galen. Whereupon ≈øaith I≈øaac accordinge vnto the doctrine of Galen, w√©e cannot altogether take away the windines from beanes, but w√©e may dimini≈øh it by boylinge them.

Thirdly, may Lentils prepared with vineger, bee mini≈øtred in sharp di≈øea≈øes? Auicen holdeth opinion that they may,Auicen. but Galen denyeth it. And therfore it is thus to b√©e vnder≈øtood, that Lentils prepared with vineger are noy≈øome in a Feuer with impo≈øtumation, bicau≈øe they freat and binde the pa≈ø≈øages, which thing Galen meaneth. But in a Feuer without impo≈øtumation, by rea≈øon of contrariety they b√©e good, as Auicen vnder≈øtandeth it.

div.head: The 13. Chap. Of Pot hearbes, and Sallet hearbes. conteining. 6. Que≈øtions.
div.p: HEreafter now in≈øueth to di≈øcour≈øe with like breuity concerning a few v≈øuall hearbes, where as fir≈øt the cau≈øe and rea≈øon may b√©e required, why Colewortes do di≈ø≈øolue drunkennes? Ari≈øtotle an≈øwereth herunto in the third part of his problemes,Ari≈øtotle‚ñ™ that Colewortes yeld a ≈øweete iuce, and conteine a purgatiue faculty, the effect wherof Phy≈øicions v≈øe to proue in the mini≈øtring of emollient Gly≈øters, ≈øo that by the ≈øame vertue it draweth the ≈øupefluous & indige≈øted matter from of the wine or drinke in tho≈øe that bee drunken. For this being left in the vppermo≈øt part of the belly, the bodye waxeth colde, which beeing cold, the thinne≈øt part of the moi≈øture is conueied into the bladder. Wherfore the body beeing rid of this double moi≈øture, mu≈øt needes bee di≈øcharged of the ≈øurfet.

Secondly, why doth Purcelain take away the benumming, or edge of the teeth? The ≈øame Ari≈øtotle al≈øo in the ≈øeconde part of his worke beefore named, ≈øaith that the ≈ølimines of Purcelain entring within the teeth, draweth forth the ≈øharpnes which is the cau≈øe of beenumming, and likewi≈øe milke meltinge about the teeth, hath the ≈øame effect.

Thirdly, why do Leekes and Onions pro≈øper be≈øt in drye ground, and wor≈øt in moy≈øte? It is al≈øo to bee an≈øwered by the ≈øame Authour in the fir≈øt parte of the Probleames,
„Äà1 page missing„Äâ
as all that is milted by hoat and drie is of the nature of water as appeareth by all kyndes of Mettals. And Earth is turned into Salt, when it is clen≈øed from the dro≈ø≈øe in moy≈øture and burnyng heat, and drieth congelyng and hardenyng it, ≈øo that Salt is a certayn drine≈ø≈øe of the earth burned by an heat into a watri≈øh hardnes, wherby the ta≈øt therof coÃÑmeth n√©ere vnto bitterne≈ø≈øe, which is ingendred of heat woorkyng vpon an earthly drie ≈øub≈øtance. Then beeing of this nature, by heat it is hot and drie, and by rea≈øon of the bitterne≈ø≈øe it killeth the belly wormes, and by drithe it drinketh vp putrifiynge moy≈øture, aboli≈øhyng the ≈øame, and con≈øequently prohibiting all ≈øtinking. Now bicau≈øe it drieth, and con≈øumeth moy≈øture and heate, it hindreth generation and fruitfulne≈ø≈øe of the grounde, and bicau≈øe it hath a ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe of a burnyng heate, it ≈øharpneth the things that are mingled with it. And bicau≈øe it hath a certain bitter drine≈ø≈øe, the ta≈øt thereof is loth≈øome, and prouoketh thir≈øt by rea≈øon of drieth, and bycau≈øe of the ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe it di≈ø≈øolueth, and beyng mingled with other ≈øauces maketh them pearce into the tungue, and ≈øo it hateth other ta≈øtes. Moreouer Salt hath a certein meruelous nature, which is to draw foorth the like vnto it ≈øelfe, out of another thyng. For if poudred Fi≈øh or flea≈øh which is very ≈øalt be layd to ≈øooke in brine which is newly made, it draweth the ≈øaltnes out of it ≈øooner then fre≈øh water doeth.

La≈øtly, Why doeth Salt crackle when it is ca≈øt into the fier? According vnto the ≈øame doctrine in the fourth of the Meteors, Salte is of ≈øub≈øtance earthy combu≈øt mingled with water and therfore it crackleth when it is throwne into the fire. But if you would know the cau≈øe why Salt pre≈øerueth flea≈øh from corruption, read it beefore in the di≈øcour≈øe of flea≈øh.

div.head: The. 16. Chap. Of Hony: conteynyng 2. Que≈øtions.
div.p:
AMonge many other w√©e mu≈øt not forget to ≈øay ≈øumwhat of Honie, and fir≈øt to demaund this que≈øtion therin, which is the better of new or olde Honie? The choyce in Honie and
Wyne is quite contrarie, for the newe≈øt Honie, and olde≈øt Wine is preferred according vnto Macrobius iudgement.Macrob. The cau≈øe hereof is this, for that the nature of wine is moy≈øt and of Honie drie, as the proofe appeareth in the v≈øe of Phy≈øick, for things which are to b√©e moi≈øtned, mu≈øt b√©e fomented with Wine: and ≈øutch as are to be dried, mu≈øt be clen≈øed with Honie. Thus in continuance of time there is ≈øome part of theÃÑ both con≈øumed away, and the Wine waxeth ≈øtronger, and the Honie drier.

Secondly, If Hony be put into a Wine ve≈ø≈øell why do the Lees ri≈øe vp vnto the top of the Hony, wheras what≈øoeuer els is put in, the Lees as the heauier ≈øub≈øtance alwayes kepeth the bottome? The dragges or Lees, as b√©eing the mo≈øt earthly and heauie≈øt part of the ≈øub≈øtance, fall downe to the bottome, and yet are ouercome by Hony, for Hony naturally by rea≈øon of the weight therof, falleth downe to the bottome, and driueth vp the L√©es as lighter then it ≈øelf.

div.head: The. 17. Chapter Of Oyle, conteinyng. 3. Que≈øtions.
div.p: NOw la≈øtly w√©e come to the con≈øideration of Oyle, where the≈øe que≈øtions are to b√©e mooued.

Fir≈øt, wherfore fleeteth Oyle in the top, wine in the middes, and Hony in the bottome? The better the Hony is, the heauier it is: and that which lieth in the bottom is alwayes the be≈øt, and in Wyne that is, cheife≈øt which lieth in the middle not troubled with the L√©es, nor aboue corrupted by the ayer. For the hu≈øband men of the countrey, not contented only to couer their ve≈ø≈øels abroad, hide them vp in the ground, and defend them from externall hurt, pre≈øeruyng them as mutch as is po≈ø≈øible from takyng the ayer, wherwith they b√©e ≈øo manife≈øtly anoyed, that ≈øumtime the whole full ve≈ø≈øels are almo≈øt corrupted. Wherfore the Wine which is in the middes of the ve≈ø≈øell, b√©eyng farthe≈øt from the aier and the L√©es in the bottome is be≈øt, as farthe≈øt di≈øtaÃÑt from two noy≈øom neighbours.

Secondly, why doth Oyle amend in goodnes, which is pre≈øerued in a ve≈ø≈øell but halfe full? The aier filleth vp the other void place of the ve≈ø≈øell, and drieth vp the ≈øuperfluous moy≈øture which aboundeth in the oyle, which beeing taken away it getteth a new ≈øweetnes in the ta≈øt.

Thirdly, why doth Oyle congeale, but wine very ≈øeldome? Oyle is a ≈ømother and thicker ≈øub≈øtance then wine is, and therfore more apt to congeale: but wine is nothinge ≈øo ≈øoft, & b√©e≈øides is much more liquid. And wheras vpon occa≈øioÃÑ hereof it may b√©e replied, why vineger which is pa≈ø≈øing cold doth not free≈øe, when other things do which are not ≈øo cold: Surely it may al≈øo bee an≈øwered by the ≈øame rea≈øon, for yt among all liquours it is the thinne≈øt, ≈øharpe al≈øo and eger, which is ≈øome hindrance, as it is euident if wee take the ≈øea for example, which by occa≈øion of the bitternes and ≈øaltnes therof, is kept from congealing. And now al≈øo of purpo≈øe a litle to digre≈ø≈øe, what is the cau≈øe that Pepper and Mu≈øtard b√©eing applied vnto the out≈øide of the ≈økin do bli≈øter and inflame the place, but receiued into the ≈øtomack they offend very litle, or not at all? Sharp ≈øpices and drugges do exulcerate the vpper mo≈øt part of the ≈økin bicau≈øe they bee therto applied in their full vertue without the mixture of any thing els with them: but beeing eaten downe into the ≈øtomack, their force is delayd by the moy≈øture of the belly, ≈øo that they bee altered by the heate which is there, beefore that they bee able to do any harme.

div.head: ‚ùß The fourth Booke, of Table Philo≈øophie, which compri≈øeth many mery hone≈øt Ie≈øtes, delectable deui≈øes, and plea≈øant purpo≈øes, to be v≈øed for delight and recreation, at the boord among company.
The Preface.
div.p:
Jn this fourth Booke we intend to ≈øet downe ≈øomwhat concerning hone≈øt myrth, and plea≈øaunt recreation in wordes, wherby men are refreshed, at the table. For as ≈øayth Aristotle in the fourth booke of his Ethicks, In this life if at any time we haue the liberty to lyue in re≈øt & quietne≈ø≈øe, and to refresh our ≈øelues with any pa≈øtime, wee ought therein to frequent comelie and curteous ≈øpeache, and to behaue our ≈øelues gentlie, ≈øo that a mannes wordes and deedes do tende vnto delight, dy≈øpo≈øing him≈øelfe to vtter him≈øelfe accordinglie, and to beare the merrie deedes and wordes of others. Vpon which place, Albertus in his Commentarie ≈øayth: Euerie man that is geuen to ≈øtudie hath nede of recreation that his witte bee not wholy ouerthrowne. For who≈øo euermore applieth his ≈øtudie, and bendeth his minde alwaies to practi≈øe or looke vpon ≈øumthinge: doubtle≈ø≈øe his ≈øpirites shalbe re≈øolued, and the animall power be de≈øtroyed, and the proper functions of the partes ≈øurcea≈ø≈øe: which partes being de≈øtitute, then is the force of ≈øtudie brought to ruine. In con≈øideration whereof tho≈øe which are ≈øtudious, and mutch troubled with affaires, haue neede of re≈øt, wherein theyr ≈øpirites may be relea≈øed, and their ≈øences re≈øolued in ≈øome plea≈øure. For lyke as in the coÃÑ mon cour≈øe of our life nature wanteth ≈øleepe, ≈øo in ≈øtudie and trauayle, re≈øt is ≈øemblablie needefull. But who ≈øo is a ≈øtudent, or wearied with hone≈øt exercy≈øe, to ≈øuch is none other then hone≈øt recreation acceptable: which playnly con≈øi≈øteth in ≈øuch wordes & deedes as are not repugnaunt to vertue, but ≈øtyrre vp the delyte of our affection. For looke howe bodylie wearine≈ø≈øe is cured by bodylie re≈øt: ≈øo is tediou≈øne≈ø≈øe of the minde a≈ø≈øwaged by plea≈øure of recreation, which is al≈øo a certaine re≈øting of the minde. As it i ‚Ä¢ read in a certaine wryter, that as there was a man of rype yeares, and much addicted vnto contemplacion; playing for his delight among children which he taught: there came one by, who beholding the
≈øame, mocked him to ≈øcorne. Then ≈øayd this good maÃÑ, why mocke≈øt thou? bend thy bow, which thou ha≈øt in thy hand, and he dyd ≈øo. Nay, bend it more quod he: J dare not ≈øayd the other for feare of breaking it. Euen ≈øo, quod he, it fareth with my mind: For vnle≈ø≈øe I should refresh it with ≈øome pla ‚Ä¢ e: it would fayle mee, and be quite extinguished. And therefore it is expedient to v≈øe hone≈øt recreation‚ñ™ by meanes wherof to recreate a mans minde, as namelie after godly ≈øtudies, and painefull trauayles And among many it is a pretie kinde of ≈øolace and delight, to v≈øe wyttie inuectiues & quippes one at another at the table, ≈øo that the wytte therein be exerci≈øed, not by byting: but by sharpning one another. Or whether it were in plea≈øaunt que≈øtions or picked deui≈øes, whereby the one prouoketh another to breake ≈øilence. Or el≈øe in plea≈øaunt tales or hy≈øtories, wherewith the hearers are delighted, and made merie.

div.head: Chap 1. Of plea≈øaunt quippes, and tauntes.
div.p:
Macrobius. ACcording to ye doctrine of Macrobius in his fourth booke of Saturnalia, there be two kindes of quippes, or inuectiues. The one a plaine rayling, or chacking. The other a figuratiuelye ≈øhadowed ≈øpeach couered cleanly with myrth & ciuilyty, ≈øouÃÑding one thing, & couertly meaning another, but not proceedyng to expre≈ø≈øe bytterne≈ø≈øe. The fyr≈øt kynd is altogyther to h ‚Ä¢ e bani≈øhed the table. For as the ≈øame aucthour wryteth, lyke as a lytle thru≈øt dryueth downe him that ≈øtandeth vppon a narrowe footing: ≈øo a ≈ømall griefe being ≈øprinckled and bathed with wyne, wyll ≈øoone dryue a man into madne≈ø≈øe. The other kynd which is coouert, may al≈øo be ≈øauced with ≈øharpne ‚Ä¢ ≈øe. The lyke whereof is reported of Octauianus, who ≈øeemed to bee a noble man of byrth. Before whome when on a tyme Cicero pronounced ≈øomewhat, I heard not what you ≈øayde, quod Octauianus. That is maruayle ≈øayde Cicero, ≈øynce your eares were woont to be ≈øo well boored, which hee ≈øpake for this cau≈øe, for that Octauianus was borne in Lybia, where the maner of the people was to make hoales through theyr eares. This
kynde of nypping, becau≈øe it is next neyghbour to rayling: ought among≈øt wy≈øe men to b√©e auoyded at the table. But ≈øome there is which hath in it le≈ø≈øe ≈øharpene≈ø≈øe, as that which Cicero v≈øed again≈øt Gneus Seruilius, which was Con≈øul but one daye. In foretymes, quod Cicero, Flamines were but for one daye, and nowe the Con≈øuls bee ≈øo. And agayne, when Fannius had b√©ene Con≈øul but a fewe dayes: then ≈øayde Cicero: there happened a great wonder in Fannius yeare, for when h√©e was Con≈øul, there was neyther Wynter, nor Spryng, nor Summer, nor Harue≈øt. And when Fannius demaunded of him, why hee came not to ≈øee him whyle hee was ≈øycke in his Con≈øul≈øhyppe: hee aun≈øweared, I woulde haue come, but the nyght came to fa≈øt vppon mee. The≈øe, and ≈øutch other lyke maye b√©e v≈øed, which touche certayne faultes and deformyties of the bodye, which ingender lyttle or no griefe at all, as are the crokedne≈ø≈øe, ry≈øing vp, or flatne≈ø≈øe of the no≈øe.

Certayne nyppes and gyrdes, doe ≈ø√©eme at the fyr≈øt appearaunce to haue ≈øome reproochefulne≈ø≈øe or ≈øclaunder in them, and yet they doe not touche the hearers, as this is. When Quintus Lucius ≈øayde vnto his friend which ≈øate by him, that his handes were cold, then ≈øayd his friende: that is great maruayle hauing brought them warme ≈øo latelye out of the Prouince. Wherewith Quintus was much delyghted, for that h√©e was without all ≈øu≈øpicion of thee uerie, whereas contrarywi≈øe, if hee had ≈øpoken it vnto one that had b ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ne guiltye and pryuie of his owne theeft: it woulde haue mutch troubled him.

Or if a man ≈øhould ≈øay vnto one that lyueth very cha≈øtly, h√©e loueth a whore as well as you, it ≈øhould much delight him. Contrarywi≈øe, if you ≈øhould ≈øay vnto a coward or timerous per≈øon, thou art as hardie as euer was Achilles, or Hercules, or vnto ≈øome notorious naughtie per≈øon, I accoumpt thee more vicious then euer was Ari≈øtides: the≈øe wordes doo ≈øounde as a pray≈øe, when as in d ‚Ä¢ de they be plaine di≈øcommendation. Al≈øo in the vttering of a nyppe or inuectiue: it is wel coÃÑmended if he which ≈øpeaketh it be al≈øo of the ≈øame condicion. As if a poore man mock at a poorer then him≈øelfe for pouerty, or one that is borne of ba≈øe parentage, floute at another as meanly borne as him≈øelfe: as
dyd one Thar≈øeus, who from a Gardener comming vnto ≈øome better calling, flouted at his olde friend and acquaintance which was blinde & of ba≈øe parentage: but immediatlie he added: And I al≈øo am borne of the ≈øame ≈øeede. There be moreouer ≈øome kinde of nyppes, which doe not onely not di≈øplea≈øe the hearers: but make them merrie. The lyke whereof Diogenes ca≈øt forth again≈øt Ari≈øtenes his mai≈øter, ≈øaying: This man of a rytch man hath made mee poore, and from a fayre hou≈øe, hath brought mee to dwell in a Tub. For by the≈øe wordes he vttered better his ≈øence and meaning, then if he had ≈øayde, I thanke my may≈øter that hath made mee a Philo≈øopher, and a man perfectly fraught with all vertue.

div.head: Chap. 2. Of ≈øpeaches conuenient for euerie kinde of per≈øon.
div.p:
THe a≈ø≈øembling togyther of men for hone≈øt myrth & banketting,Macrobius. as it is commendable, ≈øo ought it not to be dumbe, and without wordes, as ≈øayth Macrobius. And who ≈øo is de≈øirous to be a plea≈øaunt companion, and a prouoker vnto talke, and dele ‚Ä¢ table deui≈øes: mu≈øt demaunde ≈øuch que≈øtions as are ea≈øie to be re≈øolued, and wherein he knoweth the partie to haue ≈øome ≈økyll and exerci≈øe. For euerye man is glad when he is prouoked to vtter his knowledge in that wherein he is ≈økylfull, and woulde not wyllinglie haue his ‚Ä¢ unning hyd wherein he hath trauailed, which is perhappes vnknowne vnto the re≈øidue, be it Diuinitie, Phi≈øicke, A≈øtronomie, Law, or ≈øuch lyke. For herein he ≈øeemeth to haue attayned vnto ≈øome ende of his ≈øtudye, when he hath gotten fytt occa≈øion to vtter yt which he hath read, without ≈øu≈øpicion of o≈øtentacion, wherewith he can not be touched, when he ≈øpeaketh, not intruding him≈øelfe, but being thereto required. Againe, it is a great griefe, and a poynt of di≈øcourte≈øie, to demaund a que≈øtion of a man in ≈øome matter wherein he is ignoraunt, and that al≈øo in companye. For he is then eyther enforced to confe≈ø≈øe his ignoraunce, or to aun≈øwere vnadui≈øedlye, or to commytte him ≈øelfe to the hazarde of a true or fal≈øe euent. Suche as haue trauayled farre by lande and Sea, are glad when they be a≈øked of the ≈øituation of farre Countreys, or of the worcking of the wylde Seas. Captaines and Souldiors
doe wyllinglye bla≈øon theyr owne valiaunt actes, yea, ≈øometyme without any mocion of arrogancie. And generallye, euerie man reioy≈øeth to di≈øcour≈øe of his owne daungers & troubles, which he hath pa≈ø≈øed in his lyfe. If thou can≈øt, prouooke him often to talke, who hath bene many tymes fauourably entertayned of great per≈øonages, or hath accompli≈øhed emba≈ø≈øages with happy ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, or hath b√©en honorably entertained of ye Prince: or who ≈øo hauing b√©ene be≈øet by Pyrates, among the whole fleete of his fellowes, hath him≈øelfe onely e≈øcaped awaye by his wytte & valiencie. It wyll lyke ≈øome man wel to declare if thou require him, the ≈øodaine felicity of his friend, which he would not vtter of his owne accorde, and yet is loth to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe it, for feare of ≈øu≈øpicion of enuie. He that loueth hunting, is delighted to talke of Hounds, Fore≈øtes, Cha≈øes, and the euent of hunting. If there be any religious per≈øon pre≈øent, as Monke, or Fryar, gyue him leaue to glo≈øe of his owne holyne≈ø≈øe, howe he maye de≈øerue well of God, what is the commoditye of Ceremonyes, and what rewardes are promi≈øed vnto the deuout fulfyllers of the ≈øame. But if there be euer an olde man in the company, you ≈øhall do him a great plea≈øure to a≈øke him of ≈øuch matters as are nothing to the purpo≈øe, for that age is much giueÃÑ to talke, as wytne≈ø≈øeth Macrobius. All the≈øe and ≈øuch lyke thinges may be inuented to delight and procure the whole a≈ø≈øemblye to talking, and to fall vnto variable communication, of what calling ≈øo euer they b√©e.

div.head: Chap. 3. Of apte plea≈øaunt wordes.
div.p:
SW√©ete and plea≈øaunt wordes do cheare the fea≈øt no le≈ø≈øe then Wyne, as is the olde ≈øaying. For if this delight≈øome prouocation be myngled with oportunitye, it per≈øwadeth more then doeth any hearbe myngled with the Wyne, or what≈øoeuer inchauntment it b√©e, no not the be≈øt iuyces which are brought out of India or Arabia, are of ≈øo great effect. For this is the charme wherewith that fayre Helen of Greece, allured her amorous ghea≈øt, and turned him from ≈øorrowe to ioye, euen the oportunity to vtter her plea≈øaunt di≈øcour≈øes. Whereby it is euident, that plea≈øaunt wordes and apte ≈øayinges, not exceeding the
boundes of hone≈øtie, do much cheare the table, & ≈øolace the company. And now to ≈øpeake of antiquitye, there be two very eloquent coÃÑpanions, ≈øayth Macrobius, to wyt, Cicero & Plautus, excelling all other in delitefull conver≈øation, where he bringeth in certaine places out of Cicero to the ≈øame purport, as this is, that on a time it hapned that Cicero ≈øupped at the hou≈øe of Dama≈øippus the Philo≈øopher, who ≈øetting a lyttle wyne of Falernum before him: ≈øayd, drinke yee of this wyne which is forty yeare old: ≈øurely, quoth Cicero, it beareth his age well. Lykewi≈øe being de≈øired to dinner by a friend of his (for commonly he denayd none that reque≈øted him in that behalfe) which was but ≈øimple & ordinary, when he was comming away & taking leaue, he rouÃÑded the mai≈øter of the hou≈øe in the eare, ≈øaying: I knew not before yt we two were ≈øo familiar and coÃÑming al≈øo on a time vnto Pompeius hou≈øe, ≈øome yt were there before, ≈øayd that he came to late: Naye not ≈øo ≈øayd Cicero, for I ≈øee nothing preuided. Lykewy≈øe ≈øeeing Lentulus his ≈øonne in lawe, a man of ≈ømall ≈øtature, going with a long ≈øword by his ≈øyde: who, quod Cicero hath tyed my ≈øonne in lawe to a ≈øword? The ≈øame beholding the counterfayte of his brother Quintus Cicero ≈øet forth very large, and in a great portrayture, and Quintus him ≈øelfe being a man but of a verye ≈ømall ≈ø ‚Ä¢ antling: halfe my brother ≈øayde hee, is bygge ‚Ä¢ then the whole. After the victorye which Cae≈øar obtayned Cicero being demaunded how he was ≈øo deceyued in taking part: an≈øwered thus: his gyrting deceyued mee, te≈øting at the maner of Cae≈øar, who was woont to let his gowne trayle downe after him, going ≈øomewhat wantonly & ‚Ä¢ ff ‚Ä¢ minatly in apparell In ≈øo much that Sylla fore≈øeeing what might haplye in≈øue, ≈øayde on a tyme vnto Pompeius, take heede of that vngyrted boye. Laberius pa≈ø≈øing by Cicero and faking a place to ≈øyt on: I woulde gyue you part of my place then quod Cicero, but that I ≈øyt in a narrow rowme, thereby both di≈ø ‚Ä¢ ayning him, & ie≈øtyng al≈øo at the new Senate, the number whereof Cae≈øar had augmented be≈øide ryght and order. Howbeit he caryed it away not ≈ø ‚Ä¢ otree: for Laberius an≈øwerered him home agayne, ≈øaying: It is maruayle that you ≈øyt ≈øo narrowlye, which v≈øe to ≈øyt on two ≈øtooles at one tyme, thereby reproching Cicerces lyghtne≈ø≈øe. Therefore, for as much
as the≈øe and ≈øuch lyke ie≈øtes, do prouoke laughter and delyte, in them that heare them: I haue purpo≈øed to fyll this fowrth part with the lyke, according to ≈øundrye e≈øtates of per≈øons, drawing them forth of allowable aucthorityes, and dy≈øpo≈øing them in a conuenient order, and begynning eft≈øones with the greate≈øt per≈øonages.

div.head: Chap. 4. Of Emperours, and their merie ie≈øtes.
div.p:
MAcrobius wryteth, that Augu≈øtus the Emperour was delyted in ie≈øting, hauing alwayes re≈øpect of his honour, and hone≈øtie.Macrobius. And many maruayled more at the ie≈øtes and quippes which he bare, then tho≈øe which he gaue. On a tyme when he ≈øaw a grauer grauing a tombe for his father: In deede quod Augu≈øtus this is the true reueren≈øing and culture of the fathers ≈øepulcher. When he heard that king Herode among the chi ‚Ä¢ dren which were but two monethes old, whome he ≈ølew for Chri≈øtes ≈øake, had al≈øo kylled his owne ≈øonne, ≈øayd, that he had rather be Herodes hogge then his ≈øonne. There came vnto Rome a certaine young Gentleman very lyke vnto Augu≈øtus, whome wheÃÑ the Emperour had ≈øeene, be demauÃÑded of him if his mother had ≈øomtime b√©en at Rome or not? No quod the Gentleman, but my father hat b√©ene often. When Augu≈øtus had written certaine inuectiues again≈øt Pillio: but I wyll hold my peace quod Pillio, for it is a ≈øhrewd matter to write again≈øt him yt can bani≈øh mee. Then one as he was pa≈ø≈øing by, ≈øayd, there goeth a tyrant: Augu≈øtus turned about, & aun≈øwered, if I were one, thou woulde≈øt not dare to ≈øay ≈øo. One nyght as he lay in a vyllage in ye couÃÑtrey, an Oule troubled him ≈øo with hyr crying, yt he could not ≈øleepe. But when one of ye ≈øouldiors going forth had taken the Oule, he commended his indu≈øtrie, & commaunded that he ≈øhould ha ‚Ä¢ e a thou≈øand pence giuen him for a reward. Which the ≈øouldiour mi≈øtyking of ≈øayd he had rather yt ≈øhe ≈øho ‚Ä¢ ld liue, & ≈øo let hyr flie. Who wyll not maruaile how this ≈øaucie ≈øouldiour could e≈øcape ≈øo well, hauing offended an Emperor? Lucan, ye Poet reporteth, that when ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ that was inferiour vnto Iulius Cae≈øar euert ‚Ä¢ , war
‚Ä¢ ed him in certeyne matters, he au ‚Ä¢ ≈øweared him ≈øaying:

q.l: Can make thee wothie Cae≈øars y ‚Ä¢ e.

div.p: Of a necromancer that deluded a noble man.There is a ≈øtorye tolde of a certayne Necromancer, who had a noble man to his Scholler, that promy≈øed him many great gyftes and bountifull rewardes. Whome the mai≈øter meaning to trye what he woulde doe in deede, wrought ≈øo by his art that he ≈øeemed vnto him ≈øelfe that he was elected Emperour. And hauing thus obtayned much lande and lyuing as h√©e ‚Ä¢ hought, his may≈øter de≈øired him to be≈øtowe ≈øome parte thereof vppon him. Why quoth his Schollar, I knowe th√©e not. Then ≈øayd the mai≈øter, I am hee that hat hath gyuen you all the≈øe rytches, and nowe I wyll take them awaye agayne, and there withall cau≈øed the vi≈øion to ≈øurcea≈øe, and then h√©e found him ≈øelfe to be in ca≈øe as h√©e was before. Thus many men promi≈øe many goodlye matters, which they neuer meane to perfourme.

The determinacion of Fredericke the Emperour. Fredericke the Emperour lying in ≈øiege before the Cittye of Mill ‚Ä¢ yn, determyned if h√©e myght take it, to ≈ølay man, woman, and chylde. Then aun≈øwered the Erle of Subandia, ≈øaying, that his Maie≈øtye had yet a greater conque≈øt then that in hand, which he mu≈øt al≈øo obtaine. What is that, quoth the Emperor? truely ≈øayde the Erle, your owne wyll and courage of mynde. Which ≈øaying the Emperour hauing wel dyge≈øted within him ≈øelfe, altered his determination, & graunted them al theyr liues.

div.head: Chap. 5. Of Kinges, and their ≈øundrye merye ie≈øtes.
div.p:
THe noble Seneca, in his booke which he wrote of anger, ≈øheweth yt
‚Ä¢ ing Antiochus, hearing certaine of his ≈øubiects euyl reporting of him, & rayling again≈øt him in a place where there was nothing but a curtaine drawne betweene them that ≈øpake, and him that harde: h√©e gentlie reprooued theyr follie, as it had b√©ene ≈øome other man, ≈øaying vnto them, depart from he ‚Ä¢ ce lea≈øt the king heare you.

Hovve king Alexander vvould kyll the A≈ø≈øe dryuer.
∆≤alerius in the ≈øeuenth booke & thyrd Chapter. Writeth, that king Alexander being warned by an Oracle, that whom≈øoeuer he met when he walked forth of ye Gate, he ≈øhould coÃÑmaund him to b√©e ≈ølaine, ≈øeeing a dryuer of A≈ø≈øes, coÃÑming a farre of, wylled immediatly that he ≈øhould b√©e kylled. Then ye poore A≈ø≈øe dryuer a≈øking the cau≈øe why hee ≈øhould bee put to death nothauing ‚Ä¢ ffeÃÑ ded, they an≈øwered, yt it was the coÃÑmaundement of the Oracle.
Then quod the A≈ø≈øe driuer, If it be ≈øo, O kyng, then hath this lot fallen vpon another & not on m√©e, for the A≈ø≈øe which I draue before me met with you fir≈øt. Then kyng being delighted with this ≈øubtyll an≈øweare, and ≈øeeing howe he was reuoked from his errour, ≈øaued the man, & commaunded the A≈ø≈øe to be ≈ølaine.

When the people of Athens would haue yeelded diuine honors vnto Alexander, beware quod Demades, that whyles ye keepe heauen, ye loo≈øe not ‚Ä¢ he earth.Of the va ‚Ä¢
let that told king Philip that he vvas his kinsman. A certayne poore varlet meeting with Philip the king, de≈øyred him to geue him ≈øomewhat for that he was of h ‚Ä¢ s kynred. Which way ≈øaide the kyng? Marie quod the varlet, by our great grandfather Adam, Thou ≈øaye≈øt true quod the king, and commaunded that his men ≈øhoulde geue him a peny, Which when the varlet di≈ødayned at, ≈øaying, that it was no princely reward: The kyng an≈øweared, that yf he ≈øhould geue ≈øo muche vnto euery one that is as n√©ere of kyn vnto him, as he, he ≈øhoulde leaue nothyng for hym ≈øelfe.

Kyng Antiochus ≈øhewyng his mighty & excellently furni≈øhed armie vnto Hanibal, Another plea≈øant ie≈øt of king Antiochus. a≈øked him yf he thought not that it was ≈øufficient for the Romanes? Yes ≈øurely quod he, vnle≈ø≈øe they be to couetous. Plea≈øauntly ie≈øting at the kinges ≈øaying, who a≈øked him touching the number and ≈øtrength of his armie, and he an≈øwered of the ≈øpoyle. Philip kyng of Fraunce, hauyng certayne poore prie≈øtes with him at his table at dynner,Of the prie≈øt that toke a capon from king philips table, and hovv the king ‚Ä¢ ≈øpied him. perceiued one that ≈øate farthe≈øt of at the boardes end conueying an whole Capon into his pocket. When dinner was ended, the king called him a≈øide, and enquired of him ≈øecretly what he ≈øtudyed? who an≈øweared, Diuinitie. Why ≈øayd the kyng, is it not written in the Scriptures, that you ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ould not be carefull for meate again≈øt to morowe? yea ≈øayd the Prie≈øt, and therefore becau≈øe I would put away all carefulne≈ø≈øe, I haue done this thyng.

div.head: Chap. 6. Of princes, and their merie ie≈øtes
div.p:
IN the ≈øecond booke and ≈øeconde Chapter of the before alle ‚Ä¢ ged aucthour Valerius, Of a gentle man that ki≈øt the kinges daughter in the open ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ere. there is ≈øet downe an hi≈ø ‚Ä¢ orie of a young gentleman, who burnyng in the loue of Phili≈ø ‚Ä¢ iatus d ‚Ä¢ ughter, which was Prince and Tyraunt of Athens, and me ‚Ä¢ ting with her by chaunce: ki≈ø≈øed her openly in the ≈ø ‚Ä¢ reete. For which ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ct,
his wife the queene dealt earne≈øtly with him, to cau≈øe the youÃÑg gentleman to be put to death. To whom h√©e an≈øweared, if w√©e kyl them that loue vs, what ≈øhal we do vnto them that bate vs? Frontinus in the fourth booke of his ≈øtratagemes, ≈øayeth, that it behooueth a Prince to be ≈øage and auncient in behauiour, meaning, that he ought to followe graue and moderate coun≈øell.

Againe, ∆≤alerius in the fir≈øt booke and thyrde chapter writeth, that when Dioni≈øius Prince of Syracu≈øe, hovv Dioni≈øius called him ≈øel ‚Ä¢ e a robber. hauing ≈øacked the temple of Pro≈øerpina at Locris, pa≈ø≈øed the ≈øea ‚Ä¢ with a merry winde and a pro≈øperous cour≈øe: he laughed vnto his frendes, ≈øaying: ≈ø√©e what an happie iourney the immortall gods haue geuen to a theefe,Hovv king Dioni≈øius ≈øtole a goldeÃÑ coate. and a ≈øtealer of holy things. The ≈øame king taking from the Image of Jupiter, a golden coate of a great weight, and putting him on another of cloth, ≈øaid, that the golden coate was to heauie for ≈øummer, and to colde for winter: and the wollen indifferent for both the ≈øea≈øons. Likewi≈øe he tooke away the golden platters and crownes which the Images held foorth in their handes,Hovv dioni≈øius tooke the golden crovvnes from the images. ≈øaying, that it was a folly to refu≈øe their giftes whiche they offer vs, of whom w√©e require all kinde of good thinges. S. Au≈øte ‚Ä¢
in his woorke de Ciuitate Dei, writeth of Fabius the de≈øtroyer of the citie of Tarentum, that when his ≈øecretarie demaunded of hym what ≈øhoulde be done with the images and pictures of the gods, whiche were many, and armed as though they were goyng to the warres? declaryng his incontinencie, he ≈øpake ge≈øtingly ≈øaying: let vs leaue vnto the Tarentines their angrie gods.

div.head: Chap. 7. Of Earles, and their meerie ie≈øtes
div.p:
Hovv the Earle Sub√†dia an≈øvveared the Ievves.IN bookes of hi≈øtories I finde it written, that when certayne Jewes came vnto the Earle of Suba ‚Ä¢ dia, de≈øyring hym that they might dwel within his dominions, he forbid them, ≈øaying, that they had not yet made peace concernyng the vniu≈øt death of their Lorde, and therefore how dur≈øt they be ≈øo bould, as to come into his land?Hovv the Earle Bellimo ‚Ä¢ t an≈øvveared the prie≈øt that begged tole. A certayne religious man, required of the Earle of Bellimount for Gods ≈øake, to geue ≈øome tymber out of his Fore≈øt towarde the making of ≈øeates in his Churche. Then ≈øayd a knight that was pre≈øent, My Lorde wyll con≈øyder of the
matter. Nay quod the Earle, God forbid that I ≈øhoulde take any deliveraunce on this matter, ≈øince he a≈øketh for Gods ≈øake, of whom I haue receiued all that I haue, and therefore let him take what≈øoeuer he n√©edeth for the ≈øeruice of God. A certaine ≈øouldier de≈øired an Earle, (his lord and ma≈øter) to ayd and helpe him to bring vp his daughters, whiche were tenne in number. Which reque≈øt one of the Earles ≈øeruantes, a churli≈øhe fellow and very ritch, hearyng: excu≈øed his lorde, and ≈øayde,hovv a ≈øouldier gat a hundred poundes of a churle. that he had not where withall. Yeas ≈øayd the Earle, I haue thee, and I geue thee vnto him, and thou ≈øhalt geue him an hundred pound to redeeme thy libertie, and ≈øo he dyd. When the Earle of Bellimount was hardly be≈øieged in a Ca≈øtle by the Infidels,HOVV the Earle Belimount ouer came the infidels that be≈øieged him. and determined to goe foorth with a fewe, and to fight for the fayth of Chri≈øte agayn≈øt an infinite multitude: one of his ≈øouldiers ≈øaid, that it was daungerous for a fewe to encounter with ≈øo great an ho≈øt: then quod the Earle, I would to God that as many as beleeue not in God, were here with them, and ≈øo by rea≈øon of his ≈øtrong fayth, be obtained ouer them a glorious victorie.

div.head: Cap. 8. Of knightes, or ≈øouldiers, and their merie ie≈øtes.
div.p: NOwe mu≈øt we geue to vnder≈øtand, that what≈øoeuer is here written of knightes, is likewy≈øe to be applyed vnto the name of ≈øouldiers, for that the latin woord, Miles, Of a knight that ≈øaid that he vvas kin to niene kinges. is indifferent to them both, ≈øo that what ≈øo is ≈øayd of one, may be applyed to the other. But to come to the matter, I finde it written in hi≈øtories, that there was a certayne noble knight, which gloryed that he was of kinne vnto nine kinges, whereof hauyng named ≈øixe, he could not deui≈øe the other three. Then a ie≈øter ≈øtanding by ≈øayd vnto hym, Syr, I knowe well the other three. O, well ≈øayd freend (quod the knight) I pray thee tell me which they be? Mary quod the ie≈øter, the three kinges of Collein.

note.p: Of a knight that made the prie≈øt to vvash afore him.
Of a knight that ≈øaid, it vvas good lucke to meete a prie≈øt in a morning.

div.p: A knight which made a fea≈øt, would haue the prie≈øt to wa≈øhe fir≈øt: you doo well ≈øayd the prie≈øt to make vs wa≈øhe fir≈øt, and ≈øit downe la≈øt: Yea, an≈øweared the knight, me thinkes wee doo be≈øt, for of al other you ought to be fyr≈øt cleane, and la≈øt drunke.

A certayne knight which was ryding to a turneament, chaunced to m√©ete with a Prie≈øt by the way: and returnyng from the
turneament, brought home a broken legge with him. And perceiuing that the Prie≈øt came not to ≈øee him, demaunded the cau≈øe of him: who an≈øweared, I was afrayd that you had b√©en angry with mee becau≈øe I met with you before you broke your legge, for it was counted ill lucke to m√©ete with a Prie≈øt, if a man were going foorth to warre, or to turneament. Nay ≈øayd the knyght, it was good lucke for me, for yf I had not met with you,Of the tvvo knightes that fought a combate perhaps I had broken my necke. Two knightes fought a combat for lyfe whiche ≈øhould ≈ølay the other, and when the one had ouerthrowen the other the conquerour ≈øtandyng vpon him, ≈øayd vnto tho≈øe that ≈øtoode by, ≈øome body take pitie vpon hym. And when he had often called vnto them, and no man would entrea ‚Ä¢ e for his lyfe: then quod this gentle knight, I my ≈øelfe wyl take compa≈ø≈øion vppon hym, ≈øo he let hym ry≈øe, and they ≈øhoo ‚Ä¢ e handes, and departed both togeather ouer the ≈øeas.

Of a knight that a≈øked a d ‚Ä¢ onken Prior vvhat ‚Ä¢ evves in the Abbey.There was a knight which me ‚Ä¢ te with the Prior of his Pari≈øhe, cumming home very drunke from the Chapter which was held in the Abbey wherof he was, of whom he a≈øked what newes? The drunken Prior an≈øweared, a vengeance on this Abbey, for they were woont to haue twelue di≈øhes of meate at a dinner, and this day they had but eleuen. Then an≈øweared the knight, If I had but two di≈ø≈øhes of meate in my hou≈øe, they would ≈øuffi≈øe me, and thou wretch as thou art, can≈øt not be contented with eleuen? ≈øurely I wyll geue thee the twelfth, and there withall he threwe him downe in the durt.

Of a knight that de≈øired to heare his vviues confe≈ø≈øion.There was a knight which de≈øyred much to heare his wyues confe≈ø≈øion, which ≈øhe denyed hym, becau≈øe he hadde on neyther Surplice nor Stoale. And when he had gotten them, and put them on and di≈øgui≈øed hym ≈øelfe, he called her, and ≈øhe confe≈ø≈øed her ≈øelfe vnto hym, ≈øaying, that when ≈øhe was young, ≈øhe loued a young Gentleman, and afterward a Squ ‚Ä¢ re, and then a Knight, and next a Foole, and la≈øtly a Prie≈øt. Then the knight hearyng that, in a rage ca≈øt of the Surplice and the Stoale, and a≈øked her angerly, if that Prie≈øt were nowe liuing, and ≈øhe ≈øayde yea, reque≈øting hym that he would reueile it to no man. And after three dayes, when he had ≈øufficiently bit on the bridle, and vexed him ≈øelfe: ≈øhe came vnto him and ≈øayde, Deare
hu≈øband, vnder≈øtand, that that which I ≈øayde vnto you in my confe≈ø≈øion, I ≈øpake it for the nonce, and I tould you the trueth: for fir≈øt when I was married vnto you, you were a young gentleman, and afterward a Squire, then were you dubbed a Knight, and after that, you became a foole, becau≈øe you coueted to vnder≈øtand ≈øuch matters of your faythfull Lady, and nowe la≈øtly you are become a Prie≈øt, for you haue heard my confe≈ø≈øion. Frontinus in his fyr≈øt boke, wryteth, that when Scipio landed in Africa, comming foorth of the ≈øhip, he fell downe to the ground, and becau≈øe his ≈øouldiers ≈øhould not be afraide, Heare ye my ≈øouldiers ≈øaid he, I haue now taken all Africa.

div.head: Cap. 9. Of Squires and armour bearers, and their merie ie≈øtes.
div.p: QVintus Curtius in his hi≈øtorie of Alexander the great, wryteth,Quincut Curtius. that when Alexander fought with Darius, there was a Per≈øian who putting on the armour of a Macedonian ≈øouldier, came behind Alexander, and ≈øtrake him on the head,Hovve king Alexander forgaue the armourer that vv ‚Ä¢ uld haue killed him. but his helmet was ≈øo hard, that the ≈øtroke glaunced away, and did him no harme. Then being apprehended and brought before the king, and demaunded why he had done ≈øo: an≈øweared, that Darius and he had couenanted, that yf he coulde kyll Alexander, he ≈øhould then marrie his daughter, and haue part of his kyngdome. Then Alexander liking well of the couenant, and pray≈øyng his aduenture, ≈øuffered him to depart ≈øafe to his company.

A certayne Squire offered him ≈øelfe vnto a king to ≈øerue hym, ≈øaying, that he was very ≈øturdie, and bould. On a tyme ≈øeeing raine lying vpon the kinges head, he would haue beaten it of, and as he was dooing, the king boughed with his mouth, to make him afraide. Then he immediatly lyfted vp his hand,
Of a knight that gaue the King a boxe in the eare.
Of tovv Squires, that vvere ≈øvvorne felovves. and gaue him a boxe on the eare, that he ca≈øt him to the ground, ≈øaying, wylt thou eate me vp? But when the other ≈øeruants would haue apprehended him, the king bid them let him alone, ≈øaying, I tooke him into my ≈øeruice becau≈øe he promi≈øed me that he was bo ‚Ä¢ ld. Two Squires were ≈øworne fellowes, concerning all their gaynes and pray, whereof one went into turneament, and gained much, the other went not, but required his
my Lorde ≈øayd the poore man,Of a lavvier that tooke avvay a poor mans covv. yf you heare hym ≈øpeake, then haue I ≈øurely lo≈øt my Cowe in deede. An Aduocate ‚Ä¢ ntred into the Ci≈øterian order, and was ≈øet to k√©epe ≈øheepe. In a tyme when great trouble aro≈øe in the Abbey, there was none found that could geue any good coun≈øell, but he only. At the length, being called and required,Of the Aduocate that vvas ≈øet to keepe ‚Ä¢ hep. wh ‚Ä¢ rfore he medled not with the Mona≈øterie matters, an≈øweared, O brethren, God geueth abrode in the worlde, and the Abbot in the order of religion.

A certayne Earle going forth on Pilgrimage, put his lawier in tru≈øt with his wyfe, whyle he ≈øhould be ab≈øent: When the Earle was departed, the Lawyer began earn ‚Ä¢ ≈øtly to ≈øollicite her to con≈øent to his incontinent lu≈øt: whereunto, becau≈øe ≈øhe would not agree,Of a lavvier that vvas put in tru≈øt vvith an Earles vvife he withdrewe from her her meate and apparrel, and other nece≈ø≈øaries apper ‚Ä¢ eyning vnto her nece≈ø≈øarie furniture. At length fearing le≈øt ≈øhe ≈øhould be ≈øtarued, and that the people would thinke that it came through ≈øome euyll de≈øart of hers, graunted to con≈øent vnto him, and ≈øent her handmaide to bed vnto him in her ≈øt√©ede. And when he had taken his plea≈øure of her he cut her finger, which ye Lady hearing, tred a linnen cloth about her owne finger. Now, when the Earle was returned, and this bawdy Lawyer thought to haue ≈øhamed the Lady before her Lord, ≈øhe di≈øprooued his trecherie, and proued him a lyer, ≈øaying, Looke who≈øe finger is cut, & ≈øhe it is that lay with you, and there withall ≈øhe plucked away the cloth, and ≈øhewed her finger that was whole. A certayne Lawyer had taken ≈øees of both parties, in a controuer≈øie: of one, a Cowe, of the other, an Oxe.Of the clieÃÑt that bid his lavvier ≈øpeake Oxe. Nowe when he ≈øhoulde pleade for him that had geuen him the Oxe, he was dumb, and could not ≈øpeake. Then ≈øayde the Client, Speake Oxe, and he an≈øweared, The Cowe wyll not ≈øuffer me.Of the countrey man that a≈øked his Lavveir a monethes ‚Ä¢ e≈øpite to pay him his Co≈øelinges. A man of the countrey de≈øyred an Aduocate to teache him the be≈øt woord belongyng to an Aduocate, and he would geue him a certayne number of Go≈ølinges for a reward. Then ≈øayd the Aduocate, what≈øoeuer is a≈øked of thee in iudgement, deny it, and require a longer time to an≈øweare, although thou knowe it w ‚Ä¢ ll already. N ‚Ä¢ w when the Aduocate ≈øent his ≈øeruantes for the Go≈øelinges, the countreyman denyed them, ≈øaying that he owed him none.
But at length confe≈ø≈øing the det h√©e required a longer terme to pay him, which was an whole y√©ere after.

A certein Lawier which obtained the vpper hande in all cau≈øes, became a Munke,Of a Lavvier which became a Munke. and beeing made ≈øolicitour for the Abbey, all matters went again≈øt him. And when the Abbot was much di≈øplea≈øed therwith, hee ≈øaid vnto him, my Lorde b√©e not angry, for now I dare not lie and face as I haue done b√©efore, and therfore I loo≈øe all matters that are committed vnto m√©e.

And Aduocate b√©eing very ≈øicke,Of an aduocate that woulde he ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Iudgment, before he would receiue the comunion. his friendes that were about him thought it expedient for him to receiue the CommunioÃÑ ere he died. Then ≈øaid he, I will hear iudgment whether it wer be≈øt for m√©e to do ≈øo or not. Then ≈øaid his frindes wee iudge it be≈øt. But I appeale froÃÑ your ≈øentence (quod h√©e) for you are not my iudges, and ≈øo died. And an old ver≈øe there is written of lawiers many a y√©ere agoe:

q.l: I haue heard ≈øome which made their mone,
That Lawiers friendly are to none.
But whether that bee true or no:

div.head: Chap. 12. Of Marchant men, byers and ≈øellers.
div.p:
A Proper ie≈øt of a certen Marchant that would neuer come to Church, nor heare ≈øermons,Of a MarchaÃÑ
‚Ä¢ that did not loue to go to Church. and beeing mooued often times by his wife therto, ≈øaid alwayes vnto her, go thou for vs both. On a night he dreamed that he was called into iudgment, and ≈øeeing his wife with many other holly folkes entring in at the doore of ye cele≈øtial ioy, and he likewi≈øe woulde haue gone in with them: the porter put him backe, and ≈øayd, ≈øh√©e ≈øhall go in for you both. Thus hee tareing without, awaked with ≈øorow and griefe and aterward leade a godlier life.Of a MarchaÃÑt that wroght a ≈øteight to try his wiue ‚Ä¢ fal≈øhed.

A certain Marchant hauinge occa≈øion to trauayle beyond the ≈øea, who had a fayre womaÃÑ to his wife, which he had ≈øumwhat in ielou≈øie: At his home comminge, demaunded of his
wife, betw√©ene ie≈øt and good earne≈øt, how oft ≈øh√©e had made him cuckold ≈øince he went: who an≈øwered that ≈øh√©e had not done it at all, well (quod he) I ≈øhall know it on Sunday wheÃÑ I come at church: how can you (quod ≈øhe) mary ≈øaide he, looke how oft you did it, ≈øo many hornes will appeare on my heade at church: well then (quod ≈øhe) try it a gods name: This marchant in the meane time got a companye of ≈øh√©epes hornes, found the meanes to make theÃÑ ≈øticke in the heare of his head, and when Sunday came his wife and he went to church togither, and comming to church, either of them went to their owne Pew.
