And as ≈øoone as ye marchant had ≈øaid his praiers he tooke preeuely one of the ≈øh√©epes horns and ≈øtucke it on his head, and by and by his wife ≈øpied it, but ≈øhe ≈øaid nothing, within a litle while after he priuely ≈øtuck on another, and his wife ≈øpied it, and yet ≈øaid nothinge, the marchante within a while ≈øtuck on the third horne: At la≈øt, the wife perceiued the hornes to grow vp ≈øo fa≈øt, ≈øtept to her hu≈øband and rownded him in the eare, and de≈øired him for the pa≈ø≈øion of God to get him out of the church quickly for ≈øurely ≈øaid ≈øhee, if you tary here any while you will haue a huÃÑdred hornes on your head, ≈øo by that meanes, he tried his wiues fal≈øhed, although not greatly to his contentment.

A Marchant cumming to Paris, deliuered a ca≈øket full of Gold and ≈øiluer to a certein ritch Citizen to keepe,Of a MarchaÃÑt that was deceiued of a ca≈øket full of gold. who was godfather to Philip the French King. And when the marchant came to require his mony, the Citizen denyed it him, and ≈øayd that he neuer ≈øaw him before. Then the marchant complained vnto the King, wherat he being greatly a≈øtonied, cau≈øed the Marchant to hide him≈øelf ≈øecretly in his Chamber and cau≈øed the Citizen to be ≈øent for, whome curteou≈ølye interteined, and communed with him of many familiar matters. And ≈øeing a ringe vpon his finger, which he had often times offered to giue him: good godfather (quoth the Kinge) haue you yet your ringe: yea my Lord, quoth the CitizeÃÑ, and I haue often de≈øired your grace to take it at my hande, and now again I de≈øire you to accept it. Then the King receiued
the ringe, and ≈øent it immediatly ≈øecretly vnto the Citizens wife, that by the ≈øame token ≈øhee ≈øhould ≈øende vnto her hu≈øband the ca≈øket of gold and ≈øiluer. In the meanewhyle he enquired of the Citizen touching the ≈øame ca≈øket, which he vtterly denied that he had it, vntill the me≈ø≈øenger returned, and the kinge brought it foorth beefore his face, and for the fact expul≈øed him out of the realme.

One that had bought an hor≈øe, when he had paid his mony,Of one th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ bought an hor≈øe. demaunded of the ≈øeller if hee were good? yea (quod the ≈øeller) Why doe≈øt thou ≈øell him then (quod the byer) bicau≈øe I am but a poore man, (quod the ≈øeller) and h√©e will eate to mutch. What other euill conditions hath h√©e ≈øaid the byer? none an≈øwered the ≈øeller, ≈øauing that he will not clime tr√©es. But when h√©e had bought the hor≈øe, and brought him home, he bit euery body. Then ≈øaid his mai≈øter, he that ≈øould him to m√©e ≈øayd true, for he eates to mutch ind√©ede. And another time ridinge foorth vpon him, when he came to a woodden bridge he would not go ouer. Which when ≈øome ≈øawe that wher with him when he bought the hor≈øe, he tould you true ≈øaid they, for he will clime no trees.

Ther was a certein good woorkeman which gained much and yet was alwayes poore.Of a druÃÑkard that was inioyned to penance to drinke alway by mea≈øure And cumminge on a time to confe≈ø≈øion, the Prie≈øt perceiued that hee was giuen mutch to drinkinge, and therfore inioyned him penance that hee ≈øhould not drinke aboue a certen mea≈øure of wine at a meale, wherunto he con≈øented, vnle≈ø≈øe he ≈øould or bought ≈øumthing that day. On a day being at dinner with his wife, he draÃÑk vp his mea≈øure of wine, & was yet a thir≈øt. TheÃÑ his wife knowinge of ye penance that was inioyned him, hu≈øband ≈øayd ≈øhee, follow my coun≈øel, I wil ≈øell you a cow & then you may drink more by couenant, and you ≈øhal ≈øell her to me againe, and by this meanes he deceiued him≈øelfe, and could neuer bee ritch.Of one that bought a hor≈øe that would not ≈øtaÃÑd by his fellowes.

One bought an hor≈øe, and demaunded of the ≈øeller what faut he had? None (quod he) but that if you traueill him in company, he will not ≈øtand with his fellowes. The byer lyking well of that, and imputing it vnto courage and ≈øtomack,
≈øaid that he liked him neuer a whit the wor≈øe for that. But when he prooued him, he found him a lame, dul, and tyred iade and could neuer reach to his bayte with his company, but alwayes was fayne to tarry behinde.

div.head: Chap. 13. Diuers plea≈øant hy≈øtories, and pithy examples of V≈øurers.
div.p: Of certen v≈øerers that vvould not ≈øtand vp for the prie≈øtes ble≈ø≈øing.A Preacher which in a Sermon had declared the vile wickednes, and abominacion of v≈øurers, pronoun≈øing ab≈øolution after the Sermon vnto all ≈øortes of people accordinge to the maner that then was, willed yt euery ≈øort of them ≈øhould ≈øtand vp to haue his Benediction, when hee named them, according to their vocation. And fir≈øt (≈øayd he) ari≈øe al you that be Carpenters, which they did, and when he had ble≈ø≈øed them he bid them ≈øit downe agayn. Next ari≈øe Clothiers, and after them Shoemakers, and ≈øo of the re≈øidue. Now ≈øayd he la≈øt of all let the V≈øurers ≈øtande vp to be ble≈ø≈øed, and when none ≈øtoode vp, although there were many pre≈øent: Good Lorde, (quoth hee) how will they appeare before God in the day of iudgement to receiue eternall damnacion, whiche dare not ≈øtande vp before men to receiue ble≈ø≈øing?

Of the v≈øerer that wild to haue a bagge of mony vvith him.A certein V≈øurer very ritche and couetous, dwellinge in the Citie of Mentz, being ≈øicke and perceiuing that h√©e ≈øhould die, willed that a bag which hee had ful of Monie ≈øhould be buried with him in his graue, for the ≈øure perfourmance wherof, he cau≈øed his friendes to ≈øweare vnto him by an othe.

When hee was dead and buried, and afterward ≈øome came pri ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y in the night to his graue to take away the Mony, they ≈øaw there the Diuell ≈øitting with a great Spone of Iron burnying hoate, f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ dyng him with the Mony flamynge in at his mouth bright with fire.

Of the v≈øerer that confe≈ø≈øed to haue ≈øined three maner of wayes,A certayne V≈øurer which was ≈øick, confe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf to a Prie≈øt, ≈øaying, that h√©e had but thr√©e ≈øinnes whereof he was gilty, to wit, V≈øurie, Lecherie, and Gluttony. To whom the Prie≈øt ≈øaid, that h√©e could ab≈øolue him of twayne of them, but of the third, that is to ≈øay V≈øury he could not ab≈øolue him, vnle≈ø≈øe
he would make re≈øtitution. Then ≈øaid the V≈øurer, do the Scriptures, and learned men ≈øay ≈øo? Yea quoth the Prie≈øt. But I will ≈øee fir≈øt whether they ≈øay true or not, ≈øayd the V≈øurer, for yet I will not make re≈øtitution, & therfore in Gods name you may depart.

An V≈øurer which was ≈øundrie times mooued to make re≈øtitution,Of the v≈øerer that was buried vnder the Gallowe ‚Ä¢
notwith≈øtandyng could not be therto per≈øwaded. Falling ≈øicke, and waxyng weake to the death, he ≈øent for a Prie≈øt and de≈øired to haue the Rites of the Churche. The Prie≈øt denied him, vnle≈ø≈øe he would re≈øtore the goods ill gotten, which the V≈øurer refu≈øed to do. When the Prie≈øt was departed, he waxed weaker and weaker, and was euen at the poynt of death, and the Prie≈øt was ≈øent for in all ha≈øt to commend his ≈øoule vnto God, but hee could not bee founde. Then (quoth the V≈øurer) I my ≈øelfe commende my Soule vnto all the Diuels of Hell, and ≈øo died. But when h√©e was dead, his friendes be≈øought the Prie≈øt that he would burie the body in the Holly proce≈ø≈øion pathe, which h√©e denied to do. Now the Prie≈øt had an A≈ø≈øe which ≈øerued him for none other purpo≈øe, but to carry his bookes to the Churche, and knew none other way but that. Wherfore ye V≈øurers friendes, de≈øired the Prie≈øt to ≈øhew theÃÑ ≈øo mutch curte≈øy, as to let them lay the Cor≈øe vpon the A≈ø≈øes backe, and looke whether ≈øoeuer hee carried it, there to bury it, ≈øuppo≈øing that h√©e would go directly to the Churche, or home to the Prie≈øtes-hou≈øe, bicau≈øe h√©e knew none other way. The Prie≈øt was contented, and the body was layd vpon the A≈ø≈øes backe, and h√©e went forwarde, neuer turnyng to the righthand, nor to the left, vntil he came vnto the Gallowes, and ca≈øt him downe there vnder the gallowes, and there was buried amonge his fathers.

div.head: Chap. 14. Certayne mery ie≈øts of rude Hu≈øbandmen of the Countrey.
div.p:
WHen kyng Liberius, of whom Macrobius writeth in the third booke of the Saturnalia, was lately aduanced from
the plow tayle vnto great riches, h√©e called certein Philo≈øophers vnto his table, & mocking at their ofteÃÑ controuer≈øies & quiddities in Philo≈øophie, de≈øired them to re≈øolue him certein que≈øtions. Namely, why of white and blacke beanes grounde together, there ri≈øeth Meale of one couler? Wherat Aricides di≈ødaynynge: then an≈øwer thou m√©e this que≈øtion ≈øayde hee, why if a man whip with a La≈øh made of white and blacke thonges, the ≈øtrippes looke all alike whiche they make.

A younge delicate Cocknie of the Citie was married vnto a ritche Fermour of the Countrey.Of a Cockny, mayde that maried a farmer of the countrey. And alwayes again≈øt h√©e ≈øhould come home to dinner or ≈øupper from his woorke, ≈øhe prepared him ≈øome fine litle deintie di≈øh in a potenger, wherwith he was mutch di≈øcontented. And once ≈øhe dre≈ø≈øed him a capoÃÑ for his ≈øupper, wherat he was much more offended then before. This prety parnel ≈øeing that ≈øhe could not plea≈øe him, went and complayned to her mother of the matter, who a≈øked of her what ≈øhe gaue him to eate, who an≈øwered, this, and that, and recited as before is written. Then ≈øayd hir mother thou art mutch deceiued, but henceforwarde ≈øet b√©efore him a great bowle full of Beanes and Pea≈øon, with browne Bread, for h√©e is a labourynge man, and mu≈øt b√©e gro≈øely fead. Now when the daughter had followed her mothers adui≈øe, he laughed and was mery, and ≈øayd that he laughed at the Capon which ≈øh√©e dre≈ø≈øed for him the day before, but truer it is, that h√©e reioy≈øed bicau≈øe his belly was full.

Of a woman that was very willing to plea≈øe her hu≈øband.There was a woman which could neuer make Breade that would plea≈øe her hu≈øbande. On a time ≈øtrippyng her ≈øelfe naked, and wa≈ø≈øhyng her ≈øelfe cleane all her body ouer, ≈øh√©e made Dough and moulded it vpon a ≈øtoole, and when ≈øhe was wearie, ≈øh√©e forgat her≈øelf and ≈øat downe vpon the ≈øtoole and the Dough cleaued to her Buttockes. Anon ≈øh√©e aro≈øe and ≈øought for it, and her hu≈øband a≈øked her what ≈øh√©e looked for, and ≈øhe ≈øayd for the lofe which I haue made for thine own tooth. Mary quoth h√©e, it ≈øticketh to thy buttocks, and then the cleanly hu≈øwife remembred hir ≈øelf.

An hone≈øte ≈øtronge woman of the Cuntreye, when her hu≈øband
came home from woorke out of the fieldes:Of the woman that ble≈ø≈øed her hu≈øbands eye. hauing one of his eies ≈øo grieuou≈ølye hurte that he could not ≈øee with it, would needes ble≈ø≈øe her hu≈øbands other eie that it might not b√©e infected by that which was ≈øore. And ≈øo while both his eies were ≈øtopped, her ≈øweet hart, whom ≈øhe had hid vp in a corner, ≈ølipt out of the doores, the hu≈øband not ≈øeinge him.

div.head: chap. 15. Of mery Ie≈øtes of the Iewes.
div.p: A Certein Jewe fell into a ditch vpon a Saterday which is the Jewi≈øh Sabboth,Of a Iew that fell in a ditche on the ≈øaboth day. at what time ther came a Chri≈øtian by and would haue helpen him foorth, but hee would not ≈øayinge, that he mu≈øt not violate the Sabbath day. The next day the Chri≈øtian pa≈ø≈øed by again, and the Jewe called vnto him de≈øiring him to helpe him foorth. But hee an≈øwered, this day is Sunday, and now I may not breake my Sabbath, and ≈øo the wretch remained there. A good fellow in Mer≈øeborow in an euening ≈øtole away a poore widows Cow, & brought her in the night vnto a Jewe to whom hee pawned her for fiue ≈øhillinges,Of a fellovv that ≈øtole a vvidovves Covv. and the ≈øame night he ≈øtole her away agayne from that Jewe, and pawned her vnto another Jewe for ≈øo mutch mony, and againe the ≈øame night he ≈øtole her from him and pawned hir vnto the third Jewe for the like ≈øome. Then deui≈øing with him≈øelfe how the widowe might come by her Cow agayne, he ≈øtole her likewi≈øe from the thirde Jewe, and brought her home in the morning betimes by the horns. And meting with the widowes mayd that was goinge to the brooke to wa≈øhe clothes, he chid her, ≈øaying, that if he had not ben, the cow had bin lo≈øt for euer. Thus the knaue ≈øerued his owne nece≈ø≈øity for mony, deceiued the greedy Jewes and re≈øtored the widow her cow.

div.head: Chap. 16. Of mery Ie≈øtes of Theeues.
div.p:
A Theif wandring in the woodes, by chaunce met with a Prie≈øt, and ≈øaid vnto him, that he would fain be ≈øhreuen.
For,O ‚Ä¢ a theefe that vvould be ‚Ä¢ hriuen of a p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øt in the vvoods. ≈øaid hee, there pa≈ø≈øed to day a Prie≈øt by this way, and I tooke his Hor≈øe from him, and therfore I praye you inioyne me penance. Then quod the Prie≈øt, giue me fiue ≈øhillings to ≈øay ma≈ø≈øe for thine offence, and the theif told him out ten ≈øhillings into his hande, ≈øayinge, take here fiue ≈øhillings for the Prie≈øts hor≈øe whiche I tooke away this day, and bicau≈øe you make ≈øo good a market, I giue you fiue more for the Hor≈øe wheron you ride, and ≈øo h√©e tooke away his hor≈øe al≈øo.

Of the thiefe that ≈øtole the poo ‚Ä¢ e mans goo≈øe.Ther was a theif which had ≈øtolleÃÑ a poore mans goo≈øe who complayned therof vnto the Prie≈øt of the Pari≈øhe, de≈øiringe him to ≈øpeake to ye people therof out of ye pulpit the next Sunday. When Sunday was come, and the Prie≈øt in the pulpit, hee bid all the people ≈øit down, and when they an≈øwered that they were all ≈øeat, nay ≈øaid the Prie≈øt, for hee is not yet ≈øet that ≈øtole the pooremans goo≈øe (yeas quod the theef that I am) then (quod the Prie≈øt) for ≈øhame re≈øtore to the poore man his goo≈øe again,Of the thiefe that gaue one that ≈øolde an oxe a pice of his ≈øhirt to put in his mony. or els I will excommunicate thee.

There was a theif which watched a man that had ≈øoulde an Oxe, and tooke acquaintance of him, and lead him to the Tauerne, and gaue him a quarte of Wine. And when hee that had ≈øoulde the Oxe, woulde haue bin gonne, ≈øayinge, that he mu≈øt go bie him a pur≈øe to put his mony in: Nay quoth the Theif, lay thy mony to mine, and let vs drink more, and I will giue thee a piece of my ≈øhirte to wrap thy mony in, and hee did ≈øo. But when hee departed, this cou≈øening theif ran after him wt hew and cry, ≈øaying that hee had cut away a piece of his ≈øhirt with his mony in it, and ≈øhewed the place, ≈øo hee gote the mony, and the true maÃÑ was hanged.

Of a thiefe that cou≈øened a gentlwoman of a Sil
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Cup.A cou≈øening knaue ≈øeeinge a ≈øiluer Cup in a gentlemans hou≈øe, which was broken a litle in the foote: he bought a good Pickerell & caried it vnto the Gentlewoman, while her hu≈øband was abroade ≈øaying, My ma≈øter your hu≈øband hath ≈øent you this Pickrell to be dre≈ø≈øed for dinner, for he will bringe home gea≈øts with him, and willeth you to ≈øend him the broken cup that hee may haue it mended for the gea≈øts to drinke in, and ≈øh√©e deliuered it vnt ‚Ä¢ him. Now when he had toi ‚Ä¢ d
this tale to his fellow, ≈øurely, quod he, and I wyl haue the pickrell againe. And when he came to the hou≈øe, finding there the Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe, and all the hou≈øholde w√©eping, hee ≈øpake vnto her with a counterfayte merrye countenaunce, ≈øaying. B√©e of good ch√©ere now, for my mai≈øter hath taken the th√©efe, and ≈øentence is gyuen that hee ≈øhall be hanged immediatlye with the pickrell about his necke, and therefore you mu≈øt ≈øend him the pickrell out of hand, which ≈øhee deliuered. Thus the th√©efe and his fellow had both the cup, and the pickrell.

div.head: Chap. 17. Of Ie≈øters, and theyr merye deui≈øes.
div.p: MAcrobius in his Saturnalia, wryteth of Cicero, that h√©e was ≈øo plea≈øaunt in wordes, & ≈øo full of pa≈øtime:Vvhat meanes a ie≈øter v≈øed to make Eurelius to laugh. that his friends tearmed him a ≈øcoffer and Ie≈øter. Fredericke the Emperours ie≈øter, with wordes prouoked verye much one Eurelius a learned man, to haue mooued him to laughter, but h ‚Ä¢ e could not. Shortly after perceyuing him to b√©e in ≈øome deepe cogitacion, he made a great many of lyttle balles of hearbes, and threwe them hard at him. And when he demaunded of him what he ment by that: the Ie≈øter an≈øwered, ≈øaying, I haue hard ≈øay that there is great force in three thinges, to wyt: wordes, hearbs, & ≈øtones, And as for wordes I haue ≈øufficiently a≈ø≈øayd you with them & can auayle nothing, nowe wyll I trye you with hearbs: and if I can profite nothing that way, ≈øurely I wyll ≈øtone you to death: at which ≈øaying he fell in a laughter,Hovve a Ie≈øter taught his hor≈øe to knele dovvn vvheÃÑ he ≈øayd Flectamus genua. & gaue the ie≈øter a reward. A Ie≈øter taught his Hor≈øe to kneele downe on his knees as often as he ≈øayd Flectamus genua. It happened afterwarde, that a th√©efe ≈øeeing the ie≈øters Hor≈øe to be a proper Gelding, ≈øtole him away. It fortuned this theefe ryding vpon this Hor≈øe which he had ≈øtollen, to ryde through a d√©epe ≈ølough, and full of myre, which the ie≈øter ≈øeeing, cryed alowde, Flectamus genua, and forthwith the Hor≈øe fell downe vpon his kn√©es,Of a ie≈øter that eate poudered beefe greedilye, vvhen he vvas in daunger of drovvning. and threwe his ryder in the dyrt. Another i ‚Ä¢ ≈øter being vpon the Sea, and ≈øodainly a tempe≈øt ry≈øing, began very gr√©edily to eate powdered b√©efe, and when one a≈øked him why he dyd ≈øo: h√©e an≈øwered that perhappes he ≈øhoulde haue occa≈øion to drincke more ≈øhortlye then euer he dyd.

Hovve a Ie≈øter in a tempe≈øt ca≈øt his vvife ouer shyp boord.A certaine Ie≈øter being vpon the ≈øea in a tempe≈øt, euery man in the ≈øhyp was commaunded to ca≈øt the heauie≈øt thing which he had ouer boord. Then tooke he his wyfe & threw her into the Sea, ≈øaying: that he had neuer any thing ≈øo heauie. A ≈økoffer ≈øeeing theeues ryfling and ≈øearching his hou≈øe in the night:Hovv theeus came to rob a Ie≈øter. ≈øirs quod he, I maruayle what you can finde here by darcke in the nyght, when I can find nothing in the broad day lyght. A certaine merie felow being ≈øick,Hovv a man Ie≈øter made his vvyll. was admoni≈øhed by the Prie≈øt to make his wyll‚ñ™ Mary gladly quod h√©e. And I haue none other goodes but only two hor≈øes, which I bequeth to the Kinges and Princes of the earth But the Prie≈øt demanded why he would not rather giue them vnto the poore: aun≈øwered, you preache that we ≈øhould imitate God, and he hath giuen all the ritches of the earth vnto them and not vnto the poore, & therfore I would faine doe as lyke vnto him as I could.Of a Ie≈øter that should be hanged for rayling at a noble man. A Ie≈øter had rayled & ≈økoffed ≈øo bytterlye at a noble man, that he threatned to hang him, where≈øoeuer he tooke him, At length being taken by the noble mans ≈øeruants, & brought before his pre≈øence, my Lord, then quod he, I ≈øee now there remaineth nothing vnto m√©e but pre≈øent death, which I haue well de≈øerued: I be≈øeech you grant mee one reque≈øt, which may be profitable for my ≈øoules health, which a≈ø ye earne≈øt reque≈øt of tho≈øe yt ≈øtoode about him, the Lord frankly yeelded vnto. Then ≈øayd hee, when I am hanged, I be≈øeech you to come vnto mee thr√©e dayes after with a fa≈øting ≈øtomacke euery morning, & ky≈ø≈øe my bare tayle with your mouth. Now the Deuyll hang th√©e, and ky≈ø≈øe thy tayle, quod the Lord, & went away in a rage,
‚Ä¢ ovv a mery fellovv pre
‚Ä¢ ented the Fiers that came to dinner. & ≈øo he e≈øcaped. A mery coÃÑpanion, hauing prepared a mor≈øell of good meat for his owne eating, & his wiues: there came vnto his hou≈øe a company of Friars, & knowing not how to excu≈øe the matter & to ≈øhyft them of, ≈øayd vnthem: ≈øyrs I am very ≈øory yt you may not eate with m√©e, for I am excoÃÑmunicate. Then ≈øayd the Fryars, we wyll not beleeue th√©e, vnle≈ø≈øe thou tell vs the cau≈øe why? For beating of a Friar quod he. Then a ‚Ä¢ t y‚Ä¢ worthily excoÃÑmunicate ≈øaid they, & fearing lea≈øt he would haue beaten theÃÑ al≈øo, they departed incontineÃÑtly.

div.head: Chap. 18. Of merie ie≈øtes of weemen.
div.p:
MAcrobius writeth in his Saturnalia, yt when one demauÃÑded of Iulia, which was daughter vnt ‚Ä¢
Augu≈øtus ye Emperor‚ñ™
why ≈øhe decked not her ≈øelf according to her fathers plainnes‚ñ™ The aun≈øvvere of Iulia the Emperour Augu≈øtus daughter. fragilitye, ≈øhe an≈øwered ≈øaying: My father forgetteth that he is Emperor, but I remember that I am the Emperors daughter. When ≈øome that were priuie of her incontinencie, woondred yt her children were ≈øo lyke vnto Agrippa her hu≈øbande, con≈øidered that ≈øhee y√©elded ≈øo commonly the v≈øe of her body abroade in euery brothel hou≈øe: I neuer take any pa≈ø≈øenger to ≈øayle in my ≈øhyp, quod ≈øhe, but when my ≈øhyp is already fraught.Of Populia the daughter of Marcus. When one ≈øayd yt he maruailed why all brute bea≈øtes would not abide to company with ye males, but only when they would coÃÑceyue young: Populia which was daughter vnto Marcus an≈øwered, bicau≈øe they be bea≈øtes. Fau≈øtus ≈øonne vnto Sylla, A pretie quippe of F ‚Ä¢ u≈øtus to his ≈øy≈øter. knowing yt his ≈øy≈øter v≈øed the carnall company of twaine, namely Pompeius and a fullers ≈øonne: I mu≈øt ≈øayd hee how my ≈øy≈øter caÃÑ haue any ≈øpet in her, whyle ≈øhee hath the company of a fuller? A woman ≈øeeing a ≈øouldior valiently behauing him≈øelfe in a turneameÃÑt, much coÃÑmended him, & fell in loue with him.Of a vvomaÃÑ that fell in l ‚Ä¢ ue vvith a ≈øouldiour. But wheÃÑ he put vp his beauer to take ye ayre, & the womaÃÑ coÃÑming apace to ≈øee him, perceiued that it was her hu≈øband, ≈øhee made a mock at the matter, & cared not for him. A certaine ielous man ≈øet two ouer≈øeers to tend vpon his wyfe, who pa≈ø≈øing by the hou≈øe where her louer was, for the nonce fel downe in the myre.Of a ielous man, and hi ‚Ä¢ vvife. And leauing her two keepers at ye doore, ≈øhee fayned an excu≈øe to goe into that hou≈øe to wa≈øhe her ≈øelfe, & when ≈øhee had made merye with her louer, ≈øh√©e came forth & went her way. There was a woman which oftentimes would ≈øay vnto her hu≈øbaÃÑd that if he ≈øhould dye, ≈øh√©e would neuer marry more.Of a vvomaÃÑ that ≈øayd she vvoulde not marie, if her hu≈øbande vvere dead. But when he was dead, & ≈øhee talked as touching marrying another, euen by his coffins ≈øide, her mayd rebuked her, ≈øaying, that her ma≈ø ‚Ä¢ er was warme yet: If he be warme quod the mi≈øtres, I wyl blow vpoÃÑ him tyll he be cold. A certaine ielous hu≈øbande followed his wyfe to confe≈ø≈øion,of the ielous man that folovved his vvife to confe≈ø≈øion. whom when the Prie≈øt ≈øhould leade behind the Aultar to be di≈øplyed, the hu≈øband perceyuing it & doubting the wor≈øt, cryed vnto him, ≈øaying: heare yee ma≈øter Per≈øon, my wyfe is young & tender, I pray you let mee be de≈øplyed for her: And kneeling downe before the Prie≈øt, I pray you quod ye wyfe to the Prie≈øt, ≈øtrike him hard, for I am a great ≈øinner.

Of a vvomaÃÑ that tolde a gentle ‚Ä¢ an that her hu≈øband vvas a good Phi≈øition.A woman who≈øe hu≈øband had ≈øwynged hyr well, went vnto a Gentleman that was di≈ø≈øea≈øed, and tolde him that her hu≈øband was a very good Phi≈øition, but that he would cure no man vnle≈ø≈øe he were fyr≈øt well beaten. Then ≈øhe cau≈øed him to goe thither, from whence he brought home his back full of ≈øtripes, and thus his hone≈øt wyfe was reuenged on him.

div.head: Chap. 19. Merie ie≈øtes of maydens, and young vvomen.
div.p:
Of an olde vvoman that cau≈øed her bitch to eate mu≈øtarde for a policy.AN olde woman which was de≈øirous to make a matche betweene a young man & a mayde, cau≈øed a lytle bytch which ≈øhee had, to eate mu≈øtarde, and when the bytche wept with the ≈øtrongne≈ø≈øe of the mu≈øtard, ≈øh√©e ≈øhewed hir vnto the mayd, ≈øaying, that ≈øomtyme ≈øhee had beene a mayd, & for refu≈øing a young man which loued her intirely ≈øhee was chaunged into a bytch, & for ≈øorrow therof wept ≈øo continually.Of a young man that gaue him≈øelf to the Deuil for the loue of a mayde. Which thing the mayd hearing, con≈øented vnto her louer. A certayne young man gaue him≈øelf to the Deuyl for a mayd which he loued ardently, and could not obtaine her loue. But when the Deuil al≈øo doing his be≈øt, ≈øaw that he could not bring it to pa≈ø≈øe, to make hir loue the young man, h√©e went to an old woman & promi≈øed hyr certayne ≈økinnes for a reward, if ≈øh√©e could mollifye the maydens heart. Which when ≈øhee had brought to pa≈ø≈øe, and required the ≈økynnes of the Deuyl, he reached them vnto hyr vpon the ende of a long poa ‚Ä¢ e, ≈øaying: I dare not come nere th√©e, bicau≈øe thou art wor≈øe then I am, according vnto the olde ver≈øe:
A wicked woman fraught with all euyll,
Is by three farthinges wor≈øe then the Deuyll.

Of the good man that tooke his vvife a bed vvith another man.A good hone≈øt whore woman, being by hyr hu≈øband taken a bed with hyr louer, con≈øulted with an olde mother Bee of hyr acquaintaunce, how to excu≈øe the matter. But the olde woman perceyuing that the hu≈øband ye night before had eaten an hearb called Cheruile vnto his ≈øupper, ≈øought occa≈øion to m√©ete him in the ≈øtr√©ete, and ≈øaluted him, ≈øaying: God ≈øaue you both. Then ≈øayd the hu≈øband, why ≈øpeake≈øt thou thus vnto m√©e, ≈øince I am alone? Then ≈øh√©e rubbed hyr eyes, ≈øaying: a vengeance on this hearbe Cheruile which I eate the la≈øt night, for ‚Ä¢ uer it maketh m√©e to take one for twaine. The hu≈øband rem ‚Ä¢ mbring that h√©e likewy≈øe had eaten Cheruile the nyght before, thinking the old
wyues tale to b√©e true, and that it had wrought in him the lyke effect, helde his wyfe excu≈øed.of the good vvyfe that kneeled before the hearth vvorm vvood. A certaine olde woman hearing a young wyfe euermore gyuing hyr hu≈øband ouerthwart an≈øweres, & for that cau≈øe had borne him many a blow: ≈øayd vnto her, if thou wylt I wyll tell th√©e how thou ≈øhalt lyue in quiet with thyne hu≈øband, wherevnto ≈øhee wyllingly agreed. Then quod the olde woman, thou ≈øhalt goe into my garden at the full of the Moone, and kn√©ele downe before the hearbe called wormwood, and de≈øyre it to tell th√©e ≈øome coun≈øell that is good. And marke well what the hearbe ≈øayth vnto th√©e, and doe ≈øo. At the tyme appointed the olde woman hyd her ≈øelfe behind the bu≈øhe of wormwood, and when the young woman according to her in≈øtruction, began to vtter her reque≈øt to the hearbe, ≈øaying: O thou mo≈øt bytter wormwood, tell m√©e what I ≈øhall doe that is good: the old woman an≈øwered:
If thou wylt liue in peace and re≈øt,
An≈øwere with rea≈øon for that is be≈øt:
And euer after ≈øhee v≈øed her toÃÑgue better, & liued more in quiet.

div.head: Chap. 20. Merye ie≈øtes of Boyes.
div.p: BOetius in his booke of the di≈øcipline of ≈øchollars,of the boye that byt his fathers no≈øe, vvhen he vvas going to the gallovves. wryteth a ≈øtorie of a boy whom his parents corrected not in his youth, for his naughtie demeanour. But increa≈øing euery day more & more in wickedne≈ø≈øe, at la≈øt coÃÑmitted ≈øuch great robberies, that he was led to the gallowes to be hanged, & de≈øyring to ky≈ø≈øe his father ere he dyed, came vnto him and byt of his no≈øe, ≈øaying, that if he had corrected him for ≈ømal faults wheÃÑ he was a chyld,of the boye that told his father that hee had forgot to beate his mother. he had not then come vnto that ≈øhame. A certayne lytle boy ≈ø√©eing his father beating his mother euery daye, & hearing him ≈øaye one night when he was a bed, that he had forgotten to doe one thing: I know what that is quod the chyld, what ≈øayd the father? Mary ≈øayd he to beate my mother. A man had two ≈øonnes, wherof one alwaies craued a piece of what≈øoeuer was at the boord, whom the father rebuked,of the boye that heÃÑmed to his father for meate. & ≈øet them both togither on a ≈øtoole. And when the young boy ≈øaw meat on the table that he lyked & dur≈øt not a≈øke it, he hemmed, and the father threw a piece of meate at ye other. Then ≈øayd the lytle one, what a paine is this that I mu≈øt hem, and another mu≈øt haue the meate?

div.head: Chap. 21. Merye ie≈øtes of bl ‚Ä¢ nde folke.
div.p:
Of Senecas vvife, vvhen ‚Ä¢ hee vvaxed blinde. SEneca the wyfe, in his fifty two Epi≈øtle, writeth thus vnto a friend of his: you know Harpa≈øta ye fooli≈øh woman my wife, who≈øe eye ≈øight ≈øodainlye fayled her. Shee reque≈øteth of her ≈øchoolema≈øter to goe into another hou≈øe, ≈øaying that it is verye darke where ≈øh√©e now is. In
‚Ä¢ raiectum the lower, there was a blinde man which by begging had gotten twenty poundes in Turone groates,Of the blind maÃÑ, that hyd xx. pounde vvhich hee gotte a begging. which he hyd vp in the pari≈øhe Church where he dwelt, vnder one of the pewes, which the clarke perceiuing, ≈øought for in the ≈øame place, & found it, and caried it away. The next morning the blind man ≈øeeking for ye money, according to his cu≈øtom, & not finding it: ≈øayd vnto his boy, leade me into the chancel among the chaplins, & marke whom thou ≈øee≈øt to laugh bring mee to him & he dyd ≈øo. Then the blind man calling him a ≈øide, ≈øayd vnto him: Syr I haue hard much good report of you, yt you be of a very hone≈øt lyfe & vertuous coÃÑuer≈øation, I haue a ≈øecrete matter to breake vnto you, which I would haue no man to heare. I am blind & weake, and I know not how ≈øoone I ≈øhal dye. So it is, that in this Church vnder ≈øuch a pew I haue hiddeÃÑ twenty pound in Turon groates, wherof no man knoweth, & I meane to lay vp there twenty more, which I would haue you to take & to employ at your plea≈øure, be≈øtowing ≈øome part therof for my ≈øoules health as it is conuenient. When yt clark hard this, he went & layd the twenty pouÃÑd in the place againe where he had it, hoping to haue the other twenty pound al≈øo. But the blind man comming to church very early in the morning, tooke awaye the money with him, & ≈øo deceyued the clarke that had deceiued him.Of the blind man that bid his vvife ≈øet a caÃÑdle light before him. A certaine blind man, coÃÑmaunded his wyfe alwayes to ≈øet a candle a light by him. On a tyme the wyfe being offended at him, di≈øcouered her naked tayle and ≈øo ≈øtoode before him. Then ≈øayd he, wyfe is there a candle a light in the hou≈øe? yea quod ≈øh√©e: Surely ≈øayd he, if there be neuer a better, yet is there a brighter.Of the blind man that turned the goo≈øe. A blind man & his wife had a fat goo≈øe to dinner, & while the wife was gone forth about bu≈øines, & the blind man turned the ≈øpyt, there came a good fellowe into the hou≈øe, which he hearing & thinking it to be a dog, ro≈øe vp to ratle the di≈øhes to driue him away. In the meane whiles this felow ≈øtole away the goo≈øe, & put a great browne loafe which ≈øtoode there by vpon the ≈øpyt, & departed, and he turned the loafe about verye
dilygently. But when the good wyfe came in, he chyd her ≈øharply for leauing ye doore open, for ≈øayd he, there came in a dog euen now, & had I not mooued the di≈øhes to driue him away, he would haue done ≈øome harme. O hu≈øband ≈øayd ≈øhee, it was no dog, but ≈øome theefe, and he hath ≈øtollen away the goo≈øe.Of tvvo that vvere eating a ioule of ≈øammon. One yt had but one eye was eating of a iowle of SaÃÑmon with another yt had two eies, who being ready to eate ye SaÃÑmons eye, he yt had but one eye cried vnto him ≈øaying, for Gods ≈øake giue me that eye for thou lacke≈øt none, and I haue but one.

div.head: Chap. 22. Merye ie≈øtes of fooles.
div.p:
THere was a merry companion that ≈øayde there were fowre kindes of fooles.of foure kinde ‚Ä¢ of fooles. The fir≈øt of theÃÑ that threaten ≈øo much yt no maÃÑ careth for them. The ≈øecond, that ≈øweareth ≈øo much yt none wyl beleue them. The third, yt giueth ≈øo much away to others yt they k√©epe nothing for them ≈øelues. The fourth,
Of the foole that vvept vvhen the ≈øun did shine „Äà‚óä„Äâ laughed ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n it ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d.
„Äà‚óä„Äâ foole L ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ inu ‚Ä¢ tha ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e not him≈øelfe vvhen hee had on his „Äà‚óä„Äâ coat ‚Ä¢ . yt hauing none to helpe them, wyl not helpe them ≈øelues. There was a foole, who when he ≈øaw the Sunne to ≈øhyne wept, & when it rayned, laughed: & being a≈øked why he dyd ≈øo, an≈øwered that rayne coÃÑ meth after the Sunne ≈øhyning, & therefore he wept: and when it rayned he knewe that afterward the Sunne would ≈øhine, & therefore he laughed. There was a foole called Lobellinus, who vpon a time putting on a new coate knew not him ≈øelfe, & weÃÑt about inquyring of euery body if they ≈øaw not Lobellinus? Then one raught him a good ≈øow≈øe on the eare, ≈øaying, this I giue not to thee but to Lobellinus, & therewith he remembred him≈øelf who he was. A Lord gaue his foole a new caote wheron were imbroidred a great many A≈ø≈øes heads. TheÃÑ a ≈øtrange ‚Ä¢ ≈ø√©eing him, ≈øayd vnto him: It apeareth yt thou art a foole,
„Äà‚óä„Äâ foole that had ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
coate imbroidered with A≈ø≈øe ‚Ä¢ heads. bicau≈øe thou weare≈øt ≈øo many A≈ø≈øes heads vpon thy coate, which ye foole hearing, went vnto ye Lord his ma≈øter & byd him take his coate again, for he would not weare it. Why ≈øo quod ye Lord bicau≈øe ye make≈øt mee a foole, ≈øayde he, in putting A≈ø≈øes heads vpon my coate. No ≈øaid ye Lord, they be deeres heads. Deeres heads, qoud the foole, where be the hornes? Then ≈øayd ye Lord, they haue no hornes yet for they be fawnes, & with that an≈øwere ye foole was contented, & ≈øo he an≈øwered vnto who≈øoeuer mocked him therwith. Frederick the Emperor was wont to ≈øay, that they were „Äà‚óä„Äâ mo≈øt fooles in all the world, that bel√©eue the puni≈øhmentes
and rewardes that ≈øhall be in the worlde to come, and yet lyue ≈øtyll in theyr ≈øinnes.Of the foole that hyd his money in the hole. A certaine fooli≈øhe fellow hauing a lytle money, hyd it in a hole, & couered it with a ≈øtone, wherevpon he wrote: here it is. Another comming by, and reading the ≈øuper≈øcription, and maruayling what it ≈øhould ≈øignifye, ouerturned the ≈øtone & caryed away the money, and layde the ≈øtone againe in his place, and wrote vpon it: It is not here.

div.head: Chap. 23. Merye ie≈øtes of tho≈øe that are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed.
div.p: Of a mayde that vvas po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed vvith an euil ≈øpirite.A Mayd in VVe≈øtphalia which was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a ≈øpirite di≈øputed with euery one yt came to her in what ≈øcience ≈øoeuer, which a certaine ma≈øter of Art, that came lately froÃÑ Paris hearing, came vnto her. To whom ≈øayd the Deuyl: thou comme≈øt lately from the vyllage of ≈øtraw, therefore tell m√©e the quantity & quality of this propo≈øition: Euery hor≈øe is a mare. Wherfore he being amazed,Of the hu≈øbandman that a≈øked the Deuyll hovve many children hee had. departed immediatly. When a certaine maÃÑ of the cuntrey demaunded of one that was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, how many chyldren he had: the Deuyll an≈øwered that he had one. Nowe it appeareth quod the hu≈øbandman, that thou art a lyar, for I haue twayne? Nay ≈øayd the Deuyl, I haue told true, for one of them is not thine, but a Prie≈øtes. A Prie≈øt being defamed with a certaine woman, promi≈øed a deuil that if he would helpe him in his purgation, he would giue him a ≈øufficient rewarde. Then the Deuil promi≈øed him yt if he haply ≈øhould be ≈øearched, it ≈øhould not appeare at all that he had any meÃÑbers. But when the tyme came, and he had ≈øtryped him≈øelfe naked, it was of all manife≈øtly ≈ø√©ene that he had as much as was requi≈øite for any man to haue. Thus wee may ≈øee howe they are deceyued that put theyr tru≈øt in the Deuyll.Of one that coÃÑmitted his vvife to the Deuyls cu≈øtody vvhile he vvas froÃÑ home. One that was going awaye from his wyfe bicau≈øe of her naughtine≈ø≈øe, meant not to take leaue at his departure. Then ≈øayd his wyfe vnto him, to whom ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ll you commyt m√©e in your ab≈øence: to the Deuyl quod he, & immediatly he went on his iourney. But when he was gone, & her louers according to theyr cu≈øtome came to the hou≈øe, the Deuyll alwayes frayd them away. Long tyme after when the hu≈øbande came home againe, now take thou the charge of thy wyfe againe, quod the Deuyl vnto him, for I had rather k√©epe all the wylde boores in the whole countrey, then her onely.

One that was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, coÃÑmyng through the Market place in a Citie, fell thri≈øe in a laughter:Of one po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed that fell thri≈øe a laughing in the market place. and being demaunded the cau≈øe, an≈øwered: the fir≈øt was, becau≈øe he ≈øawe a man bying ≈øhooes and a Capon, and too day he ≈øhall die (quod he) for all he hath bought them. The ≈øecond was, becau≈øe he ≈øaw a Bayliff leadyng a poore th√©efe to hanging that had ≈øtollen a trifle, ≈øaying, that it was a ≈øtrange matter to ≈ø√©e a great theefe leadyng a litle theife to the gallowes.

Thirdly bicau≈øe hee ≈øaw a Prie≈øt following a childe that was going to burying, ≈øinging, and a hu≈øbandman cumming after, weeping, when as in deede (quoth h√©e) it ought to haue bin otherwi≈øe, as namelye the Prie≈øt to haue wept who≈øe ≈øunne h√©e was, and the hu≈øbandman to haue ≈øunge as beeing di≈øcharged of a great burthen. The Diuell ≈øpake in one that was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, ≈øayinge: In hell there is no redemption, and therefore man is very vnwi≈øe that will hazard ≈øo noble a pleadg, which if it bee forfeited can neuer more b√©e red√©emed. One vpon occa≈øion of talke ≈øaid to his fellow. I maruell ≈øayd h√©e, that the Diuell ≈øuffreth vs to liue, ≈øince w√©e bee all ≈øutch grieuous ≈øinners? to whom the other an≈øwered, but I maruel rather why h√©e hurteth not his ≈øeruants.

div.head: Chap. 24. Of Popes and their mery Ie≈øtes.
div.p: IT is read in the Cronicles that when the Pope is con≈øecrated,The manner of con≈øecrating Popes. as they terme it, ther is a great handful of Towe ≈øet on fire in pre≈øence of them al, & therwith al the≈øe woords ≈øpoken: Thus pa≈ø≈øeth the glory of the world, remember that thou art a≈øhes and a mortal man. A good le≈ø≈øon if they would follow it.
Sergius the Pope was called before h√©e was Pope Os porci, Of Pope Hogs mouth that is to ≈øay, Hogs mouth, and ≈øince his time all Popes haue changed their owne proper names.

Euari≈øtus the Pope, appointed ≈øeauen deacons to gward the Popes per≈øon whyle h√©e preacheth, which I thinke is but ≈øeldome,Of the Pope ‚Ä¢ preaching. or to a≈øi≈øt him that h√©e erre not, wherby h√©e might come into obloquie, and b√©e diffamed by his aduer≈øaries, Adrian the Pope with the whole a≈ø≈øembly of Cardinals, By≈øhops, and prelates, and all the Synode gaue vp all the aucthority vnto
Charles king of Rome, to chu≈øe and appoincte who ≈øhoulde bee Pope. And moreouer that all Archby≈øhops ≈øhoulde receiue their inue≈øture of him, and that all that were di≈øobedient vnto this decree ≈øhould bee accur≈øed: mutch repugnant vnto that wherin the Popes will take vpon them to make, and depo≈øe Emperours at their plea≈øure.

div.head: Chap. 25. Of Cardinals and their mery Ie≈øtes.
div.p: how the Pope ≈øent for frier Tortus, to make his Neece conceiue. OCtauianus a Cardinal, cau≈øed the Pope to ≈øend for one frier Tortus to Lions, that had very good knowledg in Phi≈øick. And when he was come vnto him, ye frier demaunded ye cau≈øe why hee ≈øent for him. The Pope an≈øwered, I haue a N√©ece that hath bin this long married, and can haue neuer a childe, and I haue ≈øent for you bicau≈øe you are a Phi≈øitioÃÑ, to do your indeuour to make her conceiue. Then an≈øwered, the Frier, your hollines is hoate, younge, and lu≈øtye you ≈øhould ≈øooner make her to conceiue then I can: wherat the Pope laughing tooke him to be his chaplein.

How two Prie≈øtes ≈øtriued for a benefice.Two Prie≈øtes ≈øtriuinge before the Cardinals for the Mai≈øter≈øhip of a certain ho≈øpitall, it is a ≈øtrange matter to ≈øe quod one of the Cardinals, how you two poore fellowes and vnlearded, can not agree for one ≈øimple Mai≈øter≈øhip of an ho≈øpitall. Nay, ≈øayd one of the Prie≈øts, it is more maruell to beeholde how you ritche prelates and learned men are at ≈øutch contention for one great Popedome. A certein Cardinall hearing of a frier yt alwaies preached again≈øt prelates, would needes haue him to preach in his audience, and h√©e did ≈øo. Then taking occa≈øion to ≈øpeake of Cardinals, hee ≈øaid that the Lords Cardinals were ≈øo termed of this Latin woord cardo which ≈øignifieth the hinge of a doore.Of a Pr ‚Ä¢ e≈øte that preached again≈øt Cardinals. For like as the hinges of a doore lacking oyle do alwayes murmour and make a noy≈øe, but beeinge oyled do open an ≈øhut very plea≈øantly: ≈øo fareth it with the≈øe Cardinals, for vntill they haue promotion they neuer leaue prechinge and cryinge out at couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe and ambition, and when they haue to mutch then they preach no more, but grea≈øe their bellies with dilicates and giue them≈øelues wholy to all voluptuou≈øne≈ø≈øe.

A certein Cardinall had a chaplein called Michael whom
hee promi≈øed that if euer God called him to greater dignitye,Of a Cardinall to p ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ his Chaplein. hee would prefer him to his contentacion. Afterward beeing made Pope and troubled with many affayres, hee quite forgat his old Chaplein Michael. Who ≈øeeing that he could haue no acce≈ø≈øe vnto the Pope, wrote vpon a doore by the whiche hee ≈øhould pa≈ø≈øe, the≈øe ver≈øes following.

q.l: Here ≈øtandeth without before the doore, Michael the Chaplein pore,
Saying that honours do manners change,
But ≈øeld to better, for that were ≈øtrange.

div.p: Which the Pope reading, and ≈øeeing him ≈øtanding before the doore, remembred his promi≈øe, & gaue him a good benefice.

div.head: Chap. 26. Of Archbi≈ø≈øhops and their mery Ie≈øts.
div.p:
A Certein Archby≈ø≈øhop preachinge vpon Palme Sundaye di≈øcour≈øed very much of Chri≈øtes humility,Of the bi≈ø≈øhop that preached of the ≈øhee a≈ø≈øe that Chri≈øt ‚Ä¢ rid vpon. and of the ≈øhee A≈ø≈øe whereupon hee rode. And when the ≈øermon was done, he mounted vp vpon his lofty palfry, and was ridinge home. Then came an olde woman running, and tooke the hor≈øe by ye bridle ≈øaying, I pray you my Lord, is this the ≈øhee a≈ø≈øe whervpon Chri≈øt roade? An Archby≈ø≈øhop in a ≈øermon ≈øorely inveied again≈øt ye whole order of Preaching friers, & compared them to the Phara≈øies. When the ≈øermon was fini≈øhed,Of the Archby≈ø≈øhop tha ‚Ä¢ preached again≈øt the friers. and the Archby≈ø≈øhop come down out of the Pulpit, the reader of the ≈øame couent aro≈øe and came to him ≈øaying: My Lord, your grace had forgotten one text which is this: Thy Nacion and thy By≈ø≈øhops haue deliuered thee vnto me. Againe, the ≈øame Archby≈ø≈øhop preached another time again≈øt Ma≈øters & Readers in the vniuer≈øities,Of an Archby≈ø≈øhop tha ‚Ä¢ preached again≈øt may≈øters. how they clothed them≈øelues in ≈øofte apparell, and ≈øought to bee magnified and placed in the chiefe ≈øeates in the ≈øcooles, and Churches, and ≈øutch like. Shortly after the ≈øame Archby≈ø≈øhop chanced to meete with a Reader, in a very foule and dirty place. Then ≈øaid the Archby≈ø≈øhop to the Reader, what do you here Ma≈øter Ammirandu ‚Ä¢
? for that was his name: Mary my Lord (quoth he) I come to make cleane & neate mine apperell wherof your Grace ≈øpake of late and therewith all he ≈øhewed him his tayle all dirty behinde.

An Archbi≈øhop beeyng in vi≈øitation, ≈øharply puni≈øhed a certayn Lady Priore≈ø≈øe of a Nunrie for tre≈øpaces which ≈øhe had
committed,Of an Archebi≈øhop that puni≈øhed the Lady priores. whom ≈øh√©e earne≈øtly intreated that in con≈øideration of a piece of money, hee would in part remit the puni≈øhment. But he deneying ≈øo to do, ≈øaying, that he loued her not, and therfore he would not plea≈øure her ≈øo mutch: I thinke ≈øo quoth ≈øhe, and wel bel√©eue it, for there was neuer yet Capon that loued an Hen.

div.head: Chap. 27. Of By≈øhops, and their mery ie≈øtes.
div.p:
Of one that flattered a bi≈øhop for ad
‚Ä¢ antage.ONe thinkyng to get the goodwill of a By≈øhop by flatterie, ≈øaid vnto him, my Lord, if your Lord≈øhip would take le≈ø≈øe paines you might liue yet fiue y√©eres, but if you continued ≈øo ≈øtill you will ≈øcarce liue two y√©eres to an end. Who an≈øwered, I had rather be a good Bi≈øhop two yeres, then an ill By≈øhop fiue y√©eres.

Of one that obiected again≈øt a bi≈øhop bicau≈øe he was couetous.One obiected vnto a Bi≈øhop, that he was to couetous, for that by keping a nigardly hou≈øe, he had ≈øaued mony enough to red√©eme his Church lands which his predice≈ø≈øour had layd to morgage. But he an≈øwered that he was far more liberal then his predice≈ø≈øour, for (≈øayd he) I haue payd his debts and mine owne al≈øo.

Of a bi≈øhop that promi≈øed to giue a Prebend at the kinges appointmentA Bi≈øhop in France, promi≈øed Philip the French Kynge, yt the fir≈øt Prebend yt fell in his gift, he would giue it to whome ≈øoeuer it plea≈øed the Kynge. And when many fell voyde, and the kyng was plea≈øured with none, he was ≈øore offended. To whom ye Bi≈øhop ≈øent this an≈øwer, de≈øiring his grace not to be offended, for he had yet giuen neuer an one of them, but ≈øould them all.

Of a Bi≈øhop that cour≈øed a Hart.The Bi≈øhop of Mentz cour≈øed an Hart, and after long ruÃÑ nyng, the bea≈øt leapt into a deepe ponde, and a greate Pike caught him fa≈øt by the throat. And when the Hart came out of the water, hee brought the Pike with him hanginge by his throat, and ≈øo h√©e tooke them bothe, and ≈øent pieces of them abread for pre≈øent to his friends.

A prie≈øt rebuked by the Bi≈øhop for buryinge a ‚Ä¢ ead A≈ø≈øe.A certain Prie≈øt was accu≈øed vnto the bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe for buriyng his dead A≈ø≈øe ≈øolemly with Dirige, & Ma≈ø≈øes of Requiem. And b√©eing much rebuked for ≈øo doing he certified the Bi≈øhop that it was a very godly A≈ø≈øe, & had made a will, & had bequea ‚Ä¢ hed his Lord≈øhip fiue pounde, which he had now
brought vnto him. And when the Bi≈øhop had receiued the money, he ≈øaid, let him then re≈øt in peace, & ≈øo di≈øcharged ye prie≈øt.

A noble younge Gentlemen that was a ≈øchollar in Paris, A gentilman that ≈øaid all bi≈øhops were blinde. ≈øayd that all Bi≈øhops in France were blinde, bicau≈øe they gaue not ≈øom good benefice to his mai≈øter, beyng but poore, and well learned. Not long after, being him≈øelf made a Bi≈øhop, he was ≈øo blinded with his ≈øpirituall promotion, that he neither gaue his poore mai≈øter any thing, but on a time when he came to Paris, his Mai≈øter went and met him, bearyng a couple of Waxe candles burnyng in his hand. And when the Bi≈øhop a≈øked him why h√©e did ≈øo: h√©e an≈øwered, bycau≈øe your lord≈øhip ≈øhould s√©e m√©e, for you are blinde.Of a Bi≈øhop that preferred his kin≈øfolke,

A certain Bi≈øhop had many yonge Nephewes and Kin≈øfolkes in his hou≈øe, which alwaies ≈øat at meate at a low table before him, and when≈øoeuer any preferment fell voyde, he repul≈øed other, and be≈øtowed it vpon one of tho≈øe. Then a man of wor≈øhip, whom the Bi≈øhop had bid to dinner, ≈øet him≈øelf downe at the childrens Table. And b√©eing demaunded by the Bi≈øhop why h√©e did ≈øo, h√©e an≈øwered that h√©e could not be preferred ≈øittyng at any other Table, neither knew he any other then tho≈øe that ≈øat there, aduanced by him vnto any dignitie.

div.head: Chap. 28. Of Archdeacons.
div.p: AN Archdeacon being in vi≈øitatioÃÑ,Of a woman that told the Archdeacon, he did not his dutie. ≈øpent whole daies in fea≈øting & making good ch√©ere, when the people looked that he ≈øhould haue preached vnto them the word of God. And as hee was going from hearyng Ma≈ø≈øe vnto dinner, an olde woman ≈øayd vnto him yt they looked for that which was his dutie to do meaning, to ≈øhew them their duties out of the word of God. Well (quoth the Archdeacon) I will not call th√©e to coun≈øell what I had be≈øt to do. But ≈øh√©e an≈øwered, ≈øurely he had ≈ømall care of our ≈øoules that put them in tru≈øt to th√©e.

An Archdeacon vi≈øited his pari≈øh Church,Of a maÃÑ tha ‚Ä¢ had a poore woman to his wife, a≈øked the Archdeacon if h ‚Ä¢ might not marry another that was „Äà‚óä„Äâ . from which h√©e was promoted vnto the Archdeaconrie. And there came vnto him an hu≈øband man to a≈øke coun≈øell, ≈øaying: M. Archdeacon I married a poore wife, and now I know where I may haue a ritch one, is it lawful for m√©e to f ‚Ä¢ r≈øake the poore one, and to take the ritche? The Archdeacon an≈øwered, by no meanes.
Then ≈øaid ye hu≈øbandmaÃÑ, but you haue for≈øaken a poore church and keepe a ritch Archdeaconry. Which he hearing, gaue vp his Archdeaconry, and returned to his owne Churche.

Of a Prie≈øt that killed a younge A≈ø≈øe in ≈øteede of a Calfe, &c.A certein Prie≈øt again≈øt his Archdeacon ≈øhoulde come in vi≈øitacion, hauinge none other proui≈øion, killed a litle A≈ø≈øe which hee had, and dre≈ø≈øed him in the ≈øtead of Veale, and wheÃÑ the Archdeacon fead hungerly theron at dinner and ye Prie≈øt him≈øelfe woulde eate none, the Archdeacon demaunded the cau≈øe. Then quod the Prie≈øt, your Ma≈øter≈øhip ≈øaith yt I haue wit and learning litle ynough already, and therefore I neede to eate no a≈ø≈øes flea≈øh. When the Archdeacon heard this, he aro≈øe from the table in a rage, and immediatly departed.

div.head: chap. 29. Of Canons and their mery Ie≈øts.
div.p: Of the Chanceler of Paris that had manie benefices. IVlius in his booke of Bees, writeth an hi≈øtory of one Philip that was Chancellour of Paris, who hauing many benefices was in his ≈øicknes admoni≈øhed by the By≈ø≈øhop to re≈øigne theÃÑ vp, for feare of longer incurring Gods di≈øplea≈øure: who an≈øwered that hee would try the truth of that, b√©efore the greate iudge. But ≈øhortly after hee was dead, hee appeared vnto the By≈ø≈øhop like a ≈øhadow, and ≈øayd: I mo≈øt mi≈øerable wretch am damned, and that cheifly for thr√©e cau≈øes: Fir≈øt for my fruites which I kept from the poore: Secondly for my pluralitye of benefices: And la≈øtly for my dete≈øtable whoredome. Moreouer hee ≈øayd, is the world yet at an end? Then quod the By≈ø≈øhop, I marueill that thou hauinge in thy life time beene a great clarke, and ≈øeeing mee and other liuing, who mu≈øt all die beefore that day come, ≈øhoulde≈øt a≈øke mee that que≈øtion? But hee ≈øayd marueill not at all, for in hell there is neither knowlegde, nor rea≈øon. Mai≈øter Albertus ≈øayd vnto a Canon of Colein, Of the CaroÃÑ that had got a di≈øpen≈øatioÃÑ, for many benefices. which came home from the Court with a di≈øpen≈øation to haue many benefices: Before you might haue gone to Hell without licence, and now you mu≈øt n√©edes go thither by vertue of your di≈øpen≈øation.

There was a Canon which had two Canonries, one in one Church, another in another, ye dreamed one night ye two ≈øtaues were reatched vnto him, and the ≈øame night ye bi≈øhops of both Churches died. Then ≈øome of his familiars expounding
his dreame, ≈øaid that he ≈øhould be cho≈øen bi≈øhop in both places and riding out the next day morninge, he fell from his hor≈øe and brake both his legges, and was faine to go with two crutches to beare him≈øelft vp withall.

div.head: Chap. 30. Of the Hault and Lame.
div.p: ON a time there came vnto a ≈øanctes church,How a prie≈øt did driue the hault and lame out of the Churche. ≈øo many hault and Lame people to be cured, yt the Prie≈øt could not driue them foorth. Then ≈øaid the prie≈øt, giue me your ≈øtaues & I wil heale you all. And when he had them, he ≈øent for fier, & beinge demaunded what he would do with it: Burne him yt is mo≈øt lambe, quoth he, that you may all be healed with his A≈ø≈øhes. And when they heard this, they ran all away.

div.head: Cap. 31. Of Prie≈øts.
div.p: A Certain poore lecherous Prie≈øt had a concubine,Of a prie≈øt that lo≈øt his Concubine and, his benefice together. whom he loued well, wherof the Archedeacon hearing, commanded him either to for≈øake his Church, or to leaue his concubin But being loth to depart from his Concubine, he re≈øigned his benefice, and when the harlot ≈øaw that he had nothing now to liue withall, ≈øhe would tarie no lenger with him, and ≈øo he lo≈øt both profit and plea≈øure together.

A certein Prie≈øt had two Concubines, one yonge,Of a prie≈øt that had an yonge and an old concubin another olde: The younge bicau≈øe ≈øhe would haue the Prie≈øt to be like her≈øelfe, pluckt all the gray heares out of his head, and the olde pluckt away al the blacke, vntill betw√©en them both thei had made him bald, not only in head, but al≈øo in his goods, and minde.

A poore aged woman, being weake and like to die, bequeathed vnto a Prie≈øt one Hen which ≈øh√©e had,Of a poore woman that bequeathed her Hen. to b√©e deliuered after her departure. But the Prie≈øt came and tooke away the Hen while ≈øhe was yet liuinge. Then ≈øayde the olde woman, I perceiue that Prie≈øts b√©e wor≈øe then the Diuell, for many a time haue I giuen my Hen to the Diuell, & the Foxe and they haue letten her alone, and now haue giuen her but once to a Prie≈øt, and h√©e taketh her away.

There was a Prie≈øt which v≈øed to cary holy water, as they termed it, about vnto his friends & pari≈øhoners hou≈øes, &, wheÃÑ
he came to a certein ritchmans hou≈øe,Of the „Äà‚óä„Äâ that had „Äà‚óä„Äâ legge. he was ≈øure of nothing els but rayling, cur≈øes, and euil language. It fortuned that he caught a ≈øore in one of his legges, and at the Prie≈øts next cuÃÑ mynge thither, he ma ‚Ä¢ e him good cheere, and de≈øired him to pray for him. Then quod the Prie≈øt, I pray God ≈øende your other legge to bee ≈øore al≈øo, that you may bee more deuoute. Which the ritch man hearinge, well bumba≈øted the Prie≈øt, and with ≈øtrayning his leg found the pain to be ea≈øed. This or the like is alwaye the end of vngodly prayers.

div.head: Chap. 32. Of Abbots and their Ie≈øts.
div.p: Of one Ar≈øemus, that ≈øent both his Scholers to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e Abbots.IT is read in the booke intitled vitae patrum, that it belonged vnto the duty of one Ar≈øenius an Abbot, alwayes to prouide an Abbot for a certein Mona≈øtarie beeing de≈øtitute, who ≈øent vnto them a ≈øchollar of his owne bringynge vp, one that was religious and ≈øeuere. But when the Munkes could not away with him, he ≈øent them another yt was calme & gentle, & finding him to be ≈øoft and tractable, thei yet mi≈øliked him and required another. Then ≈øaid Ar≈øenius, I haue ≈øent you twayne, whom I my ≈øelf haue bought vp, and I know that neither of them is de≈øtitute of the grace of ye holy gho≈øt, who appeared in the forme of fire, & of a Doue, and in none other likene≈ø≈øe yt I haue heard: And therfore I can prouide you none other.

Of an Abbot that came ‚Ä¢ uddinly among his munkes,A certein Abbot came ≈øuddeinly vpon a company of Munks as they were talkinge, & when they ≈øaw him, they were aba≈ø≈øhed. Then ≈øayd the Abbot, wherof were you talkyng? Whervnto one yt had the redie≈øt wit among them an≈øwered, of your Lord≈øhip. And what ≈øaid you of me, qouth the Abbot? Surely we were talkyng, ≈øaid the Munke, how you and other Abbots can ≈øo ≈øoone waxe euill. Mary an≈øwered the Abbot, bicau≈øe wee be made of ≈øo ill ≈øtuffe, that is to ≈øay, of Monkes.

Of an Abbot that was by his munkes dep ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ued of his dignity.An Abbot being in the Chapter hou≈øe among the Munkes, ≈øaid that he had no plea≈øure nor re≈øt, but payn & vexacion both of body & minde in the office, & that he was no lord, but rather their ≈øeruant and vnderling. To whom the munkes an≈øwered: Mid≈øummer and the fea≈øt of S. John the Bapti≈øt is now at hand, go play thy ≈øelf ≈øumwhere els, for wee will haue thy ≈øeruice no longer, and ≈øo depriued him of his office.

The Abbots roome of S. Denni≈øe in France being voyde,Of three munckes that gaue to the king fiue ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ po ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a peece, to haue the Abbotship of S. Denys. and the tyme of the election drawing neere, the Prouo≈øt of the ≈øame hou≈øe, offred vnto the king fiue hundred pound for his good wyl, the Chamberlayne as much, and the Sellerer as much al≈øo: all whiche money hee ≈øeuerally willed them to deliuer vnto his Chamberlaine. When the day appointed for the election was come, and the king was ≈øat downe vnder his cloth of e≈øtate, tho≈øe three aboue named gaping euery one for the preferment, the king called vnto him a ≈øimple Munke which ≈øate in a corner, and made him Abbot: who alleaging his in≈øufficiencie for it, and the worthynes of many other in the Couent: the king ≈ømiling, I wyl ≈øupply your want, quod bee, and giue you fifteene hundred poundes toward your charges, (which was the Prouo≈øtes, Sellerers, and Chamberlaines money.) and be≈øides helpe you with the be≈øt coun≈øell and ayde otherwy≈øe that I can.Of a mery demaund that the Abbot of Paris asked the ≈øcholemen. An Abbot of Paris, comming into the ≈øchooles at the Quodlibets, demaunded this que≈øtion, whether it were better to knowe a litle good and to followe it, or to know much and follow nothing? It was an≈øwered that the fir≈øt was the be≈øt. Then, quod the Abbot, you b√©e all fooles, that learne many ≈øciences and followe none.

div.head: Chap. 33. Of Priours and of their merie Ie≈øtes.
div.p:
IN the Priorie of Rame≈ø≈øa there dwelt a Priour that was very liberal, which cau≈øed the≈øe ver≈øes to be written euer his doore:Of the liberall priour of Rame≈ø≈øa.
Be open euermore, √¥ thou my doore,
To none bee ≈øhut, to hone≈øt or to poore.

But after his death, there ≈øucc√©eded him another who≈øe name was Raynhard, as gr√©edie and couetous, as the other was bountifull and liberall, who kept the ≈øame ver≈øes there ≈øtil, changing nothing therein but onely one point, and made them runne after this manner:
Bee open euermore √¥ thou my doore
To none, bee ≈øhut to hone≈øt or to poore.

Afterwarde b√©eing driuen from thence for his extreme niggi≈øhne≈ø≈øe, it grewe into a prouerbe: that for one point Raynhard lo≈øt his Priorie. A Priour hauing ghea≈øtes to dinner, cau≈øed his
≈øeruauntes to mingle water with the wyne,
Of a Priour that ≈øerued his ghea≈øtes vvith vvine mingled vvith vvater.
Of a Priour that told his MuÃÑkes, that he vvas like to God in ‚Ä¢ . qualities.
Of the Munke that di≈øplied the Priour vvith hard blovves to the intent it might ≈øtretche the farther. And perceiuing one of the Munkes to b√©e very talkatiue, and full of wordes, ≈øayde vnto him: Brother when wyll your myll leaue clacking? It cannot leaue ≈øir, quod the Munke, as long as ye geue it ≈øo muche water. A Priour ≈øayd vnto one of his Munkes, that he was lyke vnto God into thr√©e qualities: Fir≈øt that he could not ≈øinne, for that he defended ≈øo much his owne innocencie at t ‚Ä¢ eyr Chapters: Next in knowing althinges, for hee went about from ≈øhop to ≈øhoppe to learne newe; what was done or ≈øayd in any place: And thirdly in b√©eing in euery place, for he wandred very much abroade. A certayne Munke di≈øplying the Priour and others after Complin, ≈øtroke very harde blowes vpon the Priours head. But m√©eting afterwarde at the Chapiter, the Priour ≈øayde vnto the Munke: Brother, you know not yet wel how to di≈øplie. But when you di≈øple the Priour, you mu≈øt ≈øtrike hand≈øomely and gently, and not thus, and thus, and buffeted him well fauouredly about the eares, and ≈øo was euen with the Munke for his hard di≈øplying.

div.head: Chap. 34. Of many merie Ie≈øtes of Munkes.
div.p:
Of the yong Munke that douckt alvvaies dovvnvvard till he had founde the keies of the Abbey.
Of an olde Munke that fell a ≈øleepe in the quire.
Of him that bid the Munke to drinke, vvheÃÑ he vvas in his prayers. SOmetyme there was a young Munke in an Abbey, who alwayes went ca≈øting his eyes to the grounde, and was very milde and lowly in behauiour. Afterwarde beyng made Priour, hee helde vp his h ‚Ä¢ ad aloft‚ñ™ and was very ≈øeuere and arrogant, which ≈øeeming ≈øtrange vnto them that knew him before, & being demaunded the cau≈øe of ≈øo great alteratioÃÑ: An≈øwered, that before he alwaies looked on the earth for the keies of ye Abbey, if haply hee might find them: which now hauing found, he looked no more on the ground, but beare him≈øelf according to the dignitie wherunto he was called. An old Munke ≈øitting in ye quire‚ñ™ fell a ≈øl√©epe, and dreamed that there came vnto him a foule long ≈ølouen with ≈øuch a filthy wi≈øpe as they v≈øe to rub hor≈øes withal, and looking grimly vpon hym, would forcibly haue wyped his face therewith. But hee ≈øtriuing to e≈øcape from him, pluckt backe his head and knocked it agayn≈øt the wal, and ≈øo awaked. A Munke being deuout in his prayers, one a≈øked him if he would drinke, who
wagged his finger, ≈øignifiyng that h√©e would not. Then ≈øayd the Munkes ≈øeruaunt, my ma≈øter meaneth that he would drinke a cup of white wine. But when the Munke beck ‚Ä¢ ned with two fingers, ≈øignifiyng that he would haue none at all, and it was demaunded of his ≈øeruaunt what hee ment therby, hee an≈øwered that hee would al≈øo haue-a cup of red wine, ≈øo the ma≈øt ‚Ä¢ r dranke but litle and the knaue dranke vp all the re≈øidue.Of a fellovv that tolde the Munke his a≈ø ‚Ä¢ e beiÃÑg loden vvas able to carry all the pacience in the Abbey. A certayne Munke leading his hor≈øe to the water, ≈øaw a countrey fellowe going ouer a bridge driuing an a≈ø≈øe before him ≈øo heauily laden, that h√©e could ≈øcarce mooue one foote by another, whom the countrey fellowe notwith≈øtanding beate forwarde without pitie or mercy. Then ≈øayd the Munke, why wylt thou kyll thy bea≈øt beeing laden? The fellow an≈øwered, he is not ≈øo laden, but h√©e wyll carrie al the pacience of your Abbey, whereat the Munke was very wrath. Then ≈øayd the fellowe: The dumbe bea≈øt murmureth not vnder his burden,Of the Frier that raÃÑg the bel, and told the Munke he rang for the charitie that vvas gone out of the Abbey. and you are out of patience for one words ≈øpeaking. A certayne Frier comming vnto the gate of an Abbey, ≈ø√©eyng that hee could not get in, range the bell very hard, and a Munke comming to the gate, a≈øked why h√©e range? then ≈øayd the Frier, I ring for the charitie which is gone a way from the Abbey, which the Munke hearing, tooke the bell and range harder then h√©e had done. What meaneth this, then quod the Frier. Then quod the Munke, I ring for the pacience which is departed from your Frierie.

div.head: Chap. 35. Of merie Ie≈øtes of preaching Friers.
div.p:
IT is written in the Cronicles of Friers, that after the Lateran coun≈øell, when the Pope traueyled into the coa≈øtes of Toledo, Hovv the Pope vvrit to Dominicke the preaching Frier. about certayne affayres, and would write vnto Dominick the Frier: h√©e ≈øayd vnto the Notarie, write vnto Dominick the Frier, and to the re≈øidue of the preaching Friers. Then ≈øtaying a while: write quod hee, vnto ma≈øter Dominick, and to the preaching Friers: and after that tyme they began to b√©e called the preaching Friers. A certayne Frier to≈ø≈øing the pot,Of the Frie ‚Ä¢ that ≈øaid he mu≈øt drinke after euerie good vvorde and drinking very often at the table, was reprehended by the Priour. Then ≈øayd the Frier. It is an olde prouerbe, that a man ought
to drinke after a good ≈øaying. And there were ≈øo many read euen now,Of the frier that bid the officiall if he vvere the ≈øonne of God to make the ≈øtones bread. that there is not wine ynough to drinke after them all: for at that tyme the booke of the prouerbes of Salomon was read at the table. One ma≈øter Hugh, an Officiall, hauing a Frier at his table at dinner, and ≈øeeing that he could not eate of the bread becau≈øe it was ≈øo harte, a≈øked of him why he dyd not eate? to whom the Frier an≈øwered: If thou bee the Sonne of GOD, commaunde the≈øe ≈øtones to bee made bread. Frier Nicholas of Bron≈øbarch, an auncient & ‚Ä¢ reuerend father would often declare, how he was the Duke of Sa ‚Ä¢ ons ≈øonne,Hovv frier Nicolas of Bronsbarch ≈øaid he vvas the duke of Saxons ‚Ä¢ onne. and after this manner. The Duke dreamed that the Dutches his wyfe, b√©eing with chylde, ≈øhould beare a chylde that ≈øhould bee poore and a begger, and therefore when ≈øhe was deliuered, hee commaunded the childe to bee ≈ølayne, becau≈øe hee ≈øhoulde not ≈øhame hym. But the Dutches b√©eing mooued with motherly pitie, deliuered her ≈øonne vnto a poore knights wife, to bring vp as her owne, and h√©e encrea≈øed in learning and knowledge, and taking him≈øelfe to bee that poore knightes ≈øonne, h√©e entred into the order, that the Dukes dreame myght be fulfilled. At length when he was made a mai≈øter of his order, and came into Saxonie: the Dutche≈ø≈øe much reioyced in him, and tolde him al the whole matter. Howbeit hee long tyme refu≈øed to credite her, ≈øuppo≈øing him≈øelfe in d√©ede to haue b√©en the poore knightes ≈øonne.

div.head: Chap 36. Of Friers called Minours, and of their merie Ie≈øtes.
div.p:
Hovv a frier that had di≈øplea≈øed the Pope made his an≈øvver.A Certaine Minour Frier had di≈øplea≈øed Boniface the Pope, and by the Friers of the ≈øame order he was deliuered vnto him. Who being brought before the Pope, and de≈øiring pardon, ≈øayde the Pope vnto him, thine owne nation and thy Bi≈øhops haue deliuered thee vnto m√©e. To whom the Frier in his owne defence an≈øweares: He that deliuered mee vnto th√©e, hath the more ≈øinne.Of the vvomaÃÑ that bequethed her garment to the minor friers. At which an≈øweare the Pope being delited, ≈øent him away free. A certen woman of Brun≈øwik, bequeathed vnto the Minour Friers (of who≈øe fraternitie ≈øh√©e was,) one garment
worth a noble. But wheÃÑ the AntoniaÃÑs came to the towne and preached great pardons and indulgencies of their fraternitie, this woman hearyng thereof, carried hyr garment vnto them, which they receyued with great thanks. Which when the Minors vnder≈øtoode: they blamed hyr much for ≈øo doing, who made them an≈øweare that all fraternities were one fraternitie. Then the Minours vnder≈øtanding that the Antonians had there in the towne a S. Antonies pig, that was fat and worth a marke, they tooke him home to theyr hou≈øe and killed him. And when the Antonians complayned thereof, for that it was to great an iniurie, the Minours an≈øweared that the pigge belonged vnto their fraternitie, for that all fraternities are one fraternitie. In the ende the matter being brought before the iudges of the citie, it was agreed vpon that euery one ≈øhoulde keepe that which he had, and take better h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ de hereafter.

A certaine Minour Frier of Brun≈øwik fell mad, but notwith≈øtanding‚ñ™ Of the frier minor that fell mad. h√©e could helpe to Ma≈ø≈øe. And ≈øeing the Priours man bearing a great Capon in a platter, who≈øe legges hunge a great way ouer the platters ≈øide, he ran vnto him, enquiring of him whether it were a Crane or a Capon? But the ≈øeruant ≈øharply rebuked him away, and would not tell him. In the morning after, when the Priour ≈øhould ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe, he would helpe him. And when the Priour began Confiteor, that is to ≈øay, I confe≈ø≈øe, (a ≈øuper≈øtitious part of the Ma≈ø≈øe:) Now ≈øayd this Frier, tel me whether it were a capon or a Crane which you had ye≈øternight to ≈øupper, el≈øe I will not ab≈øolue you? Then the Priour taking compa≈ø≈øion vpon his follie, ≈øware vnto him by God that it was a capon. Then ≈øaid the Frier, Mi≈øereatur ve≈øtri, &c. God forgiue you, and ≈øo forth, and they proc√©eded in theyr l ‚Ä¢ u≈øines. On a time when many minour Friers comming froÃÑ the Chapter,Of a citezyn that deceyued a company of friers of their good cheere flocked vnto a certayne citizens hou≈øe, carrying with them wyne and other proui≈øion to make good cheere: the towne≈øman vnder≈øtanding therof (for he had b√©en foorth) cau≈øed the Belinan to ring alarme at the doore, and to cry out aloude as though there had b√©en enimies comming, which noy≈øe the Friers hearing, and fearing the lo≈ø≈øe of their hor≈øes, and their almes: in all ha≈øt ga ‚Ä¢ vp into theyr wagons, and rode away as fa≈øt as they could, & the goodman
of the hou≈øe came in, and tooke the wyne and other proui≈øion, which la≈øted him to make merie withall many dayes after,

div.head: Chap. 37. Of diuers merie Ie≈øtes of Nouices.
div.p:
Of the yong nouice that ≈øaide that he neuer read that Chri≈øt vvas either blacke or vvhite or gray frier.
Of the ‚Ä¢ arle of Blaakenburgh ≈øonne that became a Nouice. A Certaine Nouice of ye order of the Preaching Friers, being in place amoÃÑg other Friers where they coÃÑtended of ye excellencie of their orders, euery man preferring his own before the othe ‚Ä¢ : theÃÑ ≈øayd this Nouice, is it true yt euery thing which chri≈øt did is for our in≈øtruction? Y ‚Ä¢ a, ≈øaide the Friers. But I neuer reade, quod the Nouice, that our ≈øauiour Chri≈øte was either a blacke, white, or gray Frier, but hearing that he was a poore Pr ‚Ä¢ acher, I had rather follow his ≈øteppes therein, then any others. The Earle of Blankenburgh hearing that his Sonne, whom he ≈øent vnto Paris to ≈øtudie, was become a Nouice: he roo ‚Ä¢ e thither to bring him from thence. Then ≈øayde his ≈øonne, I would go with you, if you could a≈ø≈øure me of one thing. What is that, quod the father? The ≈øonne an≈øweared: that I may be ≈øure not to die ≈øo ≈øoone when I am abroade, as when I continue here. Which the father hearing, and perceyuing his ob≈øtinacie, with ≈øorow departed,Of a poore mans ≈øonne, that became a Nouice. and let him alone. A certaine poore man had put his ≈øonne to ≈øtud ‚Ä¢ e at Paris, vpon who≈øe maintenaunce he be≈øtowed all that euer he could earne, thinking that he ≈øhould haue kept and relieued him in his old age. But when hee was entred into the order of preachyng Friers, his father weepyng and lamenting thereat, a≈øked him why he had done ≈øo, who an≈øweared, bicau≈øe I woulde liue in pouertie. That might you haue done, ≈øonne, quod the father, if you had ta ‚Ä¢ ied at home with mee, and neuer haue gone out of the doores, for you ≈øhould haue found there pouertie inough. A certaine Nouice entred into the order at Paris, Of the Nouice that vvas annointed vvith lampe oyle. and as he was going to bedde at night, a lampe fell downe and al the oile was ≈øpilt vpon him. Then they brought him vnto his bed, where were wollen ≈øheetes layde vpon a bed of ≈øtraw, and he was commaunded to keepe ≈øilence. The next day morning,Hovv Frier numbert≈øed certaine nouices vvith three peeces of bread. when the other Friers came vnto him, and a≈øked him howe he fared, and was v≈øed ≈øince he came into the order: He an≈øweared, ye≈øternight I was anoynted, and layd vpon ≈øtrawe, and made dumbe. One Frier Humbert a mai≈øter of the order, carrying with him certaine Nouices vnto
Lions, came to a village where they coulde get no meate. At length an old womaÃÑ brought them a litle bread vnto the bridge whereon they ≈øate, whiche when the Nouices had eaten, he a≈øked hir if ≈øhe had any more, and ≈øhe brought another piece, and the younge men eate it immediatly very greedily. The thirde time he willed hyr to fetche more, if ≈øhe had any: which ≈øhe did, and they eate it vp all ≈øtraight wayes. Then ≈øayde the Ma≈øt ‚Ä¢ r vnto the Nouices, he will prouide you bread, that encrea≈øed the fiue loa ‚Ä¢ es in the wildernes, reciting vnto them the whole ≈øtorie out of the Euangeli≈øt, and howe there were twelue ba≈økets fu ‚Ä¢ lle ‚Ä¢ t, ouer and be≈øides that which was eaten. Now by Je≈øus quod the old woman, you be no ≈øuch, for you haue left none at all.

div.head: Chap. 38. Of merie Ie≈øtes of Connertites.
div.p:
A Certaine Conn ‚Ä¢ rti ‚Ä¢ e ≈øeruing in an Abbey,Of the connerti ‚Ä¢ e that mockt the Munkes as they vvere at banket. wayted vpon the Abbot, Priour, and Monkes at a fea≈øt, after that they came from the Chapter, where there was much good cheere prepared. And hauing many di≈ø≈øhes to carrie in, when he had brought in the fir≈øt, he ≈øayd, there is no more, and likewi≈øe at the ≈øecond he ≈øayde, there is no more, and ≈øo at euery one. Then the companie being offended that they had fedde ≈øo much of one di≈øhe, ≈øeing there was plentie, & that they were ≈øo filled that they could not ta≈øt of the other: demaunded of him, why he ≈øayde alwayes at euery di≈øhe that there was no more? In deede, ≈øayde hee, I ≈øpake that woorde, but I meant it not of meate, but of Paradi≈øe. For in this worlde you will weare ≈øoft apparell, eate delicate meates, ride with great traynes, and liue in all plea≈øure, and therefore I meant that you ≈øhall haue no more in the worlde to come. All the Cattell belonging vnto a certaine Mona≈øterie,Of the Connertite that vveÃÑt to fetch the A ‚Ä¢ bots cattel out of the pound. were carried away to the pound a good way of, and the Abbot ≈øent a ≈øimple Connertite whiche was in the hou≈øe, to bring theÃÑ home, coÃÑmaunding him that he ≈øhould not come againe emptie, but bring what ≈øoeuer he could get. But when hee whiche had them in pound, had an≈øweared him that he ≈øhould not haue them, notwith≈øtanding if he woulde ≈øit downe and eate meate with him, he ≈øhould be welcome: he fead very greedely. Which the Ma≈øter of the hou≈øe beholding, and reprouing him ≈øomwhat
therefore: he declared what commaundement was giuen vnto him, and bicau≈øe he could beare nothing el≈øe home with him, he would carrie at lea≈øt wi≈øe as much as his belly would hold. Then all the companie laughed well, and perceyuing the ≈øimplicitie of the man, gaue him all that he required.

div.head: Chap 39. Of many merie Ie≈øtes of Nunnes.
div.p: THe Nunnes of a certaine Mona≈øterie had this cu≈øtome, that when any of them were deliuered of childe, ≈øhe ≈øhould v≈øe recreations, and bathings, and other things nece≈ø≈øarie for women in that ca≈øe,The punishment of yong Nuns vvhen they be g ‚Ä¢ t vvith child. and the Nunnes would come a go≈ø≈øipping vnto hyr, and bring h ‚Ä¢ r pre≈øents. But bicau≈øe that the correction that belonged to the order ≈øhoulde not be abrogated, at the moneths ende ≈øhe mu≈øt come naked into the Chapterhou≈øe before them all, and receyue three ≈øtrypes at euery one of hir ≈øi≈øters handes with a Fore tayle, whiche alwayes hunge vp in the Chapter hou≈øe for that purpo≈øe. In a certaine Mona≈øterie were a companie of olde Nunnes, that had bene good fellowes in their youth, vnto whom the yong Nunnes cleaued very fa≈øt.Of the yong Nuns that vvere re≈øtrained of their libertie. It fortuned the olde ladie Priore≈ø≈øe died, and there ≈øucceeded one that was more ≈øeuere in hir roume which forbad the comming in of religious men, or any other vnto them. So that the yong Nunnes ≈øeing them≈øelues re≈øtrayned of their libertie, ≈øayde vnto the elder Nunnes: happie are you, Si≈øters, for you lo≈øt your virginiti ‚Ä¢ in your youth, whiche if you had nowe, there were as ≈ømall hope for you to loo≈øe it as is for v≈ø.Other that ≈øaid in con ‚Ä¢ e≈ø≈øioÃÑ, it vvas good rea≈øon to proue all thing. A certaine Nunne conf ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øing ‚Ä¢ yr ≈øelfe vnto a Bi≈øhop, that ≈øhe had ≈øinned in the acte of the fl ‚Ä¢ ≈øh: he ≈øharply reproued hyr for ≈øo doing, and demaund ‚Ä¢ d what cau≈øe moued hyr thereto, and ≈øhee an≈øweared, good rea≈øon, for it is written, proue all thing. Yea, ≈øayde the Bi≈øhop, but if you had read all that text, you had not done it, for it foloweth in the ≈øame place, keepe that whiche is good. But ≈øh√©e an≈øweared, O my Lorde, I did not turne ouer the leafe.

Of frier CoÃÑ
‚Ä¢ ade that called for ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ger in the ‚Ä¢ unrie.One, Frier Conrade, dining once in a Nunrie, called at the table for vineger, and the Nunnes ≈øayde then had none. That is maruell, quod the Frier, beyng ≈øo many broken ve≈ø≈øels in the hou≈øe.

div.head: Chap. 40. Of many merie ie≈øtes of ≈øy≈øters.
div.p: A Certaine Sy≈øter in a Priory, b√©eing an old mery wenche,Of a merie vvench in a Priorie ≈øaid that none might iu≈øtly finde faulte vvith her behauiour. made her boa≈øt that none could finde any fault with her behauior. For ≈øayd ≈øh√©e, if I laugh it is good fellow≈øhip, if I w√©epe it is deuotion, if I ≈øpeake it is Philo≈øophie, if I holde my peace it is religion, if I ≈øl√©epe it is quietne≈ø≈øe, if I ry≈øe it is a vi≈øion, and ≈øo of many thinges more. But th√©e forgat one thing, that the more ≈øhee gloryed, the more foole ≈øh√©e was counted.

A mery fellow that would faine ≈øet out the ydle occupations,Of a merye fellovv that drevv a paterne of all the ≈øy≈øters idlene≈ø≈øe. wherin the ≈øy≈øters bu≈øyed them ≈øelues: He made a ‚Ä¢ yrle, wherin h√©e painted how thr√©e ≈øy≈øters were ≈øtealing of one goo≈øe: one helde him by the legge, another layde a knife vppon his necke: and the the third ≈øtrake the knife with an hammar: and round about the cyrcle it was thus written: Looke how the≈øe thr√©e holye ≈øy≈øters are occupied about ≈øtealing of a goo≈øe, ≈øo are all the re≈øt al≈øo. Certaine ≈øy≈øters conferred togyther on a tyme,Hovve the ≈øy≈øters imagined for each a ≈øeuerall death. by what deathes they would wy≈øhe to dye. One ≈øayd I would de≈øyre to b√©e hanged in the coard of contemplacion, according to the ≈øaying of Iob. The other ≈øayd, I would choo≈øe to b√©e buryed in the graue of humilitie. The thyrde coueted to b√©e burnt in the fyre of charitye: And the fowrth to b√©e drowned in the teares of compunction. But howe farre theyr inwarde thoughtes were differing from theyr outward hipocri≈øy, theyr holie and cha≈øt liues dyd well declare. A ≈øy≈øter being in the mona≈øterie bare headed and in her peticote onely:Hovve a ≈øy≈øter vncouered her lovver part to hyde her face from the Friar. two Friars knocked at the gate, and ≈øh√©e ran to the gate and opened it. And being a≈øhamed bicau≈øe ≈øh√©e was bare headed, ≈øh√©e tooke vp the tayle of her peticoate to ca≈øt ouer her head, and vncouered her naked buttockes, and ran away as fa≈øt as ≈øh√©e could. Then one of the Fryars calling vnto her, wylled, her to couer her naked partes, ≈øaying, it is better to ≈ø√©e a womans bare top, then her bare tayle. It fortuned that in a Priorye one night, there was a Prie≈øt founde a bed with one of the ≈øy≈øters, vnto who≈øe chamber many other of the ≈øy≈øters flocked to ≈ø√©e the ≈øyght.Of the tvvo ≈øy≈øters that were taken a bed vvith tvvo prie≈øts. And when another of the ≈øy≈øters, in who≈øe bed a;l≈øo at that pre≈øent there laye a Prie≈øt, heard this ≈øtyrre, making ha≈øt to goe ≈øee the
other, thinking to couer her head with her accu≈øtomed vayle, threw the Prie≈øts breaches vpon her head, and came vnto that mery or rather lameÃÑtable ≈øpectable to bewayle yt ca≈øe among y‚Ä¢ other, as though ≈øh√©e had bene gyltie of no ≈øuch matter. But when one of the ≈øy≈øters ≈øaw the breach: O ≈øy≈øter ≈øayd ≈øh√©e, and dearely beloued fellowe, what thing is this, or what meaneth this ≈øtrange ≈øight? who then beholding her owne naughtine≈ø≈øe, was much a≈øtoni≈øhed, and becau≈øe of this accident, the other e≈øcaped vnpuni≈øhed, for that ≈øh√©e was founde not to b√©e in that faulte alone.

div.head: Chap. 41. Of many merye Dreames.
div.p:
VAlerius in the fir≈øt booke and ≈øeuenth Chapter, writeth, that Alexander the king of Macedonie, novve king Alexander vvas vvarned in a dreame of one that should kyll him. was warned of the hand yt ≈øhould ≈ølay him in his dreame, before that he felt it to be true in effect, for he thought that he ≈øawe him in his ≈øl√©epe yt ≈øhould kyll him. And ≈øhortly after, when he ≈øaw the partie, and knew that he was Antipaters ≈øonne, he declared the vanitie of his dreame, and he ca≈øt out of his minde the ≈øu≈øpicion which h√©e had conceyued of the poy≈øon, whereof he dyed at Ca≈ø≈øanders handes. Lykewi≈øe he telleth that whyl≈øt Amilcar, that was captaine of the Carthagians, Of the dreame of Amilcar the captaine. lay in ≈øiege about the Cittie of Syracu≈øe, he thought that in his dreame he hearde a voyce which ≈øayd, that the night following he ≈øhould ≈øuppe within the City. Then Amilcar being carele≈ø≈øe, or rather thinking him≈øelf ≈øure of the victorie, was ≈øomewhat negligent in not loking carefullye to his Armie, vpon whome the Syracu≈øians i≈ø≈øuing forth the next daye, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed his tentes, tooke him pri≈øoner, and led him into the Citie,Of the the dreame of Fryar Iohn of Duren. where the ≈øame night he ≈øupped not as a conquerour, but as a captiue. Fryer Iohn of Duren, dreamed one nyght, that h√©e rode vpon a ≈ønayle, hauing two long hornes, & that his armes touched the grounde, and how the boyes in the ≈øtr ‚Ä¢ etes ≈øeeing him, laughed and ≈øhouted at him: after which dreame,Of the farmar that dreamed vvher great tre≈øure vvas to be found. as he ≈øayd, he had verye good fortune, but wherein, he would not tell. A countrey man dwelling neere Rati≈øbona, dreamed that vpon the bridge at Rati≈øbona he ≈øhould find great trea≈øure. And comming thyther in the morning verye
earlye for that purpo≈øe, he met with a rytch man which a≈øked him what he ≈øought, and he told him the cau≈øe of his comming, and how and whereof he had dreamed the night before. Then the rytch man vp with his fy≈øt, & gaue him a boxe on the eare, ≈øaying: Ah foole, wylt thou beleeue dreames? I my ≈øelfe dreamed this night, how that in the vyllage of Regendolf in ≈øuch a place, (naming a certaine farme place) I ≈øhoulde finde a great ≈øumme of money, but I meane not to be ≈øo much a foole as to goe ≈ø√©eke it. But when the countrey man heard this, and perceyuing that it was his owne farme where he dwelt, thought within him≈øelf, it is happie for mee that I came hyther this day to haue a boxe on the eare, & going home immediatlye, dygged in the place which the other named, and found a ritch trea≈øure.Of the CaÃÑ non that made ver≈øes in his ≈øleepe.

A certaine Cannon in VVerda nigh to the Rhine, which neuer could make ver≈øe in all his lyfe, dreamed of the≈øe two ver≈øes in his ≈øl√©epe, which he remembred well when he awaked, to this effect.
The wordes of reuenge, a bytter doome hath giuen on thee.
Though thou ne knowe≈øt, how that thy life shall shortly ended bee.
And when he had openly told it at the table, one of his familyars ≈øaid vnto him, what euer it ≈øhould ≈øignify, if I were in your ca≈øe, I would take order with my goodes, & di≈øpo≈øe them as I thought be≈øt, what≈øoeuer ≈øhould befall: but others ≈øayd it was but a tryfle, & that dreames were not to be accoumpted of. But he being ≈øtroken into a dumpe, gat him vpon his hor≈øe, & tooke his hawke vpon his fy≈øt, & roade abroade into the fieldes for plea≈øure, to dige≈øt the melancholy. And comming homeward at night, where he mu≈øt ryde ouer a bridge yt lay ouer an arme of the Rhine, his hor≈øe began to ≈øtriue and plunge, and threwe them both headlong into the Rhine, and there were drowned.

div.head: Chap. 42. Of diuers and ≈øundrie Artificers.
div.p: MAcrobius in the ≈øecond booke of the Saturnalia, Hovve Seruilius a≈øked a painter vvhy hee painted not as vvell for him ≈øelfe as for others. wryteth yt when Seruilius of Rome, beheld the children of Mallius, an excelleÃÑt painter, how mi≈øhapen & euyl fauored they were, ≈øayd vnto him, Mallius why doe≈øt thou not paint likewi≈øe a≈øwel for thy ≈øelfe, as thou doe≈øt for other men? To whome Mallius an≈øwered, I deui≈øe in the night time, but I paynt in the day.

of a keruer that carued Pi≈ømares.One Gallatricus a keruer, made Pi≈ømares of yuorie of ≈øo ≈ømall quantitie, that they were no bygger, neyther coulde be di≈øcerned from tho≈øe Pi≈ømares that lyued in d√©ede.
